DOC.HEAD: Family Drops Custody Battle For Beaten Dog
DOC.TEXT: The family of a teen-ager convicted of beating his dog with a plank dropped their bid to retain custody of the animal after animal rights activists flooded a court with protest letters. Applause broke out in the Lowell District Court Friday when lawyer F. Andrew Turley said the family of owner Kevin Deschene had decided to drop their claim to 19-month-old Champ, a German shepherd-collie. More than 21,000 signatures were brought to the court demanding the family be denied custody because of photographs a neighbor took in November that showed Deschene beating Champ with a 4-foot wooden plank. Deschene, 19, was sentenced last month to a year in prison for a misdemeanor complaint of cruelty to animals. Six months of the conviction were suspended. The photographs by neighbor Jim Molloy were widely publicized. Deschene said he was disciplining Champ for tearing up garbage. ``This was a very difficult time for Kevin and the family,'' Turley said after the hearing Friday. ``They had Champ for eight or nine months. They loved that dog.'' Kim Deschene, Kevin's sister, was arrested after Friday's hearing for alleged witness intimidation against Molloy, said Lowell Police Sgt. Steven Smith. Barbara Deschene, Kevin's mother, also was arrested Friday _ on an unrelated charge of alleged larceny in a welfare fraud, Smith said. Allan Davidson, the executive director of the Lowell Humane Society who has been caring for Champ since Nov. 28, said his office had received more than 3,700 letters from people across the country asking that Champ not be returned to the Deschene family. ``Even Doris Day sent a telegram the day before yesterday asking us to keep the dog away from the family and put him in a loving home,'' Davidson said. Day is an active animal rights campaigner. ``The new home will provide him with the love and care he needs,'' Davidson said. He would not disclose where the dog's new home, saying he feared reprisals from the Deschene family. Esther Nowell, president of Protection of Animals in Wakefield Society, or PAWS, was one of the many animal rights activists who attended the hearing. ``I feel that justice has been done,'' Ms. Nowell said.``For the first time in my memory a man has gone to jail and is having to actually serve time for cruelty to animals. Then he's says he wants the dog back? It's not right.'' Turley said the family dropped the custody battle because they were afraid that when they got Champ back in their home, ``the circus would never end.'' ``They want to get on with their lives,'' Turley said. Wounds on Champ's head and thighs have healed, but the psychological effects will be with him for the rest of his life, Davidson said.

DOC.HEAD: Greece Recalls Ambassador Over Incident at Embassy in Albania
DOC.TEXT: Greece recalled its ambassador from Albania after accusing that country's security officials of pursuing an asylum seeker into the Greek embassy, beating him, and dragging him away. Greek officials say armed Albanian security officials moved into embassy in Tirana, the Albanian capital, on Sunday. They say the officials beat the asylum seeker and took him away. Ambassador Spyros Dokianos was recalled to Athens on Friday for consultations, said government spokesman Vyron Polydoras. Relations between the two neighboring Balkan countries have been tense since late last year. Greece says an ethnic Greek minority is mistreated in Albania, Europe's last hard-line Communist nation. Albania has an ethnic Greek minority of about 250,000 in a population of more than 3 million. Religious worship is forbidden and attempts to flee the country are punished severely.

DOC.HEAD: Havel Backed for Re-election as President
DOC.TEXT: A leading opposition group has endorsed President Vaclav Havel for re-election in a parliamentary vote next month, the state news agency said. Jan Urban, leader of the opposition Civic Forum, announced his group's support, the CTK news agency reported Friday. Havel, a dissident playwright who had been jailed by the country's former Communist authorities, was elected president in December in the wake of democratic reforms. At the time, Havel said he would accept the presidency only temporarily until a new president was chosen by a freely elected parliament. Sources close to Havel now say he may want to continue as president after the June elections, but for no longer than two years. Parliament on Wednesday approved a two-year term for the next president to match the terms of lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Hacker Sentenced To Three Years Probation
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said the light sentence given a computer hacker whose ``worm'' shut down a nationwide network would not deter them from cracking down on computer abuse. Robert T. Morris Jr., 25, was sentenced Friday to three years probation, fined $10,000 and ordered to perform 400 hours community service. Although the Justice Department had asked that Morris be given jail time, U.S. Attorney Frederick Scullin Jr. said he believed the sentence was fair. ``This is sort of a unique circumstance,'' he said. ``I don't feel it's going to be any sort of a precedent.'' Scullin said future computer hackers may face stricter sentences. ``Would-be hackers are now on notice that the Department of Justice will vigorously prosecute future computer criminals and seek severe penalties, regardless of what their motives are,'' he said. U.S. District Judge Howard Munson said there were no previous cases that could be used as a model for sentencing. In January, Morris became the first person to be convicted under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act for breaking into a federal computer network and preventing authorized use of the system. The former Cornell University graduate student was found guilty of creating a ``worm'' program on Nov. 2, 1988 that invaded an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet research system used at NASA, military facilities and major universities. Once in the system, the program replicated itself wildly, paralyzing the network. Under federal sentencing guidelines, Morris faced up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. But his attorneys argued that the case did not fit the guidelines. ``This is not your garden-variety fraud crime,'' attorney David O'Brien said. ``This crime was not motivated by malice. It was not motivated by an intention to do harm. It was an experiment _ albeit a reckless, irresponsible, stupid one.'' Defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni said the sentence was reasonable, but he will file an appeal to challenge the law under which Morris was convicted. ``I don't believe Mr. Morris deserves to be a felon for what he did,'' Guidoboni said. Morris did not speak at the sentencing and did not talk to reporters afterward. When the sentence was announced, he smiled and hugged his mother. Robert Morris Sr., a scientist at the National Computer Security Center in Bethesda, Md., said he does not consider his son a criminal. ``There is real computer crime in this country,'' he said. ``It is rampant and extremely expensive, and this case did not begin to touch on that.'' Morris, who was suspended from Cornell after the worm incident, works at a computer-related job in Cambridge, Mass. He testified at his trial that the worm was an experiment that went out of control because of a programming error he made. He admitted he designed the worm to attack the Internet system but said it wasn't supposed to replicate as it did. Prosecutors described his program as a ``full-scale assault'' and said Morris took deliberate steps to make the worm difficult to trace and eradicate.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanian Leader Says Western Support Crucial for Independence
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene says a strong declaration of support by Western nations could be decisive in bringing the Baltic republics independence from the Soviet Union. Mrs. Prunskiene's two-day, non-stop crusade for Lithuanian independence at the White House, State Department and on Capitol Hill resulted in an inconclusive session with President Bush. But she said Friday that she continues to hope that Bush and other world leaders can yet be persuaded that embracing independence for Lithuania and its neighbors Latvia and Estonia will not undermine Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his program of political and economic reform. She said the reluctance of Western nations to recognize an independent Lithuania now is ``the main factor'' in the Soviets' refusal to accept her republic's secession as an accomplished fact. Mrs. Prunskiene will meet with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in London on Tuesday and is expected to use the occasion to appeal once more for Western guarantees of Lithuanian sovereignty. Such guarantees are essential, she said, for Lithuanian participation in any compromise calling for the temporary suspension of independence laws. Mrs. Prunskiene's last scheduled appearance in the United States was an address today to the Lithuanian Youth Association here. Speaking on Friday at the National Press Club, the Lithuanian leader said the summit between Bush and Gorbachev opening here on May 30 offers a crucial opportunity to cement Baltic independence. That would end a chapter begun 50 years ago when the Soviet Union forcibly annexed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia after striking a secret deal with Nazi Germany's Adolf Hitler. But Mrs. Prunskiene said the United States and the West must act more decisively than they have to date if that is to become a reality. She said Western guarantees are needed because merely urging good-faith negotiations with Moscow is no answer to her republic's insistence on eventual true independence. ``Simply making statements that there should be cooperation is not adequate at this time when the Soviets are interfering in Lithuania's ties with other countries,'' Mrs. Prunskiene said. She appealed to Bush to withhold the preferred trade and tariff status the Soviets have eagerly sought as an opening to the world's markets. Granting ``most favored nation'' preferences while the Soviets are tightening their economic blockade of Lithuania ``would be providing implicit support for their actions.'' she said. But in a policy shift, Mrs. Prunskiene dropped demands for the immediate imposition of retaliatory U.S. economic sanctions against the Kremlin, possibly out of concern that step might anger Lithuania's supporters among the Soviet Union's emerging pro-democracy forces. ``We would hope the imposition of economic sanctions would be held in reserve as a threat to our eventually sitting down at the negotiating table, because we are not looking for a situation where the Soviet people are forced to suffer,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 250,000 AIDS Cases Reported Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 17,000 new cases of AIDS were registered in April, raising the number of victims reported worldwide to 254,078, the World Health Organization said. In the report released Friday, Uganda told the U.N. agency last month that 12,444 AIDS cases had occurred by the end of December, compared with 7,375 in April 1989. The new figures mean Uganda replaces its central African neighbor Zaire as the second worst affected country worldwide. Zaire reported 11,732 cases by the end of January. The United States reported 126,127 cases of the deadly disease, nearly half the official international total and up 1,945 from March. In South America, Brazil reported the highest total. It registered 10,510 cases as of March, up from 9,555 in December. AIDS, caused by a virus that attacks the immune system, is spread mainly by sexual contact, the use of contaminated needles among drug abusers, and blood transfusions.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Some Nuclear Weapons Still Needed in Europe
LaserPhoto KO1
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says that even as he slashes new missile systems and negotiates with the Soviets to reduce others, nuclear weapons are still needed in Europe. ``Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have insured peace in Europe,'' he said Friday in the first of a series of commencement speeches he will make on the changing geopolitical face of the world. Bush said that in addition to scrapping upgraded Lance missiles in Europe, he wants to begin talks with the Soviets to reduce other short-range missiles shortly after signing a treaty on reducing conventional forces next fall. Nonetheless, he said, ``The United States is not going to allow Europe to become `safe for conventional war.''' Thus, the nuclear component must remain to protect Europe in concert with conventional elements such as troops and tanks, he said. A senior administration official, briefing reporters on Air Force One under condition of anonymity, said, ``We think there needs to be some nuclear weapons in Europe. Deterrence has to have a nuclear component.'' Bush said the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries, meeting in late June or early July, should outline ``the minimum number and types of weapons that will be needed to deter war, credibly and effectively.'' He said ``militarily significant'' U.S. forces would remain in Europe, where some 300,000 now are stationed. In the address at Oklahoma State University, the president elaborated on his call for the NATO summit to completely review the alliance's mission, both military and political, in light of the dramatic democratic reforms in the Warsaw Pact countries. Bush later flew to Tulsa and spoke to the Oklahoma Foundation for Excellence, which honored 100 outstanding high school seniors. He also attended a Republican fund-raising reception. The president's recent acknowledgment that he hates broccoli was well noted on the Oklahoma stop. At the airport, a child held a large hand-drawn poster of Bush in a boxing ring standing triumphantly over a felled broccoli opponent. ``Bush beats broccoli,'' the poster said. The president autographed it for the child. Later he joked that someone in the graduation crowd had a sign reading, ``George, eat your broccoli.'' ``I don't need advice from little kids on what I eat,'' he exclaimed. Bush flew Friday night to Camp David, Md., and returns to the White House on Sunday for budget talks with congressional leaders. The meeting comes after a week that saw the Senate Budget Committee and the House adopt separate, Democratic-written budgets for next year. Each one strips nearly $10 billion from Bush's own military spending proposal for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. The budget itself does not require Bush's signature, but he must sign separate bills that finance programs or raise and lower taxes. Administration officials and Republican lawmakers have been pressing all year for budget negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Commander Critical of Explosion Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The skipper of the USS Iowa fired a departing salvo at the Navy, saying it had mishandled a probe into the gun turret explosion that killed 47 sailors aboard his ship last year. Facing the guns of the battleship where the sailors died on April 19, 1989, Capt. Fred P. Moosally said at his retirement ceremony Friday the men who handled the report were more interested in the Navy's image than the good of the crew. Moosally said the investigation was handled by people who used ``facts and opinions based on unsubstantiated third-party information, unsubstantiated reports and supposition.'' The Navy's investigation concluded sabotage by Gunner's Mate Clayton Hartwig caused the blast. It said Hartwig, who died in the blast, was disgruntled and suicidal about how the Navy had treated him for promotion and assignments. ``People who in their rush to manage the Iowa problem forgot about doing the right thing for the Iowa crew,'' said Moosally, a 24-year veteran. ``The explosion ... was a dual tragedy. Forty-seven men died and 1,500 survivors were made victims when they should have been heros,'' Moosally said. Moosally had previously been tight-lipped about the six-month Navy investigation of the explosion that sent a deadly fireball running inside turret No. 2. At the end of the ceremony he was awarded the Legion of Merit for leadership aboard the Iowa following the explosion. Moosally's word were soothing to some of the relatives of the dead sailors. ``I've been waiting for this day, because I was hoping and praying that the man will really speak his mind about the accident,'' Kathy Kubicina, Hartwig's sister, said in a telephone interview from her home in Cleveland, Ohio. Ms. Kubicina and other families have been fighting to get the Navy to reopen its investigation. Two congressional inquiries have reviewed the report, which several members of Congress have said is flawed. ``This is just great news. For the captain of the ship to say it was inadequate, that really tells a lot,'' said Ms. Kubicina. A Navy spokesman in Washington, Lt. Mark Walker, said Moosally's criticism of the investigation was his personal opinion. ``The investigating officer, Rear Adm. Richard Milligan, and his team were extremely thorough and professional throughout the investigation.'' Walker said Milligan's conclusions were reached ``after an intense methodical investigation during which the Navy conducted more than 20,000 technical tests that ruled out possible accidental causes.'' John Hague, whose stepson, Philip Buch, died in the explosion, has defended the Navy's report in the past. But he agreed with Moosally the Iowa crew had been slighted. ``There is no doubt in my mind that those men are heroes,'' he said from his home in La Mesa, N.M. Nancy Lewis of Northville, Mich., whose son, Richard, was killed in the explosion, said Moosally ``has joined the ranks of many of the rest of us on how the report was handled. .. Maybe the Navy is trying to do the right thing.'' Moosally, a 1966 graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy, was succeeded by his executive officer, Cmdr. John P. Morse. The battleship is expected to be decommissioned and put in mothballs later this year.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Praises Naming of Presidential Emergency Board
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's appointment of an emergency board to help resolve a labor dispute over rising health care costs in the railroad industry is winning praise from labor leaders. The board is needed to head off a ``crippling nationwide rail strike,'' the White House said Friday in naming a panel to help settle bargaining disputes between 11 unions and the nation's major railroads. Negotiators have been trying to reach a contract for two years, but rising health care costs for 300,000 workers remain an obstacle. A few months ago, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole appointed a commission to study health care costs within the coal industry, a key issue in last year's bitter Pittston strike. Dick Kilroy, chairman of the Cooperating Railway Labor Organizations, which represents the 11 unions, said health care costs in the railroad industry have been rising between 15 percent and 20 percent a year, and were expected to continue on that path for another five years. ``It's an issue that really doesn't belong on the bargaining table,'' Kilroy said. Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the AFL-CIO, called Bush's action ``very encouraging'' because, with Pittston, it was ``the second recognition of the overwhelming problem.'' Both sides in the dispute had expected the White House to appoint the board, an action that in effect provides a 60-day cooling-off period before any strike can occur. Bush was criticized by labor leaders last year when he declined to appoint an emergency board in the strike by machinists at Eastern Airlines. That was the first time, to the National Mediation Board's knowledge, that a president had not acted once the board notified him of a potential emergency within the transportation industry. Bush created the three-member railroad board under authority given him by the Railway Labor Act. Under that law, labor contracts stay in force during negotiations, essentially postponing their expiration indefinitely. If the two sides reach an impasse in their talks, other provisions of the law trigger various forms of government intervention leading up to the creation of an emergency board, if the president decides to appoint one. Administration officials said the railroad impasse differs from the airline strike. Both sides in the railroad dispute were seeking White House help, they said, but Texas Air Corp., Eastern's parent company, did not want an emergency board named in that dispute. In addition, the Eastern walkout has disrupted only a portion of the airline industry while a railroad strike would affect the entire nation. A White House statement said the railroad dispute ``threatens substantially to interrupt interstate commerce to a degree such as to deprive various sections of the country of essential transportation service.'' ``The Department of Transportation has advised that the railroads move over one-third of all intercity freight traffic, which involves goods valued at more than $1 billion each day,'' the statement said. A rail strike, besides idling railroad workers and stranding riders, could cause more than 500,000 layoffs within two weeks in industries served by railroads, the White House said. ``The direct costs of a strike could be at least $16 million per day, and the indirect economic costs could be much higher,'' it said. The members of the emergency board are Robert O. Harris of Washington, ombudsman for the International Monetary Fund, who will serve as chairman; and labor arbitrators Richard R. Kasher of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Arthur Stark of New York.

DOC.HEAD: Some Progress Reported at Trade Parlay
DOC.TEXT: The United States and its major trading partners are proclaiming progress in an ambitious effort to overhaul the global trading system while also conceding that serious obstacles remain. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and her counterparts from Japan, the 12-nation European Community and Canada said Friday that they had been able to better define the differences that exist between them during three days of talks at a posh resort in California wine country. Japanese Trade Minister Kabun Muto called the discussions ``frank and useful.'' Canadian Trade Minister John Crosbie said he believed they had been successful in ``turning the heat up'' to provide momentum toward an agreement. But the officials conceded there had been no major breakthroughs in the discussions and that such contentious issues as agricultural subsidies and barriers to trade in textiles remained far from settled. Global trade talks, being conducted through the 97-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, were launched at a conference in Uruguay in 1986 and are scheduled to conclude this December. The Bush administration is counting on a successful outcome to boost sales by American businesses and farmers and thus lower the huge U.S. trade deficit. Specifically, it is seeking agreement to phase out within 10 years costly farm subsidies, to broaden GATT rules to include service industries such as banking and insurance and to strengthen protection against copyright piracy, which costs American companies $60 billion annually. But the European Community, seeking to protect its network of small farms, is fighting the effort to slash farm subsidies while Third World nations oppose lowering barriers for service industries, contending that they need to protect fledgling domestic businesses. Hills said she was still hopeful that the differences can be resolved. She said she expected an outline of a final agreement to be completed during a negotiating session in late July. With time running out on the four-year effort to reform the global trading system, Hills said the negotiators would appeal to President Bush and other leaders at the July summit of seven industrialized nations to supply a ``political push'' to break the stalemates. Still, without a decision by some countries to compromise, the final outcome of the free-trade talks was uncertain. One U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said it was likely the toughest issues would not be resolved until the final bargaining session seven months from now in Brussels. ``Negotiations are a process of attrition,'' he said. ``It is just in the nature of things with issues that are hard-fought.'' Frans Andriessen, trade minister for the European Community, said the wealthy nations needed to try harder to make the trade package attractive to developing countries to ensure their support in the final round of bargaining. If an agreement is reached, the administration must still persuade Congress to accept the document. Already, U.S. special interests from textile manufacturers to sugar and peanut growers are lining up congressional supporters to oppose any trade agreement that results in a loss of trade protections they now enjoy.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Government Listing of Seized Noriega Assets
DOC.TEXT: The seized assets of Manuel Noriega include some of $11 million he got from U.S. intelligence agencies, his lawyers argued, while asking that the government be forced to release the money so they can be paid. A federal judge Friday ordered the government to justify its seizure of the deposed Panamanian leader's $20 million in assets, which defense attorneys claim were earned legitimately. Noriega's lawyers argued during an hourlong hearing that they cannot proceed without money from bank accounts frozen by the government. They subpoenaed records from the CIA, Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies as a way to prove Noriega's income was not from drug trafficking. Frank Rubino, Noriega's lead attorney, told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler that U.S. intelligence agencies had paid Noriega $11 million during his years in the Panamanian National Guard. ``I don't know if you can call money from the CIA tainted or not, but it's certainly not drug money,'' Rubino said. Noriega was paid another $6 million or $7 million by foreign governments, the defense claimed at the hearing, which was not attended by Noriega. Noriega was indicted in Miami in February 1988 on charges of taking money from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to make Panama a safe haven for cocaine smuggling. He surrendered to U.S. authorities Jan. 4, two weeks after U.S. troops invaded Panama. The judge appeared sympathetic to the defense's position that the seizure of assets was unreasonable. ``It appears he must have acquired some assets of his own in his 20 years as an officer,'' Hoeveler said. The judge ordered the U.S. attorney's office to come up with a list of Noriega's seized assets and justify their confiscation. He also indicated he expected them to cooperate fully with the defense subpoenas, which were served Thursday. Hoeveler said while Noriega clearly could not use ``ill-gotten gains'' to pay his attorneys, the government could not arbitrarily seize money without proving he had earned it through drug trafficking or other illegal means. Rubino said at the hearing that $5.8 million confiscated by U.S. troops in Noriega's quarters in Panama was given back to the Panamanian government by the United States without informing Noriega's lawyers. He said the government never established whether that money was acquired illegally. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said the government did not object to making a list of the bank accounts. But he said all the accounts, except one, were in foreign banks. ``Foreign governments will have some interest (in the money) and their laws will prevail over those assets,'' Sullivan said. In court papers, Rubino said the government already has spent $12 million and was prepared to spend $25 million more prosecuting Noriega. Rubino said the defense has the right to use Noriega's funds to hire more attorneys, investigators and secretaries. Sullivan responded with an affidavit from another prosecutor who said Rubino told her he had received a retainer of ``seven figures'' from Noriega. Rubino has acknowledged the comment but said it was a joke. Rubino said attorneys learned ``the intelligence community is in possession of evidence that completely exonerates General Noriega as to a particular count of the indictment,'' but said the defense lacks the money to pursue the lead. The prosecution says the money at issue is held in 27 bank accounts. ``Only one of these accounts, located in Panama, is in the defendant's name,'' a government motion said, adding investigators are not even sure if it contains any money. Noriega is being held at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Since school rules said they couldn't wear shorts, a few boys at a high school decided to protest. They wore skirts. Principal Noel Long said no one was suspended or missed class because of Thursday's protest. Darell Wilson, 17, said at least three boys wore skirts. ``I heard some students in a classroom guffawing'' at one male student who wore a skirt over his pants, Long said. ``I told him if he insisted on disrupting the classroom I would have to suspend him,'' Long said. The student removed the skirt. Student Corey Vann said Long made an announcement over the intercom Thursday morning asking teachers to send boys wearing skirts to the office. ``I think it's stupid,'' Vann said of the rule. ``Girls can wear 'em.'' According to a school handbook, neither sex is allowed to wear shorts.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Exports: Jeers from Critics, Cheers from Tobacco Industry
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette opponents want the U.S. government to end policies that they say help tobacco companies increase their sales in Asia to offset declines in the United States. The United States was long admired for its lifesaving medical advances, but ``now, because of the aggressive advertising of the tobacco industry, we are acquiring a different reputation in the Third World _ as exporters of disease and death,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., told his Labor and Human Resources Committee on Friday. Kennedy charged that the U.S. government ``has been an accomplice ... threatening trade sanctions against countries which restrict access to American cigarettes.'' The senator's comments were the latest round in an escalating conflict between the tobacco industry and critics who want to halt government efforts to expand the foreign market for U.S. brand cigarettes in the name of free trade. ``Free trade is not a license to export lung cancer or ride roughshod over the anti-smoking laws of other nations,'' Kennedy said. Walter D. Huddleston, a witness for the U.S. Cigarette Export Association, countered that the issue is not health but trade and jobs for American tobacco growers and workers. ``The same number of cigarettes are going to be smoked in foreign countries regardless of whether American products are there or not,'' he said. ``The only issue is who makes them ... who grows the tobacco .... We are not exporting the practice of smoking.'' But William Foege, former director of the Centers for Disease Control, testified that ``when U.S. manufacturers enter a market in a developing country, they not only bring cigarettes, they bring marketing and advertising techniques far superior to those existing.'' Smoking is declining about 1 percent a year in advanced countries but rising at least 2 percent in the Third World, Foege said. He predicted that it would become the leading cause of death in developing countries by the end of the decade, killing more people annually than the 6 million believed slaughtered during the entire Holocaust. The government's success in opening markets to U.S. cigarette brands in Japan, South Korea and Taiwan and a current effort in Thailand drew praise from witnesses representing the industry and tobacco-growing states and in a letter from 120 House members delivered earlier this week to U.S. trade representative Carla Hills. Dr. Gregory Connolly, testifying for the American Cancer Society and Heart and Lung Associations, said cigarette consumption was declining in Japan until the market was opened to American countries. It then rose 3 percent, while the increase in Taiwan was 4 percent, he said. In 1987, cigarettes rose from 40th to second place in total Japanese television advertising time, heavily targeting women and youths, Connolly said. Describing tobacco exports as ``a success story,'' industry witnesses said tobacco was one of the few U.S. exports earning a surplus last year, more than $4.2 billion, to help offset the $109 billion trade deficit. Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass., said hearings will be held later this month on House legislation to bar the U.S. trade representative from intervening on behalf of tobacco exports. The bill also would require U.S. tobacco brands sold abroad to carry the same health warnings as in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Plenty of For-Sale Signs on Millionaires Row
DOC.TEXT: Thinking of buying a place to get away on those hot summer weekends? How about a replica of an 18th century French chateau or the mansion that once belonged to famed author Edith Wharton? Real estate agents claim that an economic downturn in New England property hasn't hit Newport's ritziest neighborhoods, where up-for-sale mansions abound. ``There are some wonderful opportunities _ if you can afford it,'' said Robin Corbin, owner of the real estate agency Private Properties. Newport's Bellevue Avenue, known as Millionaires Row, has at least three homes for sale and more than a dozen condominiums. Other castle-like homes are listed in some of the less visible, but perhaps more opulent, neighborhoods of this high-society city that once hosted the America's Cup and is home to the Tennis Hall of Fame. Jacqueline Cranwell of Gustave J.S. White Real Estate, an affiliate of Sotheby's International Realty, said there is nothing unusual about the number of Newport spreads listed. ``All the houses we have on the market are on for various reasons, nothing to do with money problems,'' Cranwell said. ``It's just the normal turnover.'' The people who own dwellings of this sort aren't the kind affected by seasonal turns of the economy, she said. ``If you have money, you have it,'' Cranwell said. But there is some evidence to the contrary. A four-bedroom, brick carriage house on 1\ acres was listed for seven months at $2.8 million and sold only after the price was lowered to $1.3 million, Cranwell said. And some who may be able to purchase estates only with financing may not qualify in slower economic times, Corbin said. The Rhode Island Association of Realtors said the Northeast has been the hardest hit area in a nationwide slump. In the first quarter, Rhode Island home sales declined 8.5 percent from the same period last year. In Newport, the median price for a single-family home dropped to $140,000, compared to $159,000 a year ago. If you've got the money, the choices are impressive. Bellevue Avenue's Vernon Court, built in 1900 to resemble a French chateau, is one of Newport's grandest homes. The asking price? $2.6 million. A 52-foot-long entrance hall leads to the 15,000-square-foot residence, with six bedrooms for the hosts and 10 for the servants. Although the 3-acre estate is not on the waterfront, it has a heated, 25-foot-by-50-foot swimming pool _ larger than most living rooms. Within a 10-foot-high wall surrounding the yard are two tennis courts and a garden copied from the ones Henry VIII built for Ann Boylen at Hampton Court, Cranwell said. Also up for sale is Lands End on Ledge Road. It was built around 1870 and American novelist Edith Wharton bought the home about 20 years later. Wharton renovated the home with architect Ogden Codman, with whom she wrote the book, ``On the Decoration of Houses,'' one of the first on interior design, Corbin said. The stucco, waterfront home has 10 bedrooms, 5{ acres of land and is ``very typically Ogden Codman,'' who was a colonial revivalist, he said. It's listed for $2.7 million. If your tastes run to gardens, and you have $4.25 million, Wildacre on Ocean Drive might be for you. Its Japanese gardens were designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, who laid out New York City's Central Park. Castle Hill mansion has been on the market for about 1{ years. It's listed at $20 million. The 10,000-square-foot home is set on a 40-acre peninsula with more than 7,000 feet of water frontage and a private dock for 20 boats, Cranwell said. The home, built in 1875, is being used as a restaurant and guest house, but its 10 bedrooms could be converted back to a single-family home, she said. In all, Newport has about 200 mansions in private ownership today, said a spokeswoman for the Newport Preservation Society who would not give her name. At the turn of the century there were about 400 18th- and 19th-century mansions in Newport, but many have been lost do to acts of man and nature, the spokeswoman said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Cost-Cutting Measures Include Cutting Back B-2 Flight Time
DOC.TEXT: The head of the Strategic Air Command says B-2 stealth bomber pilots may fly the radar-evading aircraft only twice a month to hold down expenses. ``I realize how expensive this plane is. ... We plan to fly it twice a month under special circumstances,'' Gen. John T. Chain Jr. told reporters. Budget pressures were the primary impetus behind Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's recent decision to buy only 75 of the bat-winged aircraft instead of the 132 planned, Chain said. ``If weren't for the budget driving the numbers ... 132 would never have come down,'' Chain said. The general oversees the nation's force of nuclear bombers, intercontinental ballistic missiles, tankers and reconnaissance aircraft at SAC in Omaha, Neb. Cheney named budget pressures and the changed situation in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe in presenting his reassessment of the needs for the futuristic strategic bomber last week to Congress. Buying fewer planes will drive up the cost of each bomber. The bombers would cost $530 million apiece if 132 are purchased. If only 75 are bought, they would cost $815 million each, making them the costliest aircraft ever produced. Congressional opposition to the aircraft has grown as lawmakers scramble to glean a ``peace dividend'' from the Pentagon budget. Chain, who has been an ardent advocate on behalf of the 132-bomber request, said he could support the revised figure because of the changes that have brought democratic governments to nations in Eastern Europe. ``One hundred thirty-two was justified in the world in which it was created. ... Seventy-five is an adequate number, an adequate number of warheads for the task we have in the future,'' he said. The four-star general said he believes ``if the world turns ugly'' several years from now, the president could order the number of bombers increased. ``It's not a finite number,'' he said. But Chain said he couldn't support a purchase of fewer than 75 planes.

DOC.HEAD: Jeans, Gauchos And Orange Peels Grace Changed Parliament
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to move up details on long hair and orange peels, EDITS to TRIM. ADDS AP logo.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers in jeans. Long hair. Lapel buttons. Oranges. Once the domain of gray-suited somber Communists, Parliament is more like an old-world coffee house where writers, artists and actors mingle with politicians, professors and lawyers. The new face of Hungary's Parliament reflects the changes that have swept Eastern Europe. Even the social affairs minister in the Communist government that is now history is keeping up with the changing times, donning gauchos in place of her conservative dresses. Like the legislatures of Warsaw and East Berlin, the lofty rotunda was once where aging Communist hard-liners listened to interminable speeches and rubber-stamped legislation. Today 20-to-35-year-old Parliament deputies, the engines of Eastern Europe's stunning transformation, file in en bloc. They are members of the League of Young Democrats, or FIDESZ, and come accompanied by jeans-clad supporters waving balloons and flags. Viktor Orban, a fiery orator and energetic FIDESZ deputy, has long hair and no tie. For the first session of the new free parliament, FIDESZ placed oranges _ their symbol of the failure of Communist ideology to mold reality to its will _ on the lawmakers' desks. At the end of the day, the ashtrays were piled high with orange peels. How do they feel, the former dissidents, often jailed for touting democracy and freedom of speech? ``I expected an emotional touch,'' says Laszlo Rajk, Jr., drawing on a cigarette. ``But it didn't come.'' He looks around for an ashtray in the still unfamiliar surroundings of the vaulted, red-carpeted halls. Did he expect the transition to be this smooth? ``Oh, yes. But not this successful,'' he grins. Did they expect this to happen? ``Ten years ago, no,'' says Miklos Haraszti ``Two years ago,'' he smiles. ``Yes, I did.'' In March 1988 he called an Associated Press reporter to announce he was being detained by police that moment at his home. No reason given. But everyone knew. A demonstration planned the next day. Only one dissident was left free that March 15. He led about 10,000 pro-democracy demonstrators through city streets, weaving them carefully between the lines of truncheon-gripping police. Miklos Tamas-Gaspar sips a glass of wine at the buffet during a break, puffing on a cigar, speaking English with an impeccable British accent. He was elected in a by-election a few months before free national elections in March and April ended Communist rule. ``We won't ask you how you feel,'' jokes a reporter. ``We consider you an old hand now.'' In the chamber itself, something is missing. The Communist coat of arms. It still adorns the walls of schools and state offices where voters went to cast their ballots in the first free elections in more than 40 years. Ominous? ``It's like rennaissance times'' shrugged a member of the Democratic Forum _ the center-right party that now has the mandate to form a new government. Hungarians have ``one foot in the past and the other in the future.'' No new coat of arms has yet been designed. But every other member of Parliament touts a traditional Hungarian emblem in his lapel, along with party affiliation. The red star, balanced for decades on the spire of the sprawling neo-Gothic building, no longer reflects in the Danube river. It was quietly removed in March. The few Socialists _ former Communists, the only ones in Eastern Europe who understood if they hoped to survive they must reform _ were rewarded at the polls with popular anger at so many years of Stalinist oppression. They have only 33 of 394 seats, off to one side. Outgoing interim President Matyas Szueroes, formerly a Communsit foreign policy expert, now takes his seat on a regular bench for lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Germany Offers Moscow Economic Cooperation
With PM-Germany-Allies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German officials are dangling the prospect of more economic ties in front of the Soviets in an effort to soften their adamant rejection of a united Germany as a NATO member. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, in an interview Friday with the West Berlin radio station RIAS, said there could be ``versatile economic relations that would not be disadvantageous to the Soviets Union after German unification.'' However, asked if a united Germany can be in NATO, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze responded Friday shortly after his arrival in West Germany with a firm ``no.'' ``For such a giant to belong to one bloc, one alliance ... will not create conditions for stability,'' he said. The Soviets have called for a neutral Germany. Shevardnadze also met Friday for about 90 minutes with Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The West Germans made clear they were willing to offer something in exchange for a shift in the Kremlin's position on the military posture of a united Germany. Kohl spokesman Hans Klein said the chancellor offered Shevardnadze a significant expansion of bilateral ties, particularly economic cooperation. West Germany is already one of the Soviet Union's biggest trading partners and has indicated a willingness to guarantee East German exports to the Soviet Union. The latest offer seemed to signal Bonn's readiness to expand trade and investments, although Klein did not offer specifics. The Soviet Union has said repeatedly that it opposes allowing a united Germany to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. NATO foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels, Belgium, on Thursday, said they remain in favor of a single German state belonging to the Western alliance. But they also offered several compromise gestures to the Soviets, saying that a united Germany should not have any chemical or nuclear weapons and that Soviet troops could remain in what is now East Germany for several years. The question of security arrangements are a major obstacle at talks beginning today in Bonn among the two Germanys and the four World War II Allies.

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Says Economy Could Give Democrats Leg Up in '92
DOC.TEXT: Richard Nixon, a veteran political prognosticator, says only serious trouble in the economy would give Democrats a chance to recapture the White House in 1992. And the Democrat best equipped to challenge George Bush if the economy turns sour is New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, Nixon said in a television interview aired Friday night. The interview, one of a series the former president has done this week to promote his new book, was broadcast on public television stations. Nixon said Bush is popular because of a ``mistake-free administration,'' while the Democratic opposition is the weakest in 50 years. ``Cuomo would be able to seize on the haves vs. the have-not issue more effectively than any of the other Democrats because of his appeal,'' Nixon said. ``Cuomo has high intelligence. He has heart, or at least he appears to have, and that's what matters.'' Nixon said he seldom offers advice to Bush because ``there's nothing that you appreciate less than having well-intentioned (people), even former presidents, calling and saying, `Why don't you do this, why don't you do that?'''
DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Oppose Barry Motions
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the drug trial of Washington, D.C., Mayor Marion Barry say they should not be required to give his lawyers copies of regulations that govern drug investigations or provide details of the case against him. In another development, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson on Friday scheduled for May 25 a pre-trial hearing on a series of motions by the mayor seeking dismissal of the eight criminal charges against him. Barry's lawyers say he is the victim of prosecutorial ``overreach'' by a U.S. attorney's office that violated government regulations in an FBI sting operation leading to the mayor's arrest. Barry was arrested Jan. 18 after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine in a Washington hotel room. He is accused of five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and three felony counts of lying to a federal grand jury about his involvement with drugs. In one motion, the mayor's lawyers said the government violated its own procedures in the arrest, and demanded the government produce its regulations for undercover drug operations. In a court filing Friday in reply, prosecutors said Barry should not be given the regulations. ``Even if there were a violation of an agency regulation _ and the government vigorously denies that there was _ it would not entitle'' Barry ``to any relief unless'' his constitutional rights were violated, they said. Disclosing the guidelines ``could compromise ongoing and future undercover operations,'' they wrote.
DOC.HEAD: Private Companies Make Corn Sale To Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 600,000 metric tons of U.S. corn for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department says. Orders since Oct. 1, the beginning of the agreement's new year, now total about 13.9 million tons of corn, 3.3 million tons of wheat, 342,300 tons of soybeans and 1.2 million tons of soybean meal, the department said Friday. In addition, sales of barley total 7,300 tons. The current long-term agreement expires on Dec. 31. A five-year pact to replace it has been tentatively approved by U.S. and Soviet negotiators. Meanwhile, the latest sales raised the total for 1989-90 delivery to almost 17.2 million tons, the announcement said. In 1988-89, sales were a record of more than 21.7 million tons, including more than 16.3 million tons of corn and nearly 5.4 million tons of wheat. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 39.4 bushels of corn or 36.7 bushels of wheat or soybeans. The 600,000 tons of corn would be about 23.6 million bushels. The new sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department.

DOC.HEAD: East German Government Divided Over Unification
With PM-Germany-Allies, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A rift has developed in East Germany's first non-Communist government, with a major partner in the fragile coalition accusing leaders of letting West Germany dictate the terms for reunification. ``In the East Berlin Cabinet stands a crack in the house, because we up to now cannot be held responsible for the outcome of the (unification) state treaty,'' Richard Schroeder, head of the Social Democrat faction in Parliament, said Friday. ``I am worried about a break in the axle on the way to unity,'' he said. Experts from both Germanys met in East Berlin on Friday for ongoing talks on shifting East Germany away from a socialist economy as quickly as possible. The left-leaning Social Democrats hold important Cabinet posts in the government of Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. But they have begun distancing themselves from agreements on merging the two economies. Their latest criticism could put the shaky coalition government in jeopardy. Although the Social Democrats agreed to join the government of de Maiziere, who leads the conservative Christian Democrats, they complained Friday that the terms of the economic union would create hardships for East Germans. Social Minister Regine Hildebrandt, a Social Democrat, criticized the decision between the governments to tailor East Germany's pension program to West Germany's. She said it would reduce benefits for East Germans. The economies and social institutions of the two nations are to merge on July 2 as a prelude to full unification next year. But Social Democrats have become increasingly critical of what they say is a willingness to accept Bonn's terms and the lack of guarantees to protect East Germans who will give up enormous social subsidies. De Maiziere, whose party finished first in the March 18 elections, formed a coalition with the Social Democrats to have the two-third Parliament majority needed to make constitutional changes that would make unification possible. On Sunday, East Germans will vote in local elections. They are expected to remove the last traces of Communist control and put the finishing touches on the social revolution that began a year ago. The balloting will turn over to local hands the obedient bureaucracies that were carefully controlled by the former hard-line leadership. The balloting also may provide a gauge of the current mood toward German unification, a process that is speeding toward completion. Talks among the two Germanys and four World War II Allies were being held today in Bonn, West Germany. More than 12 million voters in 7,800 cities, districts and other municipalities are eligible to vote in the elections. Sixty-two parties and more than a quarter-million candidates are registered to run. The elections come against a backdrop of widespread protests in recent weeks by East German workers afraid that their factories will close when forced to compete with Western commerce. However, West Germany says a quick move to a free market will create jobs, raise living standards and eventually eliminate the economic hardships of the early stages of unification. The two governments agreed on the general terms of an economic union on Wednesday. It would exchange salaries, wages and small savings accounts of East Germans for an equal amount of West German marks. Wolfgang Tierse, deputy chief of the Social Democrats faction, said his party would not endorse the economic and social treaty that is being negotiated as a basis for unification. He said it would bring ``massive poverty.''

DOC.HEAD: White Officers Sentenced in Inmate's Beating Death
DOC.TEXT: An all-white jury sentenced a former police chief and two former deputies, all three white, to prison terms of 10 to 28 years for beating to death a black prisoner in 1987. Activists, who had been monitoring the trial, proclaimed the verdict Friday a victory for racial justice. ``I think justice has been served, and it certainly is a compliment to the criminal justice system that it worked,'' said Pearlie Henderson, a local civil rights activist. ``If a person wears a law badge, he's not beyond the law himself.'' The jury sentenced former Hemphill Police Chief Thomas Ladner to 28 years for the murder of Loyal Garner Jr. Former Sabine County sheriff's deputy Billy Ray Horton and former deputy James M. Hyden drew sentences of 10 and 14 years, respectively. Garner, a 34-year-old father of six from Florien, La., died Dec. 27, 1987, of severe head injuries he suffered at the county jail after his Christmas Day arrest on drunken driving charges. He had no criminal record. Horton and Hyden were allowed to remain free on bonds of $25,000 because their sentences were less than 15 years in prison. Ladner was taken into custody. The 12-member jury had convicted the three men of murder on Thursday. Corrine Garner, widow of the victim, said: ``I'm glad. I'm happy that they were convicted and they got time. .. They should have gotten life.'' Garner's father said he wanted longer sentences, but was satisfied the three men would pay for his son's death. ``He's been missed, you know. I was so used to him,'' he said. The three former lawmen were acquitted of civil rights charges in Garner's death in 1988, and their lawyers plan to appeal on grounds the murder trial constituted double jeopardy. The NAACP began monitoring the trial in Tyler, about 100 miles east of Dallas, after jury selection resulted in another all-white jury. Black leaders said they hadn't expected guilty verdicts. ``It's a great feeling,'' said Vollie Grace, president of the Hemphill chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``It restored my faith in the system.'' Some in the courtroom wept Friday as Prosecutor Jack Skeen asked for life sentences. ``Establish by your verdict the real meaning of Smith County justice,'' Skeen told the jury. ``This is Loyal Garner Jr.'s last chance.'' Ladner's attorney, John Seale, compared Skeen's efforts to those of a lynch mob. ``On one occasion, these men got mad, lost their temper and overreacted,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawks Bury One Of Two Indians Slain In Gambling War
LaserPhoto XMAS101A
DOC.TEXT: Authorities closed off this violence-torn reservation again after allowing outsiders to attend the funeral of a Mohawk Indian killed in a violent feud over casino gambling. The reservation, which straddles the border with Canada in northern New York, was opened Friday to journalists and outsiders as the Mohawks buried Matthew Pyke, the first of two Indians slain in the conflict. But state police sealed off all roads shortly before nightfall. New York and Canadian police have been stationed here since Tuesday to keep the peace. ``Things are still touchy,'' state trooper Ronald Clark said. ``We want to try to keep things stable here to allow the negotiations to begin.'' A specially assembled mediation team dispatched by the U.S. Justice Department was arriving today to buttress the efforts of one federal mediator already on the scene, said Grace Flores Hughes, director of the department's Community Relations Service in Washington. In Ottawa, Canadian Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon said the Canadian and U.S. governments would help Mohawk leaders find a lasting solution to peace. ``We have to keep in mind that governments must not impose solutions that are not welcome,'' he said. ``So there's no magic formula for governments to pull out of a bag somewhere and say here's the answer to your problems.'' Siddon said a liaison committee will now look at longer-term solutions, including economic alternatives to gambling. But first, he said, a dialogue had to be restored between all parties on the reservation. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said he would press for creation of an independent Mohawk police force on the reservation. Outsiders have been barred from entering the 28,000-acre reservation since the 22-year-old Pyke and Harold Edwards Jr., 32, were shot to death during a protracted gun battle early Tuesday. Pyke was a gambling opponent; Edwards was on the pro-gambling side. The reservation, home to about 9,000 Mohawks, has been torn by sporadic violence since last July, when the FBI and state police raided casinos on the American side. Gambling opponents say the casinos breed crime; supporters say they are an economic boon for the reservation. The warring factions laid aside their differences Friday to honor Pyke, who was buried at a cemetery a few blocks from his family's home. Forty Mohawks wearing clan beads, embroidered shirts and other traditional Indian dress led a funeral procession of about 500 people before the service at St. Regis Catholic Church. A woman in the front row carried a framed picture of Pyke, while mourners at the rear sang ``Give Peace a Chance,'' the anti-war song by the late John Lennon. ``We're putting aside our anger for the day,'' said Eddie Gray. ``It's a day for mourning.'' Members of the Warrior Society were not invited, but they observed two hours of silence in Pyke's honor. ``It's our traditional belief that we have total respect for the dead,'' Minnie Garrow said. Edwards was to be buried Monday after a service at the same church.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Fellow Americans, because of all of you I'm alive.'' _ Freed hostage Frank Reed on his arrival to Andrews Air Force Base, Md.

``Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have insured peace in Europe.'' _ President Bush in the first of a series of commencement speeches he will make on the changing geopolitical face of the world.
``This is only the very, very beginning.'' _ President Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia after the vote declaring the republic independent of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Figure in Iran-Contra Affair Found Innocent of False Declaration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Brenneke's trial...' to show that trial had begun when Brenneke hospitalized; picks up 8th graf, `Prosecutors described...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PD6 of May 4
DOC.TEXT: A self-avowed CIA contract agent was found innocent of lying about an alleged meeting at which officials in the Reagan-Bush campaign asked Iran to delay the release of U.S. hostages until after the 1980 election. Richard J. Brenneke, a controversial figure who also has been at the center of Iran-Contra investigations, was found innocent of five counts of false declaration for statements made before a federal judge in Denver in 1988. At the time, Brenneke was appearing as a character witness for Denver gold dealer Heinrich Rupp, whom Brenneke said he met in 1957 when they worked together in Southeast Asia for a CIA proprietary, Air America. Rupp was convicted of bank fraud and is serving a 41-year prison term. Brenneke told the Denver court that he and Rupp in October 1980 helped arrange clandestine meetings involving the hostage crisis, and that Rupp flew George Bush, then a candidate for vice president, to Paris for the meetings. Brenneke told of three hostage meetings at two Paris hotels. But he testified Thursday that he did not actually see Bush in Paris. Brenneke's trial originally was to have been held in Denver but was moved to Portland, near Brenneke's home, after he had open heart surgery. The trial started April 24 but was interrupted when Brenneke was hospitalized with chest pains. Prosecutors described Brenneke as a rejected CIA applicant who operated on the fringes, trying to become a broker of arms and intelligence and lying about his exploits. But the 12-member jury, after deliberating for five hours, said it believed Brenneke's story. Defense lawyer Michael Scott said the verdict did not mean that witnesses in the case such as Donald P. Gregg, the U.S. ambassador to South Korea, had lied. Nor does it mean that Bush was in Paris for the alleged meetings, Scott said. The verdict ``means that the jury did not find my client guilty,'' Scott said. Outside the courtroom, a smiling Brenneke said, ``We told the truth, we told the truth all along and, by God, it was believed.'' In Washington, D.C., Stephen Hart, deputy White House press secretary, declined any comment on the case. Brenneke has claimed in numerous media interviews to have detailed knowledge about aspects of the Iran-Contra arms scandal. In 1988, he testified at hearings organized by Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., that he had flown drugs from Colombia to Texas in 1985 as part of a supply operation for the Contras. He said that Gregg, then Bush's national security adviser, knew of the flights. Brenneke also claimed to have bought arms for the Contras in Czechoslovakia. Then-Vice President Bush called Benneke's claims ``slanderous.'' In April 1989, Kerry's narcotics and international relations subcommittee declared Brenneke an unreliable witness. Brenneke, in his mid-40s, has run an offshore investment fund, worked as a computer programmer, and as a dealer in the international arms market. The CIA denies he ever worked for the agency. In his closing arguments Friday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Thomas M. O'Rourke dismissed as a fabrication Brenneke's description of the secret Paris meeting and its purpose: to sabotage President Carter's re-election campaign by delaying the hostage release. Brenneke said the meetings were attended by the late CIA director William Casey, then chairman of the Reagan campaign, and Gregg, then a CIA agent assigned to Carter's National Security Council staff. Gregg testified last week that he was not in Paris when Brenneke said the talks took place. He produced snapshots from a family vacation at the Delaware seashore. On Wednesday, a local meteorologist testified that he had consulted 1980 weather maps and found Gregg's photographs could not have been taken when he said they were shot. Former National Security Adviser Richard V. Allen, who testified as a defense witness, said the 1980 campaign was concerned about an ``October surprise'' from Carter that would tilt the campaign away from Reagan. Allen said the campaign had learned from an inside source, who was later identified to him as Secretary of State Edmund Muskie, that Carter was close to getting the hostages released that October. Allen said he did not attend any meeting in Paris. The 52 American hostages, seized Nov. 4, 1979 at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, were released Jan. 20, 1981, the day President Reagan was sworn in.

DOC.HEAD: President Beset by Sagging Polls, Harsh New Biography
DOC.TEXT: Francois Mitterrand begins his 10th year as France's president next week with his popularity plummeting and his political integrity under harsh attack in a new best-selling biography. Some political analysts predict Mitterrand's problems will worsen in the coming months. Others suggest the Socialist president will bounce back as he has many times in an up-and-down, 45-year political career. Recent public opinion polls show a dramatic drop in popularity for the 73-year-old president. A Sofres survey recorded a 12-point fall from 61 to 53 percent in a single month, while a poll by the Journal du Dimanche newspaper found only 39 percent of respondents satisfied with Mitterrand's performance. ``Don't ever forget: Francois Mitterrand is an artist of resurrection,'' says Franz-Olivier Geisbert, author of the new unflattering biography. ``In 1980 he was finished. In 1981 he was elected president of the Republic.'' Geisbert, 41, a prominent journalist who has worked for both leftist and conservative publications, has been following Mitterrand's career for many years. His second book on Mitterrand, ``The President,'' is filled with revealing anecdotes and interviews and conversations with presidential advisors, ministers, opposition leaders, reporters, and Mitterrand himself. Currently on the best-seller list, it strips away Mitterrand's image as a lofty, high-principled statesman and depicts him instead as a ruthless scheming politician who ``squeezed aside principle and ideology'' to carve out his place in history. ``The whole Mitterrand is there, in this mix of electoral cynicism and artistic haze. He does not let himself be burdened by scruples when power is at stake,'' he wrote. The book is a devastating behind-the-scenes look at how Mitterrand exercises presidential power by manipulating political allies and enemies. It chronicles his intense dislike of his longtime Socialist rival, Michel Rocard, whom he relegated to minor Cabinet posts until attrition among his stalwarts forced him to name Rocard as prime minister after Mitterrand's reelection in 1988 to a second seven-year term. The book also describes how Mitterrand cleverly engineered a leftist coalition to beat Valery Giscard d'Estaing in 1981. The maneuver was doubly useful to Mitterrand. It led, ultimately, to the decline of the Communist Party and fueled the rise of the extreme-right National Front party, which has discredited and divided conservative political factions ever since. Mitterrand's troubles have been making headlines for weeks. Political analysts attribute them to several events, including the amnesty of a former Socialist minister involved in a political fund-raising scandal. After the Socialist Party congress in April turned into a mean dogfight among contenders to the presidency (not vacant until 1995), Mitterrand descended into the arena and gave a rare television interview trying to explain the mess. His efforts appeared to make matters worse. Analysts say Mitterrand's drop in popularity can be explained by his loss of favor among voters with political sympathies on the right. Many of these voters backed Mitterrand in 1988, viewing him a reassuring father figure comparable to Charles de Gaulle, who would work for the broad national interest. ``The key to his reelection was his ability to preserve influence beyond the political and sociological boundaries of the left,'' noted Eric Dupin in Liberation. This loss of right-leaning voters has not been countered by an increase of support from the left, such as young people and blue-collar workers. ``Mitterrand is looking for the choke to get going again,'' headlined Liberation, a leftist daily. ``The Elysee (palace) seems to have run out of inspiration, and enthusiasm.''

DOC.HEAD: Mary Ann Vecchio Just Wants to Forget Kent State
LaserPhoto CDX1
DOC.TEXT: A long-awaited memorial symbolizes the desire to record what happened at Kent State University 20 years ago, but the woman whose photographic image became an enduring symbol of that era would rather forget. The photograph portrayed an anguished Mary Ann Veccio, then 14, kneeling beside the lifeless body of one of four students slain by the National Guard on May 4, 1970. The photograph won a Pulitzer Prize for John Filo, a student photographer now deputy picture editor at Sports Illustrated magazine. It has become a classic recording of the violent shock of the Vietnam War and its repercussions at home. But the photograph hounded Vecchio into seeking seclusion. ``It really destroyed my life and I don't want to talk about it,'' the 34-year-old casino worker in Las Vegas told The Orlando Sentinel this week. She wasn't interested in discussing the memorial dedicated Friday on the Kent State campus to the four slain and nine injured students in the anti-war demonstration. ``Big deal. It has nothing to do with my life,'' Vecchio said. Her image can't be shaken loose from memories of that sunny afternoon: Her arms raised, her faced in a grimace, kneeling over the bleeding body of Jeffrey Miller, who had been shot in the mouth after lobbing a tear-gas canister back at the approaching Guard. Students were protesting President Nixon's bombing of Cambodia and the continuation of the Vietnam War. Vecchio was a runaway from the Miami area at the time, and she believes her later run-ins with the law were due to what the photo came to symbolize. Then-Florida Gov. Claude Kirk ``said she was planted there by the communists, and people wrote letters that she was responsible for murdering all those children,'' Vecchio's mother, 63-year-old Claire, said from the house in Opa-locka, Fla., where she raised Mary Ann and five other children. ``Can you imagine a 14-year-old girl having to deal with that?'' Vecchio's father, Frank, a maintenance worker for the Dade County Port Authority before he died, recognized his daughter's face in the photo. He traced her to Indianapolis and had her returned home. Later Vecchio was sent to a juvenile home, and she was arrested for petty crimes such as loitering and marijuana possession. The press hounded her, she said. ``I've been miserable since Kent State,'' she said five years after the shootings. ``Not for any political reasons, but after all the publicity I've received, I feel the police have been unnecessarily harassing me.'' Vecchio soon tired of the annual remembrances and refused to take part. She married a plumber from Kentucky in Las Vegas 11 years ago and they live in a quiet, elm-shaded mobile-home park filled with retirees. Vecchio returned to school for her high school diploma and has worked her way to a management position at a casino, supervising an army of cashiers. Others whose lives were tied to the Kent State killings hoped to ease their pain at the memorial dedication Friday. ``We hope to promote an atmosphere of reconciliation,'' said Florence Schroeder, whose son, Bill, was another of the students killed, told about 4,000 people gathered for an hour-long ceremony. Former U.S. Sen. George McGovern said the $200,000 memorial should encourage reconciliation between the United States and Vietnam, which do not have diplomatic relations. ``The war in Vietnam is unfinished,'' said McGovern, the Democratic presidential candidate in 1972. ``The killing has stopped, but the arrogance that produced it survives, and so does the agony, the guilt and the separation.'' The memorial, on 2{ acres adjacent to the parking lot where the students were killed, includes a granite plaza with four pylons similar in shape to elongated gravestones. A smaller, waist-high marker, was erected in honor of the slain students in 1971. Although she and her husband, Louis, participated in the ceremony, the families of Miller and Allison Krause did not show up, university spokeswoman Janet Thiede said. Ms. Krause's mother, Doris Krause of Monroeville, Pa., had said she did not plan to attend because she believed the memorial should have been bigger and built earlier. The parents of the fourth victim, Sandra Scheuer, were on campus but did not speak at the ceremonies.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Hikes Compensation to Some Salmon Fishermen
DOC.TEXT: Exxon said it is paying a total of $62 million to compensate Kodiak and Chignik fishermen for 1989 salmon losses from the Exxon Valdez oil spill, but angry fishermen say it's not enough. The company said Friday it had paid about $50 million to Kodiak fishermen and $4 million to Chignik fishermen so far, and would pay an additional $8 million to the two groups because last year's neglected salmon run was bigger than anticipated. Most fishing was prohibited last year because of fears the oil could enter the food chain through the fish. The spill's long-term effect on salmon fishing isn't yet known. ``We're not only living by our commitment that we made early on to compensate them for everything they expected to get, but we're paying them for an even greater volume of fish,'' said Exxon claim manager Dave Shoup. The fishermen, however, said they expected more than twice as much in additional compensation, and accused Exxon of ``breaking faith.'' ``They're about $10.8 million short'' of Kodiak fishermen's claims, said Jeff Stephan, president of United Fishermen's Marketing Association in Kodiak. ``They've told us all along in a public relations campaign that they expect to make the fishermen whole. They've said that to me 100 times in negotiations. And we believed them,'' he said. ``Well, we're sitting here in May and the fishermen are nowhere near whole.'' The major point of contention is whether fishermen should be compensated for more than $6 million in salmon harvested at the state-owned Kitoi Hatchery by the hatchery's operator. Fishermen say they suffered by not being the ones to harvest those fish and so should be compensated for them by the oil company. Exxon says it won't compensate the fishermen for fish that were harvested _ only for those that weren't. Exxon's voluntary compensation program doesn't officially settle fishermen's claims, many of which are in lawsuits filed in state and federal court. The lawsuits include claims of lost opportunities, mental anguish and and other damages. Kodiak Island is about 250 miles southwest of Bligh Reef in Prince William Sound, where the Exxon Valdez ran aground in March 24, 1989, spilling nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil. The village of Chignik, on the Alaska Peninsula, lies across the Shelikof Strait from Kodiak. Negotiations will continue with the fishermen over the company's voluntary claims program as well, Shoup said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Spiritual Leader Wants Israel Pressured To Free Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: The spiritual mentor of Moslem militants holding Western hostages says no more of the captives should be freed unless Israel releases Arab prisoners, a newspaper reported today. ``We want the states of the world to pressure Israel into releasing Arab prisoners the same way they exert pressure for the release of Western hostages,'' al-Anwar quoted Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah as telling a Friday prayer sermon. Americans Frank Reed and Robert Polhill have been released by their Lebanese captors in the past two weeks. Most of the remaining 16 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including six Americans, are believed to be held by Iranian-backed Shiite Moslem groups in Beirut's southern shantytowns, a stronghold of the fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God. Fadlallah, Hezbollah's ``spiritual guide,'' declared: ``We don't want the human rights and freedom of anyone to be achieved at our expense,'' in apparent rejection of the release of Western captives without a reciprocal move by Israel. ``Either (our people) will be free or we will not respect the freedom of the world that does not respect our freedom,'' he added. The conservative al-Anwar carried the full text of Fadlallah's address. The missing Westerners comprise six Americans, four Britons, two Swiss, two West Germans, an Italian and an Irishman. American Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held captive. He was kidnapped in Moslem west Beirut March 16, 1985. Hezbollah issued a statement Friday blaming the United States for hindering the release of Western captives. ``The U.S. administration bears the responsibility for any complications in this issue,'' it said. ``The ball is now in America's court after the efforts that had been exerted by the Islamic republic and Syria to free two Americans as a step toward resolving the question of all the hostages,'' the statement said. Polhill, 55, was freed April 22 after 39 months in captivity. Reed, 57, was released eight days later after 42 months as a hostage. Iran and Syria have called for a reciprocal goodwill gesture from the United States. Iranian newspapers and some of the Shiite kidnap groups have demanded that as a precondition for further hostage releases, Israel frees some 400 Palestinian and Lebanese prisoners it holds. The hostage-holders also have demanded freedom for 15 convicted militants imprisoned in Kuwait for the bombing of the U.S. and French embassies there in December 1983. Israel and Kuwait have refused to negotiate with terrorists and the United States has said it would not pressure them into bowing to the kidnappers' demands.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Crews Hope Canal Will Halt Fire's Progress
DOC.TEXT: Scattered showers helped firefighters bring under control a four-day-old blaze that charred an estimated 25,000 acres of the Everglades as it closed in on a federal wildlife preserve. Firefighters counted on the L-67 canal as the last line of defense between the wall of flames and 150,000 drought-crisp wetlands to the west. Officials are concerned the fire could jump the 100-foot-wide canal and move into the sprawling Big Cypress National Wildlife Preserve. Friday evening, firefighters reported they had controlled the blaze and would continue monitoring for possible flare-ups. ``With that rain, it slowed it down a little bit, brought the humidity up,'' said John Kern of the state Division of Forestry. The fire apparently was sparked accidentally in an area frequented by people on motorcycles and all-terrain vehicles, said senior state forester Gene Dempsey. Despite the size of the scorched area, about 25 miles west of downtown Miami, wildlife officials say there has been little affect on animals because the severe drought already had forced most species to water. ``We have a few snakes and rodents scurrying away, but that's about it,'' said senior state forester Gene Dempsey. David Maehr, a Florida panther biologist with the state Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission, said the 17 cats wearing the agency's radio-tracking collars were checked Friday and were ``nowhere near any danger from fire.'' About 30 to 50 panthers are believed to roam the wilds of South Florida, making them one of the world's rarest mammals. No inhabited areas were threatened by the blaze, one of three west of Miami. Another fire in Everglades National Park, about 27 miles southwest of the city, scorched 10,500 acres by Friday. Firefighters expected to control it today, said park spokeswoman Darlene Koontz. Another fire, on the Seminole reservation in Broward County, was contained after burning 800 acres, Dempsery said.

DOC.HEAD: Chimney Collapse In China Kills 24
DOC.TEXT: A tall factory chimney collapsed in southern China, killing 24 construction workers, a newspaper reported. Friday's Yangcheng Evening News, seen in Beijing today, said the 130-foot chimney was at a brick factory in Canton's Kaiping county. The paper said the structure toppled because of an unstable foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Government Rules Getty Museum Cannot Export Sculpture
DOC.TEXT: The J. Paul Getty Museum was denied an export license for a $12 million sculpture after the government announced new guidelines for exporting art treasures. The Department of Trade and Industry announced Friday that works of art considered important to Britain's heritage cannot be exported if a British buyer can be found. The Malibu, Calif.-based Getty Museum applied to export the ``Three Graces'' from Britain in March 1989 after its $12.4 million bid was accepted by the sculpture's owners, a trust in Britain's Caribbean Cayman Islands colony.
