The export license was deferred while the government sought a public owner for the 19th-century statue of three standing nude women. The National Galleries of Scotland said Friday it is interested and pledged $1.64 million toward the cost. The sculptor, Canova, was a leading artist of the neoclassical movement and worked for the Vatican and European aristocracy. He died in 1922.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor: Soccer Player Contracts AIDS After Collision
DOC.TEXT: A doctor says an Italian man contracted the AIDS virus after colliding with an infected drug abuser during a soccer game near this northern town. The incident was first reported in a letter published in the latest issue of The Lancet, a respected British medical journal. Five doctors from the Varese Regional Hospital's infectious diseases unit signed the letter. Dr. Donato Torre, one of the five, said Friday other cases of transmission of the AIDS virus from sporting accidents have been documented in the United States and Britain. The doctors said the incident occurred when two players crashed into each other during an informal soccer game in December near Varese, near the Swiss border. The virus was apparently transmitted from deep cuts to their eyebrows and foreheads. The letter said that two months after the accident, during a routine blood test, the previously uninfected man's blood serum was found to carry the HIV-1 virus, which causes AIDS. A year before the injury, another routine blood test had shown he was uninfected. In the telephone interview, Torre said the other man involved was a member of a soccer team made up of players from a drug rehabilitation center. ``In the absence of other risk factors, this case is compatible with the acquisition of HIV-1 infection by traumatic contact with a seropositive man,'' the letter said. AIDS is a deadly affliction in which a virus attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a wide variety of infections and cancers. It is spread mainly by sexual contact, the use of contaminated needles among drug abusers, and transfusion of tainted blood. The doctors who signed the letter said the patient who contracted the AIDS virus after the collision denied drug abuse; he had not had blood transfusions, injections or dental care; and he had not been to such high-risk areas as Africa or the Caribbean. He has been in a stable relationship for four years with a woman who was uninfected and he did not have sex with other women, the letter said. The men were not identified for reasons of privacy. In the telephone interview, Torre said new standard procedures were needed to handle such accidents. ``It's logical that when accident victims suffer lesions with bleeding and they come into contact with another accident victim, such as in a car accident, they should be tested immediately for the HIV virus,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Strikes Southern Italy, At Least 2 Injured
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake rocked southern Italy this morning, causing damage and injuring at least two people. The quake measured 4.8 on the Richter scale, according to the National Institute of Geophysics in Rome. The temblor at 9:30 a.m. (2:30 a.m. EDT) and subsequent aftershocks sent frightened residents running into the streets. Southern Italy has been struck by devastating temblors in the past, including one in 1980 that killed about 3,000 people in the Naples region. The epicenter was about 95 miles southeast of Naples. However, the temblor was felt as far south as the regions of Calabria and Puglia, the toe and heel of the Italian ``boot.'' Two people were injured in Potenza, about 80 miles southeast of Naples, when chunks of molding fell from the walls inside their homes. Damage to older buildings was reported, but the extent was not immeditely clear. The national telephone company, SIP, reported lines were tied up by calls to fire departments and other authorities. It issued a statement asking people to limit their calls to emergency cases. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number means that the ground motion is 10 times greater. A quake of magnitude 4 can cause moderate damage in populated areas, while one measuring 5 can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Rain and Floods in the East; Fair Skies in West
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms moved out of the South and brought rain early today to the East, and fair skies over the West promised hot weather. A flood watch was posted until 4 a.m. in western Pennsylvania and the West Virginia panhandle. Scattered showers were expected today over the northern Plains. Temperatures were expected to soar into the 90s in central California, Nevada and the desert Southwest. Phoenix had 82 degrees and Las Vegas was 76 shortly after midnight. Flooding or high winds closed roads, downed power lines and chased people from their homes in Texas, Oklahoma, Ohio and Arkansas on Friday. In Virginia, crews in Augusta County worked early today to restore power after a severe storm killed two people, blew apart buildings, uprooted trees and tore down power lines. Strong thunderstorms developed in warm and humid air in the Carolinas on Friday and moved northward today along a cold front. Thunderstorms early today were over Washington, D.C., Philadelphia and New York City. Rain was falling from upstate New York across the New England coastline to Portland, Maine. On Friday, showers and thunderstorms developed over the eastern seaboard and extended from northern Alabama to the upper Ohio Valley, where heavy rains fell in parts. Erie, Pa., was drenched with nearly 1 inch of rain in two hours. The thunderstorms produced golf-ball size hail at Ware Shoals, S.C. and near Zebulun, N.C. A thunderstorm with high winds over southern Indiana downed numerous trees at Paradise and damaged at least four homes. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered across much of the Gulf Coast to Virginia. Light rain and drizzle extended from eastern Iowa through lower Michigan and the lower Great Lakes region to New Jersey and southern New England. Scattered light rainshowers extended from New Mexico to the northern high plains region. Fair skies prevailed west of the Rockies. Friday's high for the Lower 48 was 104 degrees at Borrego Springs, Ca. DOC.HEAD: Colombia, Fearing Drug Violence, Helps Candidates Cut Appearances
DOC.TEXT: Fearing more deadly attacks on candidates, the government is buying radio and TV ads for presidential hopefuls to cut down on risky public appearances. Three presidential candidates have been killed since August, when drug traffickers launched a war against the government that has left nearly 300 people dead. The traffickers are blamed for at least two of the assassinations. In the drug capital of Medellin on Friday, police killed six unidentified men during a shootout at a shopping center. The decree by President Virgilio Barco earmarked $340,000 to allow all 13 contenders for May 27 elections to buy air time. The Thursday order increased free time on government-owned television for candidates' speeches. It also said voters will decide whether the country's constitution should be reformed. There is widespread support for proposals intended to strengthen the judicial system and reduce the drug cartels' influence in the congress. ``The urgent strengthening of institutions is necessary for a return to normality and to overcome a situation in which public security is constantly disturbed,'' said the presidential decree. The proposal would need the support of 51 percent of the voters. Despite the government help in campaign advertising, presidential candidate Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party traveled Friday to the eastern city of Bucaramanga. His campaign said he would make a series of appearances in public plazas. Gaviria had suspended his campaign activities after the April 26 assassination of Carlos Pizarro, a leftist presidential contender and former guerrilla leader. An assassin shot and killed Pizarro, the candidate for the April 19 Movement, aboard a Colombian jetliner. In previous months of the campaign, candidates Sen. Luis Carlos Galan of the Liberal Party and Bernardo Jaramillo of the Patriotic Union were assassinated. The slaying of Galan in August set off a U.S.-backed government crackdown on the traffickers. Authorities say they believe the assassins of Galan and Jaramillo were working for drug traffickers. The media, citing security sources, have reported drug traffickers were the main suspects in Pizarro's killing. But the Medellin cartel denied involvement and no government official has yet said who was responsible. Also Friday, a government official blamed druglords for a car-bomb attack that killed four people, including a 3-year-old girl, in the southern city of Cali on Thursday night. The Cali car bomb, which carried 220 pounds of dynamite, wounded 36 people and destroyed several buildings when it exploded in front of a drugstore in the city's commercial district. ``This was a demented attack carried out by persons tied to the Medellin cartel,'' Raul Caicedo, the secretary of Cali's municipal government, told the RCN radio network on Friday. The drugstore was one of a chain belonging to Gilberto Rodriguez, the reputed leader of the Cali cocaine cartel. Authorities blamed the Medellin cartel for several bombings of drugstores in the chain in 1988 and 1989. During that time, the two cartels fought a war for control of the New York City cocaine market.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Rebels Agree to Begin Disarming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to CORRECT that Mrs. Chamorro was referring to immediate reduction in Sandinista army, sted Contras; UPDATES with information about that reduction; ADDS quotes, byline; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan rebels today agreed with the new government to begin disarming next week, and the President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pledged to start reducing the size of the Sandinista-controlled army. If carried out, the agreement will mean an end to a decade-old civil war between thousands of U.S.-backed Contra rebels and the previous leftist Sandinista government. An estimated 30,000 people have died in the fighting. Mrs. Chamorro also said weapons given to civilian Sandinista supporters by the outgoing administration should be ``recovered and destroyed.'' Israel Galeano, the Contra commander, agreed his forces would begin disarming Tuesday. The accord, which was reached after a 15-hour meeting that ended at 1 a.m. today, said the rebel fighters would be disarmed by June 10. The accord said the security of the rebels and their families camped with them would be guaranteed. The bulk of the rebel army, estimated at between 9,000 and 12,000 fighters, has returned to Nicaragua from Honduran base camps in the past few months. Many are in security zones supervised by U.N. peacekeepeers. The rebels had previously agreed to surrender their weapons by June 10 but then stalled, saying they wanted the army to be disbanded first. The army is controlled by the Sandinista Front, which lost national elections to Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-backed opposition coalition in February. Mrs. Chamorro, who is also acting as defense minister, did not specify by how much the army would be reduced but promised to do so by the date of the Contra demobilization. ``On June 10, we will announce the program of the reduction of the armed forces ordered in (my) inaugural address of April 25th, and whose implementation should begin immediately,'' Mrs. Chamorro said. Her government has also forced top officers to leave the party in a move intended to depoliticize the army. Today's announcements followed closed-door talks that began Friday. Members of Mrs. Chamorro's Cabinet and Nicaragua's Roman Catholic cardinal, Miguel Obando y Bravo, also attended. Galeano said Friday the fact that the Contras were meeting with Mrs. Chamorro shows a willingness to work to rebuild ``a society that is destroyed.'' Many Contras are angry over Mrs. Chamorro's decision to keep Gen. Humberto Ortega as head of the army, although she said the post would be temporary. Ortega, brother of former President Daniel Ortega, had been defense minister under the Sandinistas. When Mrs. Chamorro took office April 25, she charged Gen. Ortega with coming up with a program for reducing the armed forces in keeping with Contra demands. However, she said Ortega would stay on as head of the army until the Contras were disarmed.

DOC.HEAD: Gay Rights Activists Blast Claim of Homosexual `Cure'
LaserPhoto SK3
DOC.TEXT: Gay rights activists have demanded scientific proof from a foundation promoting therapy and sports as ``cures'' for homosexuality. Robert Austin, president of the Utah AIDS Coalition, condemned the notion that sexual orientation can be changed. ``Reorientation therapy is to psychiatry what bloodletting is to the healing arts,'' he said. Austin commented Friday as 120 social workers and therapists gathered for the opening of a two-day conference sponsored by the Evergreen Foundation, a self-described group of former homosexuals dedicated to helping others abandon gay lifestyles. The foundation touts development of athletic skills to spur the transition to heterosexuality, but conference organizers conceded they have no studies to back up their views. Instead, they cited anecdotal cases and testimonials from ex-homosexuals that homosexuality can be cured. Jeff Konrad said he was able to change his homosexual orientation by playing sports and relating to men in a non-sexual way through a support group. ``I was an isolated, shy person and I didn't play baseball,'' he said. ``A lot of gay men aren't good at sports. I didn't have enough self-confidence to go after that ball and when the ball came, I wasn't aggressive. All I needed was love, pushing and a masculine role model.'' Joe Dallas of Orange, Calif., a fundamentalist Christian therapist, told conference goers that while not technically an illness, homosexuality is a ``symptom of inner conflict'' often stemming from a childhood devoid of proper male identity development. He said he has helped 70 people achieve significant sexual reorientation or modified behavior during the last three years. ``I need more time, perhaps five to nine years, to do a follow-up study that would be more credible,'' Dallas said. ``But none of my clients have renounced our efforts.'' Austin said the majority of mental health professionals agree that sexual orientation cannot be changed. He predicted that the foundation's year-old treatment program would ``fall on the ash heap of history,'' joining the notion that homosexuality is a mental disease _ an idea rejected by the American Psychiatric Association in 1973. ``It will not fall without its victims,'' Austin said. ``Gay and lesbian teens, haunted by confusion over their affectation, attempt suicide three times as often as their heterosexual counterparts. ``I find the very idea of professionals in the mental health professions adding to that despair and confusion by offering false hopes of reorientation to be unconscionable,'' he said. Evergreen President Alan Seegmiller said his organization reflects Christian values, which can sometimes be the force that prompts homosexuals to seek change. He said 40 to 50 members of the foundation are members of the Mormon Church, which condemns homosexuality as a serious sin. ``We respect gays who are happy with their lifestyle, but we do believe that the most complete, actualized person will be heterosexual,'' he said. ``I see homosexuality as just the red light on the dash that says check under the hood, something's the matter here.'' Austin was joined at a news conference by a minister, a social worker and several Mormon homosexuals who recounted painful memories of various treatments that failed. Mark Hansen said one Mormon counselor had him hang a poster of a woman in a string bikini above his bed to change sexual orientation, while another therapist said to remove the poster because ``it was wrong to replace one perversion with another perversion.'' Still another counselor had Hansen place a pinto bean in his shoe. He said each time he felt the bean, ``I was told to say to myself, `I am completely heterosexual.''' The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, while making occasional referrals to the program, is not affiliated with the foundation, said spokesman Don LeFevre. ``LDS Social Services professionals view the foundation as a support group, or resource,'' he said. In the late 1960s, church-owned Brigham Young University offered homosexual students aversion therapy, including electroshock treatments, but abandoned the experiment ``when it was determined to be ineffective,'' LeFevre said. Now, the church offers individual and group therapy for ``both those with homosexual orientation and for family members who seek it. ... It is a spiritually based therapy.''

DOC.HEAD: Coca Crop Reduced In Govt Program
DOC.TEXT: A program that pays farmers to destroy their coca plants has eliminated more than one-tenth of the country's acreage this year of the main ingredient in cocaine, U.S. officials say. In April, coca leaf farmers destroyed 2,700 acres of plants, bringing the total since Dec. 1 to 9,800 acres, the U.S. Embassy said Friday. That represents over one-tenth of the 94,000 acres devoted to coca cultivation, it said. Farmers receive $2,000 from the Bolivian government for every 2{ acres destroyed. But the government says it is having trouble making the payments because of a faltering economy. Treasury officials indicate the funding of educational, health and other government programs are delayed because of payments made to coca leaf farmers. The nine-month-old government of President Jaime Paz Zamora is to meet with President Bush in Washington next week to discuss cooperation in fighting cocaine trafficking. The U.S. government is expected to provide at least $60 million this year for military and police assistance to combat cocaine trafficking in Bolivia. The voluntary coca eradication program took off late last year in response to a sharp drop in coca leaf prices brought about by the Colombian anti-drug crackdown and increased interdiction activities in Bolivia. The anti-drug crackdown has disrupted cocaine production and resulted in a glut of coca leaves. A 100 pound sack of coca is selling for around $10 while the cost of production is estimated at $30. A similar weight of leaf sold for $200 to $300 five years ago. Farmers are lining up in front of government offices to sign up for the coca reduction program and tens of thousands of farmers have left the Chapare coca leaf producing region in recent months in response to the sharp drop in coca leaf prices. ``The fact that the voluntary eradiction program has begun to show significant progress proves that interdiction, eradication and alternative development programs are three interdependent parts of an integrated strategy and must be pursued simultaneoulsy and with equal strength,'' U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard said in an interview. The voluntary coca eradication program is taking place in the Chapare, a lush tropical region in the heart of Bolivia that produces nearly a third of the world's coca leaves. At least 300,000 farmers depend on coca leaf cultivation and cocaine production for their livelihood. The leaves, which resemble bay leaves, are grown on bushes and are harvested four times a year. After they are dried they are macerated with kerosene in plastic covered pits to become paste. After further processings in labs located in the Bolivian lowlands as well as in Colombia and Brazil, the paste is transformed into cocaine. The Bolivian government says the country must be developed as a whole in order to wean farmers away from coca cultivation. Bolivia, with a population of 7.1 million, is the poorest country and the largest recepient of U.S. aid in South America. At least $300 million enters the Bolivian economy from cocaine trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Paul Hogan Weds Co-star
DOC.TEXT: ``Crocodile Dundee'' star Paul Hogan married co-star Linda Kozlowski today at the multimillion-dollar mansion he built for her as a wedding gift. In the two Crocodile Dundee movies Hogan, 51, played the ruggedly handsome character from the outback who fell in love with an American journalist played by Ms. Kozlowski, 33. He also has appeared overseas in television commercials promoting Australian tourism. The wedding took place in Byron Bay in far northern New South Wales state of eastern Australia. Hogan, who started his working life as a painter on the Sydney bridge, built the $2 million mansion for his bride as a wedding gift. Reporters were banned from the ceremony, which Hogan had said would be attended by about 100 close friends and family as well as a ``couple of mates.'' The community has been buzzing with rumors for the past week about Hollywood film stars like Sylvester Stallone and Clint Eastwood flying in for the wedding. Local radio reports claimed they were seen in the area, but no official announcement was made about whether they attended. Hogan was married twice before _ to the same woman, Noelene. They separated in 1986 but remarried seven months later before finally ending their 29 years together. They had five children. It was not known if his ex-wife attended, but Hogan said the children were among the guests. The bride's parents, Maj. and Mrs. Stan Kozlowski, flew in from California. Hogan recently completed ``Almost An Angel,'' a film he wrote and starred in.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Guerrilla Fatally Shoots US Soldier Before Bases Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with slain U.S. Marine's hometown, state, U.S. Embassy statement, killing of a central Philippine mayor
DOC.TEXT: A suspected communist guerrilla fatally shot a U.S. Marine near an American-run base, prompting cancellation of off-base leave for all U.S. military personnel in the country, officials said today. The Friday night attack near Subic Naval Base came after authorities said they had evidence communist guerrillas planned to kill Americans before talks begin this month on extending the base's lease. Rebels waging a 21-year-old Marxist insurgency are also suspected of having killed at least 14 people, including a town mayor, in attacks in the central and southern Philippines since Thursday. Gunnery Sgt. John S. Fredette, 34, of Buena Park, Calif., was slain in the liberty town of Olongapo near the base, about 50 miles west of Manila, according to a spokesman for the Subic facility. Fredette was assigned to Marine Fighter@Attack Squadron 323, which is on temporary duty in the Philippines from its base at the Marine Air Station in El Toro, Calif., said spokesman Petty Officer John Moore. A police investigator, Patrolman Romeo de Guzman, said Fredette was walking along a sidestreet in Olongapo when one of five suspected communist New People's Army members shot him once in the neck with a handgun. The five escaped on foot after the shooting. Fredette was rushed to the Subic Base hospital where he died one hour later, de Guzman added. De Guzman said the killing ``has all the earmarks'' of a communist assassination but did not elaborate. Following the killing, U.S. authorities canceled off-base leave and non-essential travel for the 40,000 U.S. troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at Subic and the five other U.S.-run bases throughout the country. Last month, the Navy barred most non-essential travel to Manila but had allowed sailors to visit Olongapo, traditionally among the safest cities in the Philippines. U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt expressed his ``shock and sorrow at the cowardly murder'' of Fredette, said U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Victoria Middleton. The incident is under investigation by both U.S. naval and Philippine authorities. A Filipino intelligence officer, who refused to be identified, said investigators have identified two of the assailants as rebels operating in the nearby province of Bataan. Filipino and U.S. authorities have been concerned after local military officials reported an alleged member of the communist New People's Army hit squad was arrested in Olongapo last week and four other members of the team were still at large. Documents seized from the arrested man, Dionisio Bendoy, indicated a plan by the insurgents to assassinate Americans in the city before the opening of talks on May 14 on the future of six U.S. military facilities in the Philippines. The United States maintains the Subic base, Clark Air Base and four other smaller facilities in the country under a 1947 pact that expires in September 1991. The rebels have demanded the bases be closed. The rebels traditionally have not operated in the Olongapo area because of strong public support for the bases. Rebels do operate around Clark Air Base in central Luzon. Ms. Middleton said security was tightened at American facilities in Manila about two months ago because of fears of a rebel attack. Last September, guerrillas killed two civilian employees of Camp O'Donnell, a U.S. Air Force post near Clark. In October 1987, communist rebels gunned down three Americans in simultaneous attacks outside Clark. At least three other Americans have been killed elsewhere in the country in the past four years, including U.S. Army Col. James ``Nick'' Rowe, who was ambushed April last year while on his way to work in a Manila suburb.

DOC.HEAD: Former Playboy Model Convicted of Tax Evasion
DOC.TEXT: An actress who posed nude for Playboy with her twin sister was convicted of evading taxes on $685,000 in cash she allegedly received from an elderly millionaire for sex. Lynnette Harris, 35, was found guilty Friday by a federal court jury. Her identical twin, Leigh Ann Conley, faces trial June 4 on tax evasion charges. Prosecutors said the sisters received more than $1 million in cash, houses, furs, cars and other items from Milwaukee businessman David Kritzik, who died last June at age 89. Ms. Harris described the cash as a non-taxable gift during her testimony. Prosecutors called it income for sexual service. She would not speak to reporters after the verdict was announced. Ms. Harris was convicted of failing to report as income money she received from Kritzik from 1984 to 1987. The taxes amount to $260,000, said U.S. Attorney Mel Johnson. U.S. District Judge Thomas J. Curran scheduled sentencing for July 25. Ms. Harris could be sentenced to a maximum 12 years in prison and fined $625,000. Her lawyer, Dave Geraghty, said the verdict will be appealed. ``She believes in her innocence and so do we. She was very disappointed,'' Geraghty said. The sisters grew up in Milwaukee and attended a girls' parochial school. Ms. Harris now lives in Mukwonago and Ms. Conley lives in suburban Glendale. The Internal Revenue Service says Ms. Conley owes taxes on $397,000 from Kritzik, who built a fortune as a merchant, stock investor and founder of the Treasure Island discount stores that were eventually sold to J.C. Penney Co. for $11 million. The twins posed nude together for a 1981 edition of Playboy and appeared in two motion pictures, ``Sorceress'' and a remake of ``I, the Jury.''

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow Cuts Town In Two
DOC.TEXT: A fast-moving flow of sizzling lava from Kilauea Volcano cut this deserted town in two Friday and raced toward a final fiery climax with the ocean. A portion of the flow, which had moved about a third of a mile since Thursday night, cut a speeding path around the town's hub. Part of the flow was filling up a gully that separated the molten mass from the Kalapana Store and Drive-In and the Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church. Star of the Sea Church, a Roman Catholic church known as the ``painted church'' because of its colorful murals, was moved, beating by a few hours a portion of the flow that crossed Highway 137 halfway between the town and Harry K. Brown State Park, a quarter of a mile away. Three more homes burned Friday to boost the count to 134 since Kilauea began its current eruption in January 1983. Three of the last families to flee the area managed to move their belongings before their homes were cut off by the encroaching flow. A tractor trailer began moving the church about 7 a.m. Friday. It was brought to a roadside area where other houses that were salvaged are located. Church officials have not said where the church will be relocated. An elderly native Hawaiian woman pleaded with workers and officials not to move the church. But Bishop Joseph Ferrario decided last week to move it to preserve its interior paintings. ``How can you move it? How can you move it?'' the woman screamed at workers preparing to move the church. Others echoed similar sentiments. ``How can you call it Star of the Sea Church if it isn't by the sea?'' asked Kapena Kamahele, a Hilo resident whose family has a long history in Kalapana. Kamahele said the destruction of Kalapana, one of the last vestiges of the ``old style'' Hawaii, was seen by many longtime residents as the punishment for mistreatment of the land. Many of the newer, non-Hawaiian people who moved to the area failed to understand the Hawaiian village lifestyle that many in this coastal community held sacred, she said. ``We are erasing the chalkboard and starting from scratch,'' Kamahele said. ``Hawaiians will teach all people how to do it.'' Civil Defense officials ordered members of the Congregational church who had spent the night in the building to evacuate Friday morning. ``The book is closed. We open a new book today,'' said Bernice McKeague, church moderator. Church members held a prayer vigil Thursday night and watched as the lava built up in a small gully behind the church. The Kalapana Store, the meeting center of the town, remained standing just like its owner said it would. ``Madam Pele (Hawaii's volcano goddess) will never take me,'' said Walter Yamaguchi, the 82-year-old owner. He said he left some supplies in the store to sell once it reopened. However, the flow continued to build behind his store. Of increasing concern to authorities was the threat to public health when the lava begins to fall into the ocean. When lava hits the water, it explodes and releases gases including hydrochloric acid, a strong-smelling chemical that is quite dangerous, said Civil Defense spokesman Bud Trulson.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia Follows Independence Declaration with Currency Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Latvian currency planned, anti-independence rally. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Latvian economists moved quickly today to bolster the republic's declaration of independence by announcing plans for a currency that could be traded internationally. The republic's legislature on Friday joined neighboring Lithuania and Estonia in declaring independence from the Soviet Union, 50 years after the Kremlin annexed the three Baltic republics. However, Latvia took a more gradual approach than Lithuania, saying full independence would come only after an indefinite period of negotiations with Soviet authorities. Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov said low-level talks were expected to begin May 15. ``Everything is ahead,'' he said said after the vote Friday. ``This is only the very, very beginning.'' Soviet leaders had no immediate reaction to Latvia's move. Gorbunov said at an evening news conference that the Latvian government had received a proposal from Estonian President Arnold Ruutel to start immediate coordinated actions on the two republics' drives for independence. Economists of the new Latvia Fund today told a news conference in Riga, the republican capital, that work was under way to restore the pre-Soviet Latvian currency, the lat. The fund, created last month, plans to immediately issue bonds and lottery tickets that can be sold abroad for $11 million to finance the creation and printing of the new currency, they said. The lat may enter circulation _ coexisting with the non-convertible Soviet ruble _ as early as next year, fund members predicted. ``This is not theory. This is a concrete step to independence,'' said Jazeps Barkans, director of Latvian television and a fund member. In addition to voting 138-0 vote for independence, Latvian lawmakers also decided on Friday to drop the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's name, making it simply ``The Republic of Latvia.'' Their call for a gradual break with the Soviet Union, however, contrasted with the Lithuanian decision on March 11 to declare complete independence. Gorbunov said he could not predict what the Soviets would say, but he added that the Latvian government had tried to make it clear that there is ``no cause to close the door on dialogue and start setting ultimatums.'' Fifty-seven anti-independence lawmakers refused to cast ballots in the assembly of just under 200 members. Even so, the measure had no problem achieving the two-thirds majority needed for approval. After the vote was announced, Latvians inside and outside the hall broke into a chorus of ``God Bless Latvia,'' the republic's traditional anthem. A cheering crowd showered emerging lawmakers with roses, pansies and daffodils. Latvians danced in the streets of Riga. ``I waited my whole life for this,'' said Ilma Kaminska, 65, who said she remembered when Latvia was forcibly annexed by Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin in 1940. ``I believed, I always believed,'' she said with tears in her eyes. However, about 300 people gathered on Riga's Cathedral Square this morning to hear speakers mounted on an army truck say the independence declaration was illegal and should be revoked. The rally was organized by Interfront, which includes ethnic Russians and other non-Latvian residents. The independence bill was championed by the pro-independence Latvian People's Front that dominates the parliament. The neighboring republic of Estonia took a similar step March 30. Lithuania, which declared full independence, is now suffering from a Kremlin-imposed economic blockade of oil, natural gas and other raw materials. In his comments Friday, Gorbunov said Latvia could offer its solidarity but had few resources for economic help. In Washington, Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene appealed on Friday for Western backing. She said a strong declaration of support could be decisive in Lithuania's drive. She said she continues to hope that President Bush and other world leaders can yet be persuaded that embracing independence for Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors will not undermine Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his program of political and economic reform.

DOC.HEAD: University Threatens Action Against ROTC for Gay Exclusion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CORRECT name of program, Officers' sted Officer, to CORRECT name of school to University of Kansas sted Kansas University, and to correct style on `senate.' Picks up 7th graf pvs, `University of...'. Stands for story slugged PM-ROTC Protest on PM-News Advisory.
DOC.TEXT: Students at universities around the country protested the exclusion of homosexuals from the Reserve Officers' Training Corps, and an assembly at one school threatened to withhold credit for ROTC courses. The activities Friday at 25 campuses were coordinated by students at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. At the University of Kansas, the school senate proposed that ROTC courses no longer be counted for credit toward graduation until the Department of Defense changes its policy of banning homosexuals from earning military commissions through the program. The policy prohibits gay students from entering the ROTC, though they make take ROTC courses. The Lawrence, Kan., school's senate, two-thirds faculty and one-third students, said the proposal would go into effect next year, pending approval by Chancellor Gene Budig, unles the ROTC policy is reversed. The senate also passed a motion to ban ROTC from holding commissioning ceremonies on university property until the issue is resolved. University of Washington students in Seattle adopted a resolution calling on the school's regents to lobby the state's congressional delegation to help change the discriminatory law. ``These students may be just as disciplined and capable as any other soldier, sailor, pilot or officer, but because of their sexual preference or orientation, they are barred from serving in the armed forces,'' students association president Heidi Wills said. ``This is treating a segment ... of our student body as second-class citizens,'' she said. Declarations also were made Friday at Northwestern, the University of California at Los Angeles and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, among other schools. About 20 Ohio State University students gathered outside the administration building to protest the presence of ROTC on the campus. Students carried signs including one that read, `The Few. The Proud. The Gay.'' ``ROTC is such a big part of this campus, and they won't let us in. The university is hypocritical and needs to live up to their stated policy of non-discrimination based on sexual orientation,'' said Mike Scarce, vice president of the Gay and Lesbian Alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebels Kidnap American
DOC.TEXT: An American Peace Corps volunteer and three relief workers were kidnapped by Liberian rebels as they inspected refugee centers along the Liberian-Guinean border, a French relief agency has said. The American, David Kelley, was checking water supplies at a Liberian village when he was kidnapped on Tuesday, said Marc Gastellu-Epchjorry, a spokesman for Doctors Without Borders. Kelley's hometown was not known. Also abducted were Ludovic Pichrist, a logistics expert from the group's Belgian chapter; Werner Will of West Germany; and a Guinean, Naiankoye Kolie, Gastellu-Epchjorry said Friday. The State Department reported the abductions but did not identify the victims. Kolie was freed on Friday, and he reached Guinean authorities, the spokesman said. ``He said the other three are in good health, but the rebels want to interrogate them,'' said Gastellu-Epchjorry. He did not know when or where the three Westerners might be released or what the subject of interrogtion might be. The three were checking water sanitation at border villages where more than 100,000 people have sought refuge from fighting between the rebels and troops loyal to President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia. The French and Belgian chapters of Doctors Without Borders have sent 16 people to the region to vaccinate refugees and assure the quality of their water supplies to prevent epidemics. The rebels have previously captured other Westerners and held them for several days before releasing them. Fighting between the rebels and Liberian government troops broke out Dec. 24 in northeastern Nimba County, and humanitarian groups estimate hundreds of rebels and scores of soldiers have been killed. About 250,000 refugees have fled to other parts of Liberia and to Guinea and Ivory Coast. Washington is a staunch supporter of Doe, who seized power in a bloody 1980 coup from the descendants of freed U.S. slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. But about 400 of the 500 American personnel and their dependents have left Liberia in recent days as rebel forces have moved to within striking distance of the capital, Monrovia, the State Department has said. Officials last week described the exodus not as an evacuation but an ``authorized voluntary departure.'' Before the departures got under way, there were about 5,000 Americans in Liberia. There are no precise figures available on the number Americans in unofficial capacities who have left.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS NEW YORK-dated last item to delete reference in 2nd graf to Trump `divorce proceedings'. No divorce action has been filed.
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples may have to wait a while longer to see her name on the marquee instead of in supermarket tabloid headlines. The so-called other woman in the marital wrangling of Donald and Ivana Trump auditioned for Madonna's role in the national tour of the Broadway show ``Speed-the-Plow.'' But she didn't get it. ``Marla was actually quite good,'' Gene Wolsk, a co-producer, told The New York Times. ``But even before we came to any decision, her people asked about the length of the tour and she was hesitant about committing herself for that period of time.'' Ms. Maples has had a couple of bit parts in movies and has done some modeling. Madonna starred as an office temp working for two Hollywood producers in playwright David Mamet's ``Speed-the-Plow,'' a scathing look at greed in the film industry. Brooke Shields has also been mentioned as a possibility for the role originally played by Madonna. But Wolsk told the Times the producers were now thinking about casting an actress who did not necessarily have ``a name.''

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators Do Not Expect Agreement Next Week As Planned
DOC.TEXT: NATO and Warsaw Pact countries say they will not be able to reach agreement by next week as planned on terms for monitoring each other's airspace, according to news reports today. However, both sides still hope for an accord this year, the reports said. About 250 experts from the countries are meeting in Budapest for a second round of talks in the so-called Open Skies conference. The conference is intended to build trust between the two military blocs by opening their skies to surveillance flights that would allow other countries to monitor their military activities. At the first round of talks in Ottawa, Canada, in February, the participants set a tentative May 12 deadline for signing an accord by the foreign ministers of the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations. Tibor Toth, head of the Hungarian delegation to the talks, said it now appeared certain the two sides would not be able to reach agreement by then, the daily Nepszabadsag reported. U.S. and Soviet negotiators said last week they did not expect the conference to meet its deadline, citing ``major outstanding problems'' that still needed to be resolved. But they, too, have said they would like to see an accord signed by the end of the year. There is already agreement that the size of a country should determine how many surveillance flights it is allotted. But the United States and the Soviet Union disagree on a number of key issues, including the type of plane and equipment used and how information obtained from the flights should be used. The Soviet Union would like the information to be pooled, but the United States wants information sharing to be voluntary.

DOC.HEAD: Police Raid Broadcast Network to Arrest Union Leader
DOC.TEXT: Police raided the headquarters of South Korea's second largest broadcast network and seized a fugitive union leader. In other labor unrest, dozens of workers came down from a crane where they had been conducting a sit-down strike at a shipyard in southern Korea. About 100 riot troopers stormed into the main office of the Munhwa Broadcasting Co. shortly before midnight Friday, surrounded the network's union office, and hauled away union leader Chun Young-il. Scuffles occurred between a dozen MBC workers and police officers, but no injuries were reported. Chun, a 38-year-old union leader from the nation's largest broadcast network, KBS, had stayed in the nearby MBC building since police stormed the KBS headeuarters on Monday. About 1,000 MBC workers have staged a sympathy strike to support KBS workers, who were demanding the resignation of their new government-appointed chief. They consider the new boss an opponent of reform efforts in South Korea. Police have been searching for union leaders accused of organizing recent labor protests at the KBS network, factories and the Hyundai Heavy Industries Co. shipyard in the southern city of Ulsan. Labor protests in South Korea died down today, a national holiday for the Children's Day. However, thousands of riot police remained on alert around the Hyundai shipyard, where some workers remained on strike. Relatives persuaded dozens of workers holed up on top of a 240-foot crane at the shipyard to end their sit-in today. Another 19 exhausted workers came down on Friday. There have been contradictory reports on the number of the workers on the crane, but police believe more than 50, including several union leaders wanted by police, are still there. Police prepared nets and air mattresses at the shipyard to prevent suicide attempts by the workers remaining on the crane. The workers climbed the crane a week ago when thousands of police firing tear gas raided the world's largest shipyard to quell a three-day strike demanding the release of jailed union leaders. The police raid triggered sympathy strikes at other Hyundai subsidiaries in Ulsan and other cities.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Prince Seeks Reconciliation With Syria, Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Crown Prince Abdallah bin Abdul Aziz of Saudi Arabia arrived today for talks with Syrian leaders on ending a long-standing rift with Iraq and forging a new Arab unity. Damascus is the prince's first stop on a tour of key Arab capitals amid efforts to mediate a rapprochement between Syria and Iraq and to convene an emergency Arab summit in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad. Abdallah is also scheduled to visit Baghdad and Cairo. He also is expected to try to end the 7-year-old feud between President Hafez Assad and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasser Arafat. In 1983, Syrian-backed radical Palestinian factions mutinied and drove PLO forces out of their last Lebanese stronghold. Ending these rifts would overcome the last major obstacles to organizing the strongest show of Arab unity in decades. It would also open the way for a Baghdad summit later this month. Last month, Arafat called for a Baghdad summit to discuss the massive emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel and other pressing Middle East issues. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein wants to host the summit and show that the Arab world supports him amid what he views as a concentrated Western campaign against Iraq's drive to build up its military arsenal. The United States and Britain say authorities intercepted nuclear trigger devices and components for a huge ``super gun'' as they were being smuggled from Britain to Iraq. Experts believe the gun would have been capable of firing chemical weapons at Israel. Saddam claims the Western effort is aimed at setting the stage for an Israeli attack on Iraq's burgeoning military installations. The Saudi envoy's visit to Damascus coincided with a visit to Baghdad by King Hussein of Jordan to persuade Saddam to reconcile with Syria's Assad. But the Syrian president told visiting Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak on Thursday that he will not attend the Baghdad summit because he was not consulted in advance. Arab League sources said the 22-member organization's secretary-general, Chadli Bendjedid, plans to visit Damascus to persuade Syria to attend. Prince Abdallah is also chairman of an Arab League committee assigned to ``clear pan-Arab obstacles.'' The committee, formed at the 1982 Arab summit in Morocco was instrumental in promoting a rapprochement between Syria and Jordan. Syria and Egypt recently resumed ties, taking Arabs a step closer to the unity that has eluded them for decades. Libya has also moved toward patching up its differences with Egypt. Most Arab nations broke relations with Cairo over its 1979 peace treaty with Israel. But Egypt has gradually re-established ties with most Arab nations since 1987 when an Arab summit welcomed it back into the Arab fold. In addition, Syria and Jordan improved relations in 1985 after years of dispute. Last year, Syria restored ties with Morocco that were broken in 1986. And Marxist South Yemen and conservative North Yemen are striving toward unity after a 20-year split.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Train Wreck Outside Oaxaca Kills At Least Six
DOC.TEXT: A train carrying about 200 passengers left the rails and tumbled into a dry riverbed in southern Oaxaca state, killing at least six people and injuring 40, the Mexican Red Cross said. The relief organization originally had said that at least 40 people died in Thursday night's crash. But Ana Maria Tovar, local director of the Red Cross, reduced the death toll on Friday and said the mistake occurred because the crash site was isolated and the accident occurred at night. A news release from the Mexican National Railroad put the toll at seven dead and 20 injured. The second-class train, The Oaxacan, was en route from Oaxaca to Mexico City when it left the tracks, apparently because of brake failure. The derailment occurred at Cuicatlan village. No foreigners were reported aboard.

DOC.HEAD: Germanys, Allies Open Talks On Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more comments from Genscher and other foreign ministers. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today dismissed Soviet objections to NATO membership for a united Germany as he opened unification talks with the World War II Allies. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, however, acknowledged that other nations have ``legitimate interests'' that may need to be addressed. In addition to the Soviet objections, Poland wants assurances that Germany will not claim any Polish land that was German territory prior to World War II. Genscher, Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze joined their counterparts from Britain, France and East Germany for the first such top-level talks on uniting the Germanys. The six diplomats gathered this morning at the Foreign Ministry in Bonn. Final decisions were not expected from the meeting, held just 3{ weeks before the start of the U.S.-Soviet summit in Washington. East Germany's Markus Meckel, a pastor and former janitor turned foreign minister, was the first to arrive in a black Mercedes-Benz. Chatting with each other, the men stood in a row and posed for photographers, with Baker and Shevardnadze constantly side by side. At the heart of the talks is the Soviet refusal to accept a united Germany in NATO. The Soviets have called for a neutral Germany, and Shevardnadze said today Moscow remained opposed to NATO membership for a united Germany, according to ADN, East Germany's government-run news agency. He said such an arrangement would be ``incompatible with Soviet security interests,'' it said. ``The foreign minister asked his counterparts at the table for understanding,'' ADN reported. Baker and British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd tried to ease the Soviet fears, said a British official who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. He quoted Hurd as saying, ``We are seeing a changing NATO. We are moving away from the vocabulary of the Cold War.'' ``We have difficult problems to solve,'' Genscher said in his opening remarks after they had sat down at a round table inside the Foreign Ministry's main conference room. ``However, if we are all willing not only to defend our own interests but also to respect the interests of our partners, then we will find solutions.'' Genscher started his remarks, distributed to reporters beforehand, by calling to mind the ``immeasurable suffering'' caused by World War II and the Nazi dictatorship. He also mentioned the Helsinki Final Act regulating relations among European countries, as he rebuffed Moscow's opposition to a unified Germany in the U.S.-led Atlantic Alliance. ``The Final Act emphasizes quite distinctly that all principles are of primary significance,'' Genscher said. ``In this connection, I refer to the principle of sovereign equality, which gives all participating states the right to be or not to be a party to treaties of alliance.'' ``Since we know that the Western alliance, adapting itself as it does to the changes in Europe, brings about peace and security, a free-standing united Germany would be of no benefit to Europe,'' he added. Baker and Hurd echoed Genscher's position that it was for the Germans alone to decide whether they want to belong to an alliance. Baker said in his opening statement the United States and the other Allied powers that carved up Germany after the Nazi defeat 45 years ago should not impose special restrictions on a united Germany, thereby ``planting seeds of future instability.'' ``Today we engage in an act of reconcialition _ of a people too long separated, of a continent too long divided,'' Baker said. Shevardnadze was conciliatory in his statement, according to the British official. ``He accepted entirely the self-determination of the German people,'' the official said. Neither Shevardnadze nor Baker dwelled on Germany's Nazi past. ``We don't want a discussion on obsolete views,'' the British official quoted Shevardnadze as saying. Baker said, ``We face the challenge of rising above the past.'' The British official said French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas called for Poland to become involved in the unification talks at the third meeting of the foreign ministers, to be held in Paris. A date has not been set. While Genscher has said a united Germany will be in NATO, he also has offered to let the Soviets keep some of their troops in what is now East Germany for a transitional period. About 250,000 U.S. troops are stationed in West Germany, with an estimated 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Killed In Wedding Reception Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Hooded gunmen opened fire on a crowd attending a wedding reception Saturday, killing seven people and wounding four others, the state-run news agency reported. The shooting occurred at 5 a.m. in San Carlos City in Pangasinan province, 100 miles northwest of Manila, the Philippine News Agency said. The agency quoted San Carlos police station chief Capt. Juanito Mangonon as saying the gunmen raked the wedding reception with automatic gunfire shortly after the groom and the bride left for the wedding ceremony at a Roman Catholic church, a few miles away. The assailants were apparently after one of the guests but opened fire on the people preparing the wedding reception after failing to find their target, Mangonon said. The gunmen fled on foot after the shooting.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Take Gold After Holding Businessman's Family Hostage
DOC.TEXT: Robbers held a businessman and his family hostage until he revealed the combinations of safes at his foundry, then stole more than $250,000 worth of gold, police said Saturday. Five gunmen broke into the isolated suburban villa of Jean-Luc Escard on Friday evening and held his wife, 3-year-old daughter and mother-in-law captive while awaiting his return from his business in Marseille, police said. Escard was overpowered when he arrived and was struck several times before telling the robbers the combinations of safes at his business, police said. Two robbers went to his office, taking Mrs. Escard with them to dismantle an alarm system, stole the gold, then returned to the villa to drop off the woman and flee in Escard's car with their colleagues. Police said detectives had made little progress in their investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Union to Withdraw 26,800 Troops From Mongolia This Year
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will withdraw 26,800 troops from Mongolia by the end of this year, the Soviet military commander in Ulan Bator said Saturday. The Soviets in March promised to pull out all of their estimated 60,000 troops by 1992, with planned withdrawal of main combat units in 1991 and equipment support units the following year. Lt. Gen. Mayorov was quoted by the official Chinese news agency, Xinhua, as saying during a news conference in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator that the troop withdrawal would begin May 15 and end in August. The troops include a motorized-infantry division and several air units. The Soviets will also pull out 436 tanks, 375 cannon, 400 armored cars and over 5,930 other weapons, Xinhua said. The Soviets will turn over 55 barracks and seven airports to the Mongolians, and its remaining troops will leave by the end of 1992, Mayorov said. The withdrawal is part of an effort to improve relations with China and to cut the Soviet defense budget. Soviet troop withdrawl has been one of the demands of Mongolian opposition groups.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 6 p.m. EDT, TIME set by source
DOC.HEAD: Panel Studies 1988 Election, Says Voters Didn't Do Their Job
DOC.TEXT: Voters surrendered to apathy or uncritical acceptance of George Bush's campaign ads in the 1988 presidential election, a political study panel concludes. ``American voters today do not seem to understand their rightful place in the operation of American democracy,'' the panel said in a report Saturday. ``They act as if they believe that presidential elections belong to somebody else, most notably presidential candidates and their handlers.'' The panel _ eight figures from politics, the media, political science and public policy analysis _ spent two years on the project. They used polls, focus group interviews and analysis of news coverage of the election. ``Folks have basically checked out,'' said Bruce Buchanan, executive director of the panel and associate professor of government at the University of Texas. The panel was assembled by the Markle Foundation, which studies the role of mass communications in a democratic society. Two months before the election, a third of the people could not name Dan Quayle as Bush's running mate, and nearly a half couldn't name Lloyd Bentsen as Michael Dukakis' would-be vice president, Buchanan said. Just weeks before the election, 22 percent still could not name Quayle and 30 percent could not identify Bentsen, he said. Moreover, the group said, most citizens did not inform themselves well enough to be able to recognize mistruths in the Bush campaign's paid advertising. ``When we asked voters what they had learned about each candidate, particularly Dukakis, they said they `learned' that he was willing to furlough convicted murderers and had no concern about the pollution of Boston Harbor,'' Buchanan said. ``What they didn't know was the extent to which the advertising squared with a reasonable construction of the facts.'' The panel also blamed the news media and the candidates themselves for what it called a failure to live up their responsibilities. Most coverage, especially on television, concentrated on the ``horse race'' aspects of the election _ who is leading _ and the personalities of the contestants, rather than the candidates' qualifications or the issues. Even when the news focused on campaign advertising, it emphasized the ``guile'' of the Republicans' commercials and the ineffectiveness of the Democrats' rather than the veracity of the claims, the commission said. The panel expressed dismay at the turnout _ 50.1 percent of eligible voters actually cast ballots, the lowest percentage in 64 years. ``Even as enthusiasm for democracy ignites around the globe, it is waning in the very nation whose political traditions inspire others,'' the panel said. The panel called for congressional pressure for institutionalized candidate debates and free air time to educate voters. It said the news media should ``assume a more substantive role in seeking the truth in candidate claims in advertising'' and should overcome candidates' ``attempts to misuse the media.'' The panel also called for keeping polls open for 20 hours on election day, for eliciting broadcasters' cooperating in not projecting winners until the polls are closed everywhere and for simpler registration procedures. Members of the panel were Robert O'Neil, president of the University of Virginia, chairman; James David Barber, Duke University political scientist; former Sens. John C. Culver, D-Iowa, and Charles Mathias, R-Md.; Joan Konner, dean of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism; Eugene Patterson, editor emeritus of the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times; and Eddie N. Williams, president of the Joint Center for Policy Studies.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Shows Thousands Are Victims of Phony Health Plans
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Americans face as much as $500 million in unpaid medical bills because they relied on thinly funded and often fraudulent health plans that collapsed, according to a published report. A three-month investigation by the Gannett News Service found that many of the defunct health plans were the work of con artists who preyed on small businesses and their employees. Some failures can be blamed on business errors and mismanagement, the investigation found, but others resulted because the plan operators paid themselves big salaries and ran up huge expense accounts, then quit paying claims and moved on. State and federal authorities, including postal inspectors, the Office of Labor Racketeering and the FBI, are pursuing civil and criminal investigations of dozens of health plans across the country, Gannett said. At least two federal indictments already have been handed up, and more are expected over the next few months, the report said. The Senate Investigations subcommittee chaired by Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has scheduled hearings on the problem for May 14-15. The Gannett investigation found that while many victims were left without health coverage, the plans provided handsome lifestyles for their operators. For example, Michael Rubell and James Helm, owners of Rubell Helm Insurance Services of Irvine, Calif., which owes millions in unpaid claims in Florida, Texas and California, took $7,100-a-week salaries, Gannett said. Rubell and Helm's tailor got $115,000 in company funds in less than a year, the newspaper chain said, citing court documents in a lawsuit brought by California against the pair. They declined to talk to Gannett for the story. By contrast, many victims are of modest means, such as teachers, service station attendants and textile mill workers. They work for small employers _ sometimes the owner and family members are the only people covered _ who find it nearly impossible to get affordable health insurance coverage. ``The groups of people who are victimized are the ones who can least afford the hit,'' said Norman Transeth, a Labor Department investigator looking into health insurance fraud. For instance, Richard Flaherty was awaiting double bypass heart surgery at a hospital in Sparks, Nev., last June when word came that health insurance coverage sold through his trade association wasn't any good. A retired service station operator, Flaherty still owes about $120,000 in medical bills. His insurance claim is part of a federal lawsuit to settle the dispute over who should pay the bills. The health plans that have collapsed in recent years are known collectively as Multiple Employer Trusts or Multiple Employer Welfare Arrangements. They cover employees of a group of companies, usually small businesses. Unlike traditional health plans provided by large companies, labor unions and government, METs and MEWAs often are not fully or even partly covered by insurance firms. And because regulations are lax, the Gannett investigation showed, the plans seldom are required to hold reserves against losses. Instead, they rely on monthly contributions to cover claims and operating expenses. But in many cases, Gannett found, expenses are inflated and premiums are kept low to attract participants. When claims exceed expectations, the plans cannot pay. ``All too many of these are nothing more than Ponzi schemes,'' said Raymond Maria, acting Labor Department inspector general, who is working to expose what he calls ``a burgeoning problem of fraud.'' In a Ponzi scheme, current income is used to pay off previous investors; when new investments slow and income declines, the scheme collapses.

DOC.HEAD: London No Longer No. 1 in Phone Books
DOC.TEXT: London telephones jangle to new numbers on Sunday, when area codes 71 and 81 replace the simple No. 1. If only it were that simple. ``I am totally confident that all the necessary adjustments will be made as planned on Sunday,'' said Millie Banerjee, general manager of British Telecom's London network. She was speaking only for the company, not the customer. British Telecom is ready for up to 50,000 misdialed calls per minute, and has prepared recorded messages in the appropriate languages to intercept international calls placed with the wrong number. For international callers, London numbers will be preceded by the country code, 44, and either 71 or 81 depending on location in the city. Callers within Britain will be dialing 071 or 081 instead of 01. With Britain enjoying a three-day weekend, the real test won't come until Tuesday when banks, exchanges and businesses reopen. Telecom says London is the foreign city that receives the most calls from the United States _ up to 100,000 a day. Because of the proliferation of fax machines and direct-dial business systems that assign a telephone number to every desk, Telecom said it had used up nearly all the potential 5 million numbers in the old London exchange. Splitting the city will double the pool. The 71 code has been assigned to inner London, within approximately 4 miles of Charing Cross, and 81 to the outer reaches. John Turner, Telecom's communications manager for the code change, said Friday that as many as one-fourth of the 380,000 businesses in London had not reprogrammed their telephones or fax machines. David Fletcher, chief executive of the British Security Industry Association, estimated that as many as one-fourth of the capital's 100,000 burglar alarms had not been adjusted to contact the new numbers. Some people are upset by the change. Many believe that self-esteem and property values are bound to decline in areas with the 81 code such as Finchley, Hornsey, Shepherds Bush, Hammersmith, Wembley, Putney and Tooting. Elsie Burch Donald, author of ``Debrett's Etiquette and Modern Manners,'' laid down the law a year ago: ``071 will be a superior number to have. Clearly there is an advantage socially, culturally, economically to be living in central London.'' Judging from letters to London newspapers, however, the new telephone numbers are being taken in stride. Only one gripe was noted in the major papers last week. ``We'll be 081, and nobody gives a damn,'' said Elaine Howard, manager of a real estate office in Blackheath. ``I have heard it will make a difference to the market, but so far it's all rumor.'' The change should be simple for Britons accustomed to wrestling with Telecom's maddening provincial directories, which list telephone numbers and city codes in separate sections. If you're dialing a number in Piddletrenthide, for instance, you find the number in the white pages and the city code in the pink _ 03004 for three-digit numbers or 0300 for six-digit numbers. Sir Bryan Carsberg, director-general of the Office of Telecommunications, advised spending a few moments to prepare. Change your personal telephone lists, reprogram that push-button telephone, check that fax machine, lay in a supply of stick-on labels to correct obsolete stationery, he urged. ``Sir Bryan,'' according to a statement released by his office, ``wishes the telephone operating companies, and you, the all-important customers, a successful changeover to the new London numbering scheme.''

DOC.HEAD: Presidents Don't Occupy Front Row-Center at Famed Washington Church
DOC.TEXT: The place of honor in ``the church of the presidents'' is not in the front row but back toward the cheap seats. Pew 54 at St. John's Church is where George and Barbara Bush sit when they visit the landmark building across Lafayette Square from the White House, as they often do on Sundays when they are in Washington. Every president since James Madison has worshipped in the yellow Episocopal church at least once, and it was Madison himself who choose Pew 54 as the president's row. The Rev. John C. Harper, pastor of St. John's since 1963, savors the symbolism of America's president being seated ``in the midst of the people'' instead of the front pew. The Bushes are at Camp David, Md., this weekend so they will not be on hand for a service Sunday at which the presiding bishop of the Episcopal Church, Edmond Browning, will lead the parish in celebrating its 175th anniversary. But Harper provided a taste of St. John's history for the Bushes and the few dozen others who turned out for the 8 a.m. communion service last Sunday. He called St. John's, nestled between the headquarters of the AFL-CIO and the Veterans Affairs Department, ``a symbol of small power amid great power ... a reminder that not all of the things in this life are large.'' The yellow stucco church was designed by Benjamin Henry Latrobe, the same architect who oversaw the construction of the U.S. Capitol and the rebuilding of the White House after it was burned by the British in the War of 1812. The cornerstone was laid in 1815 and the first services held a few years later. Shortly thereafter, the congregation decided to expand the compact, cross-shaped Byzantine structure, and a nave, belltower and columned porch were added. Not that all the services were packed. John Adams complained in his diary after returning from a service in 1828: ``There were scarcely 30 persons in the house. The neglect of public worship in this city is an increasing evil.'' Although they frequently attend St. John's, the Bushes remain on the parish roll of another Episcopal church, St. Martin's, in their hometown of Houston. The Harvard-educated Harper, a New England contemporary of Bush's, has seen seven presidents during his 27 years at St. John's. John F. Kennedy attended his installation in 1963 _ and sat in the front pew. Lyndon Johnson slipped into the church for prayer in November 1963, the day after Kennedy's assassination. Gerald Ford worshipped there frequently. Ronald Reagan attended services on the mornings of his two inaugurations _ and on Sunday, March 29, 1981, the day before he was wounded in an assassination attempt. Bush and Dan Quayle both showed up for a prayer service on the morning of their inaugurations last year. Harper, in an interview, said of preaching before a president, ``I don't want to sound blase, but it's no big deal. ... I've never tailored my sermons to whoever is coming.'' A literary man and onetime English teacher, Harper also does not thunder over affairs of state. ``It's not my style. I'm a pastoral preacher. I'm not a prophetic preacher,'' he said. ``When I was called here to be rector, I remember saying to the vestry, `You really don't want me. What you ought to have in that pulpit is somebody who can make the headlines of The Washington Post on Monday morning ... someone like Bishop Pike.' They said , `Oh, no, no, no. we don't,''' he recalled. Instead, they got what Harper called a ``garden-variety pastor'' who has succeeded in building the congregation's rolls to more than 1,000 and reducing the average age of the vestry to 43. ``When I came here they (the vestry) were all members of the Metropolitan Club, as a symbol of power. My guess is now maybe a quarter of them might be. I consider that great progress,'' said Harper, himself a member in good standing of the elite club. Harper prides himself on being non-partisan. He ascribes to some advice a friend once gave him. It's fine to be called ``the church of the presidents,'' the friend counseled, but ``be sure that you're never known as `the church of the president.'''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Storm Tourist Resort, Rob Guests
DOC.TEXT: Twenty gunmen in camouflage uniforms robbed tourists and local residents in a midnight raid on a resort hotel that left some guests with only their pajamas, police said Saturday. Attacks on foreigners have been rare in Sri Lanka, despite ethnic and political strife that has claimed more than 17,000 lives in seven years. The raid also occurred as tourism in Sri Lanka, once badly affected by the violence, had been picking up recently. The robbers escaped early Saturday with $25,000 worth of cameras, jewelry, clothing and cash in the raid on the Sigiriya Village Hotel located in a jungle near archaeological ruins 95 miles northeast of Colombo, the police said. No injuries were reported, but some guests were left with only their nightclothes. The nationalities and number of the guests were not immediately known, but police said 32 of the hotel's 100 rooms were occupied.

DOC.HEAD: Alabama Town Holds Separate Proms for Blacks and Whites
DOC.TEXT: Change comes slowly to this Old South town of stately mansions and Confederate flags on pickup trucks, where dogwood blossoms and racially segregated high school proms are sure signs of spring. There are no signs of racial division among the 760 students at modern, red-brick Eufala High School. Sixty percent are white, but the president of the student body and president of the 180-member senior class are black, as are the basketball and football homecoming queens. But when it comes time to don formal gowns and rented tuxedoes for the annual junior-senior affair, white students go to one dance, blacks to another. Both are sponsored by private groups, not the school itself. ``I think we're the only school in Alabama that does this. We're the only one in America, I hope,'' said senior class president James Samuel, who is bound for the U.S. Air Force Academy after graduation. ``They seem to think that if we go to dances together, there will be racial flareups, a fight,'' said Carmen Campbell, 18, a white senior and friend of Samuel. Community leaders say the southeast Alabama city of about 14,000 still has segregated proms even though the public school system was integrated 20 years ago after years of maintaining separate schools for blacks and whites. Superintendent Dan Parker said the school district got out of the dance business completely four years earlier, but he denied race was the reason. ``Alcohol usually gets to be a problem,'' said Parker, who has headed the 2,900-student system since 1978. ``They leave, get drunk, and then come back. Why should the board or teachers have to assume liability for that?'' Opponents of segregated proms claim the white-controlled school board uses worries over liquor and liability to dodge the issue of mixed-race dances. The school system also refuses to sponsor homecoming dances and sock-hops. An ROTC banquet planned for late May will be the first school-sanctioned social event in about two decades, officials said. ``If the whites don't want to have a prom with the blacks, you can't make them, and vice versa,'' said W.D. Moorer, a school board member since the 1950s. ``I don't think it's been a big issue, but it might be now.'' School board president Billy Houston called holding two proms ``a case of individual preference by the students.'' Eufaula's annual white prom is sponsored by a group called Youth Enterprises, whose president, Marie Houston, is Houston's daughter. The whites' dance is May 19 at Lakepoint State Park Resort on the banks of Lake Eufaula. The black prom, put on by Young Blacks in Action, is May 26 at Lakepoint. A group of black parents last went before the school board about three years ago asking it to sponsor a joint prom, but neither the board nor the administration took up the idea. ``We have gone to the Board of Education, the superintendent of education and the principal, and they just give us the run-around,'' said Rose Jordan of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Nearly all the seniors at a class meeting last fall cheered when Samuel suggested holding a single prom, Miss Campbell said. Wayne Fiquett, in his first year as principal at Eufaula High School, said he has talked with students and faculty about holding an integrated prom in 1991. Several teachers were ``very willing'' to chaperone. Parker said student support for a joint, school-sponsored prom might not be enough to win the school board's approval. ``The senior class might be 90 percent in favor of going to the Bahamas, too, or abortion, or all coming to school naked, but that doesn't mean we're going to do it,'' he said. ``Children learn from experiences, but the school system cannot provide all of life's experiences.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Claims Paper Invades Privacy By Publishing Divorce Lists
DOC.TEXT: A Newport newspaper's inconspicuous list of divorces could become a test of a state's right to bar public information from being reported by the news media. The U.S. Supreme Court has refused to say whether states can put off-limits otherwise public information by invoking privacy concerns _ and a Newport divorce lawyer contends Rhode Island's privacy law is such a shield. Attorney Thomas W. Kelly is suing The Newport Daily News on behalf of a woman who wants to keep her name out of the newspaper's monthly listing of divorces granted in Newport County Family Court. ``The Supreme Court has opened the door for the first time,'' said Kelly, citing its June 1989 ruling clearing The Florida Star newspaper after it published the name of a rape victim despite state law against such publication. The paper was not not liable for invasion of privacy, the high court ruled, but said there might be a ``zone of personal privacy within which the state may protect the individual from intrusion by the press.'' Rhode Island's 10-year-old privacy law provides the right to be secure from ``unreasonable publicity'' of a fact ``which would be offensive or objectionable to a reasonable man of ordinary sensibilities.'' Kelly acknowledges his chances of winning are slim, but argues his client is entitled to privacy because she is not a prominent figure and has not run for public office. He wants the newspaper to ``discern the newsworthiness'' of the divorces it publishes. A hearing on the case is set for Monday, when the court is expected to consider the newspaper's motion to dismiss the lawsuit. Jane Kirtley, head of the Reporters Committee for the Freedom of the Press, said the lawsuit is frivolous. In open court, she said, ``the press' role is to act as a surrogate for that portion of the public which cannot be there.'' Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz, who defended Newport socialite Claus von Bulow on charges he attempted to murder his wife, said there is ``no possibility'' a state can bar publication of a public record. ``The only way for the state to get around that is to say divorce is not a matter of public record _ but of course it is,'' Dershowitz said. David B. Offer, the newspaper's editor, said divorces are noteworthy, regardless of the people involved, because of their effects on the community, its businesses, schools, churches and welfare programs. ``Some may call that voyeurism or scandal,'' Offer said. ``But it seems to me that if (divorces) are of interest to a segment of the community that people have a right to read about them in a community newspaper.'' Kelly also contends divorce carries a social stigma, an argument dismissed by sociologist Frances Goldscheider of Brown University. ``If 50 percent of marriages end in divorce, it can't be much of a stigma anywhere,'' she said. Eileen Slocum of Newport's ritzy Bellevue Avenue, said divorce is no more an issue in Newport than elsewhere. ``There are a few very well-known people that really want no accessibility but there aren't very many,'' she said. Slocum said she scans the divorce listing, like she does the obituaries, because ``I hate to miss out on the death of a friend or a divorce.'' The plaintiff, identified as Jane Doe, declined to be interviewed, saying through Kelly that she did not want to discuss her personal life. The attorney said she is in her 20s, was married less than 10 years and had no children. A second woman who came forward after learning of the lawsuit is identified in a pending amended complaint as Alison Roe.
