For House Democrats, an inevitable vote on the Frank case will put them on record as either abandoning a party colleague or appearing to condone what Frank himself admits was ``bad judgment.'' Even Republicans who might expect to gain from Frank's troubles might be wary lest House members of both parties start to find their personal lives going under the investigative microscope. Frank has already announced his bid for a sixth term despite a deadlock in the ethics committee's eight-month investigation. The slow progress prompted him to abandon his plan to await a verdict before announcing whether he would seek reelection. There is no time limit on the ethics committee and every week of delay brings it closer to the election. At least one conservative Republican is hoping the case is resolved in time to get Democrats on the record before elections. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., has promised to seek a floor vote on expelling Frank from the House once the ethics committee completes its work. He wants to force Democrats to choose between anti-homosexual sentiments among the voters and loyalty to a colleague who has ensnared himself in an unpopular ethics case. ``A Democratic incumbent who votes against a tougher penalty will have to answer whether that sort of behavior would be tolerated locally,'' said Gary Koops of the National Republican Campaign Committee. Koops said Republican strategists have no plans to make the Frank case a national political litmus test. Rather, he said, ``it's a district by district issue.'' Republicans will fail if they try to pin Barney Frank's problems on other Democrats, according to Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee spokesman Howard Schloss. Republicans tried to use former House Speaker Jim Wright's troubles at elections in some 30 congressional districts and failed to do any political damage, Schloss said. ``It just doesn't work,'' Schloss said. ``That's not why people vote for members.'' When the closed-door ethics committee deliberations broke down last week _ eight months into the investigation _ initial speculation held that Republican members were insisting on a tough penalty in hopes of forcing a floor vote. Committee members who insisted on anonymity said however that much of the dispute within the panel concerned upholding its reputation as a bi-partisan body whose recommendations traditionally have been unanimous. The ethics panel is different from other House committees, which are controlled by majority Democrats, because its membership is evenly divided between the two parties. The committee members also said there is no unanimity among precedent-conscious lawmakers on how to address the question of an individual congressman's sexual conduct. Any committee decision is likely to address the question of whether it is tolerable for a member of Congress to hire a prostitute. The case focuses on Frank's admission that he paid Gobie $80 to have sexual relations with him in 1985 and that he hired Gobie as a personal assistant and chauffeur. It also centers on the charges by Gobie that he operated a prostitution ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment with the congressman's knowledge, that the two had sexual relatons in the House gymnasium and that Frank invoked congressional privilege to waive parking tickets incurred by Gobie while using Frank's car. Particulars of the Frank case seem unusual enough that they might not produce a precedent applicable in many future controversies. But some ruling by the House on the question of prostitution seems all but guaranteed.
EDITORS NOTE: John Diamond is a Washington-based New England regional reporter for The Associated Press.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.HEAD: Dingell Says Submarine Contractor Impeding Fraud Probe
DOC.TEXT: A House committee chairman charged on Saturday that the manufacturer of the Navy's new $1.2 billion guided-missile destroyer is hampering congressional investigators examining allegations of contract fraud. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., said the Bath Iron Works of Bath, Maine, has refused to provide the congressional General Accounting Office with documents or allow investigators to interview employees unless the GAO promises to withhold the information from Congress. Dingell, in a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, said it was time the Navy got tough with the contractor. ``The Navy appears to be coddling Bath rather than protecting the public's interest,'' Dingell wrote. A copy of the four-page letter, dated May 2, was obtained by The Associated Press. A spokesman for Bath Iron Works said Saturday the company has cooperated with the GAO and the Defense Contract Audit Agency, which are looking into the allegations by Dingell and those made anonymously through a whistleblowers' hotline. ``Mr. Dingell's letter contains no new allegations that we've heard about,'' said Jim McGregor, the company's spokesman. Dingell, the chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, has been highly critical of the Navy's plans to buy 33 of the DDG-51 destroyers at a cost of about $30 billion. Dingell has questioned the survivability of the ship and its sophisticated Aegis weapons system against missile attack and alleged that the Navy's contract with Bath is a ``procurement nightmare'' of fraud and abuse. The destroyer, called the Arleigh Burke class after the World War II naval hero and former chief of naval operations, is designed with an all-steel superstructure and will be equipped with Tomahawk cruise missiles. The Pentagon, as part of its budget-cutting efforts and rethinking of the Soviet threat to the West, may scale back the program. In his letter to Cheney, Dingell said Bath had violated the Pentagon regulation that all contractor employees fill out their time cards in ink to avoid supervisors directing them to mischarge. ``None of the yard workers at Bath Iron Works fill out their own time cards _ they are filled out by their supervisors who also have responsibility for the budgets,'' Dingell said. ``This is an outrage _ it violates every principle of responsible internal controls and makes it virtually impossible to audit for mischarging,'' he said. The Defense Contract Audit Agency, in an effort to prevent mischarging, conducts surprise floor checks in which investigators question employees on what they are working on and compare that to the job they are charging their time. According to Dingell, however, the Navy and Bath Iron Works reached an agreement that required the DCAA to give the company 24-hour notice before a floor check. Dingell said that despite the limitation, investigators found an employee who submitted two time cards, both of which were accepted by the company; a part-time employee who recorded 40 hours of work although he only worked 25 hours; and an employee who charged his time to a cost-reimbursable contract when he admitted to investigators he worked on a fixed-price contract. ``The preliminary DCAA audits have indicated that there is substance to virtually all of the anonymous allegations of mischarging and defective pricing,'' Dingell said. Bath spokesman McGregor disputed the congressman's claims. ``Bath Iron Works never intentionally mischarged anything on any of its contracts with the Navy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Gordon Calls for Investigation of New Telephone Game
DOC.TEXT: ``The Game,'' a million-dollar telephone trivia quiz promoted as ``a direct line to the American dream'' may violate interstate gambling laws, a Tennessee congressman says. Participants in ``The Game,'' scheduled to start Monday, either lose the $2.99 cost of calling the 900-prefix telephone number or win prizes ranging from $5 to $1 million, says Rep. Bart Gordon. ``Participants in this game are effectively betting $2.99 that they will win money, much as participants in a lottery pay for the chance to win cash,'' Gordon said Friday, calling for a federal investigation into the contest. ``Only one of every 100 participants wins even the $5 prize,'' he said. In ``The Game,'' produced by the Los Angeles-based 900 Million Productions, contestants call in and compete with as many as nine other callers to be the first to answer a trivia question. The winner gets a toll-free number to call to compete with other first-round winners for a $5 prize. Second round winners proceed to a third round with $100 prizes. The winner of seven rounds is supposed to win $1 million, which gives contestants odds of one in 10 million, said Kent Syler, a spokesman for the Democrat. Gordon sent a letter to Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Friday asking for an investigation into whether the game requires skill or dumb luck, said Kent Syler, administrative assistant for Gordon. Syler said the only skill required by the game would be the dexterity of contestants' fingers in pressing the numbers on the telephone. ``It is, at best, borderline gambling,'' Syler said. ``I can't think of another opportunity a person has to pay a fee and win some money.'' Not so, said Rhonda Brauer of Hill and Knowlton Inc. in Los Angeles, who is handling public relations for ``The Game.'' ``It's definitely a game of skill and knowledge _ and speed,'' she said. ``It is not a game of chance.'' She did say the questions are based on common knowledge. ``You have to be knowledgeable about things in the United States like how many keys are there on a piano,'' she said. There are 88 keys. ``The Game'' was developed by Allen Koss, who produced such television game shows as ``Tic Tac Dough,'' ``Concentration'' and ``The Joker's Wild.'' While contestants can play ``The Game'' at any time, May 20 is the first date the company will give away the million-dollar prize, officials say, and other millionaires will be made every second Sunday thereafter. ``Only in America is it possible to win $1 million from the privacy of home,'' said Lynn Folse, vice president of 900 Million Productions. ``For the first time, people can use their touch-tone phones for a direct line to the American dream.''

DOC.HEAD: Former President Withdraws From National Party After More Than 50 Years
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Dissatisfied with the changing policies of the government, former president P.W. Botha has withdrawn from the National Party that he served for more than 50 years, a newspaper reported Saturday. The Afrikaans-language newspaper Rapport said Botha, who resigned last August after 11 years in power, was upset with the wide-ranging reforms introduced by his successor, F.W. de Klerk. Botha declined to renew his membership in the governing party when it expired recently, Rapport said. The newspaper said Botha was angry that the African National Congress delegation that met with the government Wednesday through Friday included Joe Slovo, who also is the head of the South African Communist Party. While in office, Botha said that he would never consider the possibility of a black government in South Africa. He also said he would never negotiate with the ANC while it continued to pursue its guerrilla campaign. Since his departure in August, De Klerk has freed leading black nationalist Nelson Mandela, legalized the ANC, pledged to dismantle apartheid and negotiate a new constitution that includes the country's 28-million black majority. Last week's talks were the first ever between the government and the ANC since the congress was formed in 1912. Both sides agreed to try to end the country's ``climate of violence'' and work toward negotiations on a new constitution. Botha, 73, was a staunch anti-communist throughout his political career, which began in the 1930s when he dropped out of college to begin working for the Nationalists. He won a seat in Parliament in the 1948 election that brought the National Party to power. The Nationalists began codifying apartheid legislation shortly afterward and have governed South Africa continuously for the past 42 years. He became prime minister in 1978 and then president in 1984 under a new constitution. Botha, known for his thundering temper, was credited with instituting limited race reforms in the early 1980s. But after nationwide unrest erupted in 1984, he relied increasingly on the security forces to crack down on anti-apartheid activists. Botha suffered a stroke in January 1989. He returned to office several weeks later, but clashed repeatedly with his Cabinet. He resigned in August following a dispute. Since then, Botha has remained out of public view and has not had any contact with his former colleagues, according to government sources.

DOC.HEAD: Allies: Unification Should Go Forward; Soviets Oppose German NATO Membership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To UPDATE with further comment from Shevardnadze, U.S. official on NATO membership, SUB grafs 11-12 pvs, bgng, `Shevardnadze said...' with 7 grafs; pickup 13th graf pvs, `The meeting...'; DELETES grafs 26-27 pvs, `But he ...' to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BON1,5,9,11,13
DOC.TEXT: The four World War II allies agreed Saturday that German unification should go forward without delay, and they shied away from imposing restraints on what will be Europe's most powerful nation. ``The Cold War is over. Our planet, the world, Europe, are now embarking on a new road,'' Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said after the nearly seven-hour meeting. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher read a declaration by the nations that set a timetable for further talks, with a session in June in Berlin, in July in Paris and in September in Moscow. It was the first top-level unification session among the Germanys and the Allies _ the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France _ which split Germany into two countries 45 years ago. The diplomats also agreed to invite Polish Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski to the Paris session, when border issues will be discussed, Genscher said. Poland has expressed fears over possible German claims to territory that belonged to Germany before World War II, and Poland will have the right to address all related issues, the declaration said. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, appearing at a joint news conference with the other diplomats after the meeting, emphasized that Germans of the new nation should make their own decisions. Otherwise, he said, the Allies would be ``planting seeds of future instability.'' Asked about such touchy issues as the size of a new German army and how close it might be deployed to Poland and the Soviet Union, he said: ``Ultimately, the fundamental decision with respect to any nation's military forces is going to be up to that nation.'' Genscher reiterated a pledge that the new nation would renounce nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. But he also rebuffed continued Soviet objections to NATO membership for a united Germany, the main sticking point in the talks. Shevardnadze repeated in statement Friday that a solution was possible. ``I'm optimistically inclined,'' he said. ``I think we shall succeed on all of these matters in finding mutually acceptable solutions. That is the premise upon which we proceed.'' ``Are there any serious divergences? I don't think we should dramatize. This is normal around negotiations,'' he said. ``The Soviet delegation, the Soviet leadership, intend to work constructively in order to accelerate the vitally important historical process of building German unity.'' A senior U.S. official said during a briefing later, however, that during the meeting Shevardnadze reiterated Soviet opposition to NATO membership. The foreign minister said it would be ``difficult for the Soviet people to accept and create an imbalance in Europe,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told reporters the Western allies did not want Moscow to feel its security interests were being neglected. However, he added that ``at the end of the day, it's not of course for them (the Soviets) to decide'' whether a united Germany is a member of NATO. The meeting was held behind closed doors in the West German Foreign Ministry. Baker set the tone in a speech that said the work of the four powers should be limited to relinquishing their 45 years of control over Berlin, the old German capital. ``We face the challenge of rising above the past,'' he said in comments distributed to reporters before the meeting. ``We engage in an act of reconciliation _ of a people too long separated, of a continent too long divided.'' According to a British official who briefed reporters on the condition of anonymity, Shevardnadze ``accepted entirely the self-determination of the German people.'' Neither Shevardnadze nor Baker dwelled on Germany's Nazi past. ``We don't want a discussion on obsolete views,'' the British official quoted Shevardnadze as saying. Genscher emphasized in his opening remarks that there were ``difficult problems'' to solve. ``If we are all willing not only to defend our own interests but also to respect the interests of our partners, then we will find solutions.'' He cited the Helsinki Final Act regulating relations among European countries in his rebuff of Moscow's stance against a unified Germany joining NATO. ``The Final Act emphasizes quite distinctly that all principles are of primary significance,'' Genscher said. ``In this connection, I refer to the principle of sovereign equality, which gives all participating states the right to be or not to be a party to treaties of alliance.'' ``Since we know that the Western alliance, adapting itself as it does to the changes in Europe, brings about peace and security, a free-standing united Germany would be of no benefit to Europe,'' he added. The Soviets have called for a neutral Germany, while Shevardnadze was quoted last month as favoring a ``non-aligned'' Germany. Baker acknowledged that other nations have ``legitimate interests'' that may need to be addressed, a reference to the Soviet Union, which lost more than 20 million people to the Nazi invaders. Baker said the new Germany should not extend beyond the borders of what are now East Germany, West Germany and Berlin. Genscher has said a united Germany will be in NATO, but he also has offered to let the Soviets keep some of their troops in what is now East Germany for a transitional period. About 250,000 U.S. troops are stationed in West Germany, with an estimated 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Democracy Becoming New Goal of International Lending
DOC.TEXT: Governments and bankers are finding a new goal for lending billions of dollars internationally every year: the promotion of democracy. This is a sharp departure the traditional political neutrality of banks, although that tradition is gradually being honored more in the breach than in the observance. The World Bank, whose largest stockholder is the United States, has not made loans in recent years to Nicaragua or Vietnam. After the bloody Chinese suppression last year of student demonstrators, the United States arranged for $720 million in World Bank loans to be suspended. Of the 152 governments that own the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, 30 of them will be owners of the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The United States will be the largest single stockholder in the new $12 billion bank when arrangements are completed. That is expected to happen May 30 in Paris. ``The purpose of the bank shall be to... promote private and entrepreneurial initiative in the Central and Eastern European countries committed to and applying the principles of multiparty democracy, pluralism and market economics,'' says the first of its Articles of Agreement. That is a long journey from the ancient Roman proverb, ``Money has no smell.'' And the World Bank's own Articles of Agreement say: ``The Bank and its officers shall not interfere in the political affairs of any member; nor shall they be influenced in their decisions by the political character of the member or members concerned.'' Members of the World Bank do include both communist and non-communist governments. The World Bank estimates total lending to Third World countries at $1.3 trillion. Some of the leaders of those countries are communists, others are authoritarians with other ideologies. And there appear to be limits to how far the bank will go in rewarding ideology. World Bank President Barber Conable, an American, took issue with a statement last week by Herman Cohen, assistant secretary of State for Africa. Cohen predicted that in the not-too-distant future the United States will make progress toward democracy a condition for aid. ``I don't know what Mr. Cohen may have meant when he said that political conditionality was a desirable force,'' Conable said. ``We, obviously, respect democracy and support it but so far as our development work is concerned, it's based on economic criteria.''

DOC.HEAD: Reputed Cali Cartel Leader Interrupts Trial to Plead Guilty
DOC.TEXT: The reputed No. 3 man in Colombia's Cali drug cartel and an associate pleaded guilty to federal drug charges two weeks into their trial, after a defense attorney concluded the government had ``an unbeatable case.'' Luis Santacruz Echeverri, accused of handling the U.S. end of shipments, pleaded guilty to 49 counts; Guillermo Penagos, reputedly his top lieutenant, admitted to 30 charges, court officials said Friday. Jose Quinon, Santacruz's attorney, said he advised his client to make the plea after details of the government's case came out. ``It was an unbeatable case, very well put together,'' Quinon said. In exchange for the pleas, the government agreed to drop the most serious count, operating a continuing criminal enterprise, which carryies a mandatory life prison sentence. As it is, the charges they pleaded to Thursday carry a minimum term of 10 years and a maximum of life imprisonment. Their trial had been expected to last another month. ``Echeverri's as big an active doper as we've ever gotten,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Howard Vick Jr. ``This disrupts their U.S. operation.'' John Fernandes, spokesman for the Drug Enforcement Administration, said, ``Echeverri's a mover and shaker, and he is very trusted in South America. You don't easily replace him.'' The case against Santacruz blossomed with the seizure of 2{ tons of cocaine at a Chicago produce market. The Colombian cocaine had arrived in Miami aboard a Honduran freighter and had been trucked to the Chicago warehouse. Hotel and airline records placed Santacruz and Penagos in Chicago when the cocaine arrived, signaling that leaders of Colombia's lesser known cartel were overseeing shipments personally. Santacruz, who has had homes in Miami since 1983, was known to the DEA as the U.S. coordinator of the cartel's smuggling operations. Federal agents say his half-brother Jose Santacruz Londono is co-leader of the cartel based in Cali, Colombia. Luis Santacruz was arraigned behind bars last July at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center southwest of Miami because of fears that fellow traffickers would try to either kidnap or assassinate him. The trial was before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler, who also is handling the drug trial of deposed Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Whale Shark Freed From Fisherman's Net
DOC.TEXT: A team of divers and a naturalist rescued a rare giant whale shark that became entangled in fishing nets in the Gulf of Aqaba on Saturday, Israel army radio reported. ``We had to get him out of the net, but you have to remember that this was an 8-meter (26-foot) shark, so it wasn't exactly like taking taking a fly out of a net,'' said Roni Zilber, a member of the Nature Preserve Society who helped cut the shark free. ``Since this shark is an endangered species, we are very interested that it continue to swim in the Gulf of Aqaba,'' he said on army radio, adding that it was caught by mistake. The shark weighed about 1,500 pounds and that its appearance near the town of Eilat was a rare phenomenon, he said. The fisherman who caught the shark immediately notified nature officials when he discovered it in his nets. The whale shark is a harmless plankton feeder and can grow to 50 feet. It is the largest in the shark species.

DOC.HEAD: Czech City Rediscovers Its Liberation By U.S. Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf to restore dropped zero in the number of visitors expected.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PLS01
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Czechs joined U.S. veterans Saturday for a sun-kissed streetfest in the first celebration ever of the liberation of this beer-brewing city by American troops in World War II. Pubs were turned into imitations of Wild West saloons, and youths with American Army paraphernalia rode the streets on vintage Harley-Davidson motorcycles inherited from their parents. Up to 150,000 visitors were expected to descend on Pilsen, a city of 130,000, on Sunday, when President Vaclav Havel and U.S. Ambassador Shirley Temple Black were to preside over the close of the two-day celebration. Gen. George C. Patton's 3rd Army liberated Pilsen on May 6, 1945, just three days before World War II ended in Prague. By agreement with the Soviets, American troops came to a halt at the demarcation line cutting southwest through Czech territory, leaving the Red Army to conquer the Czechoslovak capital. ``Boy, everybody wanted to go on to Prague and get it over with,'' said Cpl. Ross Johnston, 75, an attorney from Zanesville, Ohio. ``But we had to stop here, wait for two weeks and then we were pulled out.'' The Communists barred any commemoration of the U.S. liberation of about 3,600 miles of Czechoslovak territory and marked May 5 as a day of liberation by Soviet troops. Six months after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution in December, however, the atmosphere in this grim industrial city had changed remarkably. American flags adorned the former bastions of Communist officials, and scores of U.S. veterans were in town for the celebration. Tens of thousands of people turned out Saturday morning to see the ceremonial inauguration of a monument to the 2nd Infantry Divison on Pilsen's downtown Republic Square. Those who lived long enough to see the return of Patton's men still remember the postwar atmosphere. ``It felt so right that our town was freed from the Nazis by a western army,'' Frantisek Kotva, a pensioner, mused over a mug of the city's famous beer. ``We all loved the GIs, but then we had to forget about them for a long time,'' he said, alluding to the four decades of Communist suppression that followed. Elsewhere in Czechoslovakia, the occasion was marked with quieter ceremonies. Ambassador Temple Black joined Jan Urban, the leader of the Civic Forum movement that led the revolution against the Communists, at the unveiling of a memorial to the U.S. Army in Vitejovice, about 70 miles southwest of Prague. A similar plaque was unveiled in the nearby town of Chodov. In Lipnik and Bevcou, crowds gathered to remember Martin Zeberski, a U.S. pilot killed there in August 1944. Havel and Temple Black will lead Sunday's festivities in Pilsen, which were to begin with a morning ceremony at the demarcation line and end with a ``country ball.'' ``I've been to several similar events, but this is much bigger than any of us expected,'' Johnston said. ``If the very president of the United States came here in person, he could not be shown more courtesy and respect than we were.''

DOC.HEAD: Weizsaecker Concludes Visit Aimed at Calming Polish Fears
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German President Richard von Weizsaecker went sightseeing Saturday, the last day of his unprecedented visit designed to calm Polish fears about German unification. During four days of official meetings and informal visits, Weizsaecker repeatedly assured Poles that a united Germany would respect Poland's borders and wants to contribute to an ``integrated Europe,'' not dominate it. Adam Michnik, a leading Polish thinker, wrote in Saturday's pro-Solidarity Gazeta Wyborcza that the Weizsaecker visit, the first to Poland by a West German head of state, will bring a new perspective to bilateral ties. ``A lot depends on Polish-German relations, especially stability in the heart of Europe,'' Michnik said. ``It is not enough to be afraid of Germans.'' ``From this time on, we must take up Polish-German problems at a different, higher level,'' he said. Weizsaecker ended his visit sightseeing at the birthplace of the 18th century German philosopher and writer Gottfried Herder in Morag, and at a museum for the astronomer Copernicus in Frombork. He planned to return Saturday to Bonn, where the foreign ministers of both Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies were holding talks on German unification. Poland has sought a role in the talks to press its security concerns, especially the permanence of its postwar western border, drawn along the Oder and Neisse rivers to include territory from defeated Germany. The rush toward German unification has been received with concern in Poland, where the prospect of a resurgent economic and political power next door stirs memories of Germany's World War II aggression. ``The distance between our nations is diminishing, but in order to eliminate it completely, we should learn well the ... layers of distrust between us,'' Weizsaecker told students at Gdansk University Friday. Michnik wrote that Poland, as it struggles to transform its Communist political and economic system, can learn from the West German experience. ``It is not enough to feed one's conscience with the memory of martyrs, and it is absolutely not enough to reduce the interest to the Oder and Neisse border,'' he said. ``The Federal Republic of Germany belongs among the most democratic states and we should know more about how the Federal Republic was formed and the welfare of Germans was ensured,'' he said. Michnik, a key opposition activist before Solidarity toppled Poland's Communist regime last year, said there are parallels between Germany and Poland. He said Weizsaecker, a German army officer who participated in the Sept. 1, 1939 invasion of Poland at World War II's start, also has roots in the German political and social groupings from which resistance to Hitler developed. ``This is the German tradition of resistance against a totalitarian system. The tradition of anti-totalitarian resistance is also our root. It is easier to meet in this field,'' Michnik wrote. Weizsaecker began his visit Wednesday, the first of two days of meetings in Warsaw with President Wojciech Jaruzelski, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and other leaders. On Friday, he traveled to Westerplatte, the Baltic penisula where the first shots of World War II sounded when a German ship opened fire on a small Polish garrision. He also met with Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and toured Gdansk, which was occupied and then destroyed by Germany during the war.

DOC.HEAD: Crucial Second Round of Elections in Croatia
DOC.TEXT: A center-right party that wants Croatia to declare its independence from Yugoslavia hopes to win control of the republic's parliament in elections Sunday and Monday. The Croatian Democratic Union won 104 of the 131 seats in the republic's 356-seat, three-house parliament in the first round of voting April 22-23. The remaining 225 seats are to be decided in the balloting that begins Sunday, and initial results are not expected until Monday afternoon. There was no campaigning Saturday, which was mandated a ``day of silence'' in the race for the republic's first free elections in 50 years. Political observers believe that another victory for the Democratic Union and its leader, Franjo Tudjman, a retired army general once imprisoned for almost five years for nationalism, will intensify the split between Croatia and Serbia. The two are the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics and have been fierce rivals since the country was created in 1918. Serbia indicated Friday it may follow Croatia and its northern neighbor, Slovenia, in holding free elections in the next six months. But a victory by pro-independence forces in Croatia would likely bolster the Serbian Communists, who advocate a centralized Yugoslavia and have used nationalism to help keep a firm grip on power in their republic. Yugoslavia already has two distinctly different political systems. There is one-party Communist rule in Serbia and multiparty politics in Croatia and Slovenia. In free parliamentary elections last month in Slovenia, the republic's reform Communists were defeated, but their popular leader, Milan Kucan, won the presidency. Croatia's reform-minded Communist Party, renamed the Party for Democratic Reform, won only 13 seats in the first round of elections, and the centrist Coalition for National Accord won just three. Tudjman, who ran his Western-style campaign under the slogan ``Croatia belongs to the Croatians,'' has expressed confidence his party will cap its initial victory and that the new parliament will elect him president. ``We need the second-round victory, after which we will devote ourselves to the construction of new Croatia,'' he said. Tudjman believes Yugoslavia's six republics should be independent states and establish relations with each other only if common interests are involved. Croatia's reform Communists are more cautious. They say the current federation is fine for now. If it fails to meet Croatia's needs in the future, however, they say Yugoslavia should become a confederation without central rule. Serbia's media, strongly influenced by the Communist Party, call Tudjman a secessionist or sometimes even a fascist. Croatia's 450,000 Serb minority, which faced mass extermination in the Croatian puppet state set up by Nazi Germany, recently staged several rallies denouncing Tudjman's ideas. Serbs in Croatia say they would demand full autonomy for the regions where they live if his party wins the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Five Rockets Blast Kabul, Killing One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: One word cq for Najibullah
DOC.TEXT: Five rockets slammed into the Afghan capital of Kabul on Saturday, killing one person and wounding three people, Radio Kabul reported. The rocket attack occured a day after Afghan President Najibullah lifted a 15-month-old state of emergency. The radio broadcast, monitored in Islamabad, blamed the attack on ``Pakistan-based extremists,'' apparently referring to U.S.-backed rebels. No one claimed responsibility for the attack. Afghan guerrillas, headquartered in Pakistan and Iran, have been fighting for 12 years to topple the Soviet-style government in Kabul. The United States sends the seven major rebel groups in Pakistan about $500 million annually in military supplies. Moscow provides about $5 billion a year to its allies in Kabul, according to Western diplomats in Islamabad. Soviet troops entered Afghanistan in December 1979 at the invitation of the pro-Soviet government of Babrak Karmal. By the start of 1988 _ before Moscow agreed to withdraw troops _ some 103,000 Soviet troops and about 50,000 Afghan army troops were pitted against some 200,000 guerrillas. The Soviets withdrew the last of their troops in February 1989, but Moscow said military advisers would remain. Up to 15,000 Soviet troops were killed during the intervention. The State Department says exact Afghan casualties are unavailable, but it says there were 1 million Afghan deaths. There are a total of about 5 million refugees, of whom about 3 million are in Pakistan and 1.9 million in Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Warrants Served to Confiscate $17 Million in South Florida Bank Accounts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that `Operation Polar Cap' is lengthy investigation sted launched three three weeks ago.
DOC.TEXT: Federal drug agents served warrants to confiscate $17.6 million in South Florida financial institutions as a nationwide drug money laundering crackdown focuses on suspicious accounts, a spokesman said Saturday. Federal officials froze $400 million in more than 750 accounts nationally three weeks ago as part of the long-running Operation Polar Cap. Investigators have been working to pin down the origin of the funds, said Drug Enforcement Administration spokesman John Fernandes. The seizure warrants served Friday in South Florida, covering $17.6 million, were for accounts in which investigators have concluded that there was ``probable cause'' to believe the money was drug proceeds, Fernandes said Saturday. He said he didn't have any detail on what seizure orders might have been issued in other parts of the country. The warrants were served on bank officers for 72 accounts at 20 South Florida banks _ a legal step in the process of transferring the suspected drug cartel money to federal coffers. In all, accounts had been frozen in 78 Miami banks. The government also could prosecute bankers and the account holders after tracing the money, Fernandes said. ``If we show complicity on the part of a bank or bank official or some representative of a corporation or a front corporation or what have you, that would be a separate part of the civil action,'' the DEA spokesman said. Meanwhile, the account holders are preparing to fight the freezing or loss of funds, with some arguing they were involved in ``flight capital'' _ sending of assets from troubled foreign countries to the United States _ and not money laundering. ``It's the only way people in Colombia can have dollars in the United States to avoid inflation and other problems with the Colombian economy,'' said Fred Schwartz, an attorney for a Colombian industrialist with $600,000 in frozen accounts. Schwartz and other attorneys say their clients bought dollars in Latin America on the black market _ a huge pot of money swelled by the cocaine trade _ without knowing the cash was drug-tainted. The money then was transferred to U.S. accounts, often in violation of currency laws abroad, as a cushion against the vagaries of Latin American economics and politics. Javier Murcio, a flight capital expert with DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., consulting firm, said the DEA seizures ``must induce some nervousness on the part of these individuals.'' But he doubted flight capital would be driven from Miami banks because of the enforcement, saying, ``People who are going to take it out of their countries will always do so regardless of the circumstances.'' Fernandes indicated the seizure warrants covered some drug money that was laundered through foreign currency black markets before it was deposited in U.S. banks. ``I wouldn't want to stereotype it,'' he said. ``Playing with the black market is only one way of getting the (drug) money through. The technology used is only limited to the imagination of the money launderers.'' The Justice Department obtained a court order April 16 in Atlanta to freeze accounts in 173 banks in 22 states after investigators estimated Colombia's Medellin cartel amassed $1.2 billion from cocaine sales from 1987 to early 1989. Federal officials believe $400 million was returned to the United States to support drug trafficking.

DOC.HEAD: Double-Header of Masterpieces Opening at National Gallery
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 16th graf pvs, bgng: Brown ducked, to CORRECT spelling of van Gogh, Gauguin; SUBS penultimate graf, The Buehrle, to include closing date
DOC.TEXT:
Nearly 140 masterpieces from two formidable family collections, including a celebrated, $40.7 million self-portrait by Pablo Picasso, are going on display Sunday at the National Gallery of Art. Opening in the gallery's modernistic East Building is the first and only U.S. exhibition of 85 old masters, impressionists, post-impressionists and early modern works from the collection of the late Swiss industrialist, Emil G. Buehrle. Appearing simultaneously in the gallery's West Building is the entire collection of 54 paintings, watercolors and drawings from the home of millionaire publisher Walter H. Annenberg in Rancho Mirage, Calif., shown together for the first time on a national tour that began last summer in Philadelphia. Gallery director J. Carter Brown called the twin exhibitions ``a fabulous double-header'' and said that ``we may never see in our lifetime a concentration of art of such quality and importance.'' First lady Barbara Bush, wearing a white jacket and pearls, attended a gallery reception in Annenberg's honor Wednesday night and toured his collection with Brown as her personal guide. She is said to be an admirer of French impressionist paintings. Brown said the Buehrle exhibit was drawn from 321 works _ many of them rarely seen in public _ that comprise ``one of the greatest private collections to have been created in the 20th century.'' The 38 Italian, Dutch, French and Spanish artists represented in the show range from Frans Hals and Francisco Goya to impressionists Edouard Manet, Camille Pissarro, Edgar Degas, Paul Cezanne, Claude Monet, Paul Gauguin and Vincent van Gogh. Among the 20th century masters in the exhibit, titled ``The Passionate Eye: Impressionist and Other Master Paintings from the Collection of Emil G. Buehrle,'' are Henri Matisse, Georges Braque, Picasso, Franz Marc and Wassily Kandinsky. Brown said Annenberg, a philanthropist, publisher and former U.S. ambassador to Britain, and his wife, Leonore, had ``assembled one of the world's greatest private collections of impressionist and post-impressionist art.'' The National Gallery show includes three recent Annenberg acquisitions that did not appear in the Philadelphia exhibit, Braque's ``The Studio,'' Henri Fantin-Latour's ``Asters and Fruit on a Table'' and the Picasso self-portrait, ``Au Lapin Agile.'' Annenberg bought the 1905 Picasso painting at Sotheby's in New York last November for $40.7 million, the third most expensive artwork ever sold at auction. Since he sold his publishing empire to Rupert Murdoch for $3 billion in 1988, the 82-year-old collector has accelerated his art purchases amid intense speculation over the eventual fate of his masterpieces. If Annenberg leaves his collection to a museum, the National Gallery is considered a likely candidate, along with the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and possibly the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
Brown ducked a reporter's question last week about the National Gallery's chances of acquiring the Annenberg collection, which includes eight Cezannes, five van Goghs, six Monets and other paintings by Degas, Gauguin, Matisse and Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The show also includes an Annenberg portrait by Andrew Wyeth and a montage by Romare Bearden of the ``Roots'' television miniseries that Annenberg commissioned for the cover of TV Guide. Americans will never have another chance to view the Buehrle collection after its current world tour, unless they travel to the family home in Zurich, Switzerland. When the tour ends, the family says it will retire the collection from international lending. The Buehrle show, underwritten by Martin Marietta Corp., will remain until July 15. It also will appear at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts, Aug. 3 through Oct. 14; the Yokohama Museum of Art in Japan, Nov. 2 to Jan. 13, 1991; and the Royal Academy of Arts in London, Feb. 1 to April 14. ``Masterpieces of Impressionism and Post-Impressionism: The Annenberg Collection'' will appear at the National Gallery through Aug. 5, and at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art from Aug. 16 through Nov. 11. It will appear at New York's Metropolitan Museum next summer. The exhibition is underwritten by the GTE Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow Continues Toward Ocean After Cutting Off Village Access
DOC.TEXT: Lava from Kilauea Volcano cut off the last road out of this coastal community Saturday and nearly encircled the town's store and a church. Part of the lava flow was headed toward an area of sand dunes about 225 yards from the ocean, according to Hawaii County Civil Defense spokesman Bruce Butts. Another finger of lava was headed toward a park and was about 50 yards from the park boundary, he said. The Kalapana Store and Drive-Inn, the community's meeting place, and the Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church still were standing although nearly encircled by lava, Butts said. Lava was filling a gulley behind the two buildings in the heart of the village and was expected to eventually reach them, he said. The blazing hot lava has destroyed a total of 134 homes, including 50 in the past month, since Kilauea's east rift zone began erupting on Jan. 3, 1983. The historic Star-of-the-Sea Catholic Church, known for its brightly painted murals, was moved to higher ground Friday before lava cut off the escape route. Members of the Congregational church earlier decided not to move their church, partly because of termite damage. ``If it's God's will that the building goes go, it's His will,'' said church moderator Bernice McKeague. Officials were concerned about a possible health threat when the hot lava reaches the ocean's salt water, because that produces steam clouds, known as laze, containing hydrochloric acid and other potentially hazardous chemicals. ``Our main concern is the tradewinds,'' Butts said. ``As long as there are tradewinds, the laze will be blown away. ``If winds shift, our concern mainly will be for the command post and the people on the barricades,'' he said. ``We will play it by ear, and watch the wind situation, but if there is a wind shift, we may have to move people.'' U.S. Rep. Daniel Akaka, recently named to the U.S. Senate to succeed the late Spark Matsunaga, attended a service with members of the Congregational church Friday. He said he hopes federal aid will be approved, possibly within the next week. He said he met with visiting representatives of the Federal Emergency Management Agency before they returned to Washington.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Claims Responsibility For Failed Bomb Attack In Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility Saturday for planting plastic explosives outside the British army barracks in Hanover, West Germany, in an intended attack foiled by a civilian and his German shephard. In a statement to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, the IRA said: ``A number of devices containing a substantial amount of plastic explosives were placed inside the base after an active service unit penetrated the security fencing.'' An unarmed civilian dog handler with his German shepherd broke up the attack early Friday when he spotted three men who had cut a hole in a fence at Langenhagen barracks. He challenged the men, who fled after firing four shots at him. Seventy soldiers with the 1st Postal and Courier Regiment of the Royal Engineers, who were sleeping in the barracks at the time, were immediately ordered out. The barracks are only about 75 feet from the perimeter fence. West German forensic experts examined the four bullets fired by the terrorists. Dr. Hans-Jurgen Forster, spokesman for the West German federal prosecutor, said they came from a AK-47 semi-automatic rifle, ``a classic IRA weapon.'' West German investigators confirmed that the explosives used in the attack were Czechslovakian-made Semtex. A total of 104.5 pounds were planted in two olive green rucksacks placed close to the barracks building, they said. The IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the mainly Protestant province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic under a socialist government.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Captive Says Kidnappers Treated Him Well in Final Months
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 16th and 17th grafs, ``He has been xxx with Peggy Say saying that discussions about her brother, hostage Terry Anderson, delayed until next week.
DOC.TEXT: Freed hostage Frank Reed pronounced himself in good health Saturday, saying ``I'm beautiful, I'm OK.'' He said his kidnappers ``treated me fine'' the last six months of his captivity and joked that ``room service was pretty good.'' His doctors said they were pleased with how he looked even though his weight had dropped from about 185 pounds to about 140 now. ``Our early evaluations are good,'' said Brig. Gen. Robert W. Poel, commander of the Malcolm Grow Air Force Medical Center. Reed, in a telephone interview with The Associated Press, said he was looking forward to going home to Malden, Mass., on Tuesday or Wednesday for the first time in eight years to see his 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague, for the ``real celebration of success.'' The town north of Boston is planning a big celebration for him and residents already have started hanging out yellow ribbons on homes and buildings. But Poel, at a news conference, said he would be surprised if Reed left by Wednesday and that his departure would not be until the end of the week ahead at the earliest. ``Maybe a day or two shorter or a day or two longer,'' he added. In the interview, Reed, 57, sounded in high spirits despite being blindfolded and bound much of his more than 3{ years in captivity and his weight loss. He was released last Monday in Beirut by Lebanese kidnappers. ``So far everything is fine,'' he said. He added that he was just getting life-giving muscles and that he needed vitamins. His doctors said they were giving him vitamin supplements. ``Every muscle in my body is completely out of shape,'' Reed said. ``When you stand up, you're going against the force of gravity. I haven't even done that very much.'' ``I've eaten quality food but haven't had much of it,'' he said. ``We used to joke _ John (McCarthy), Brian (Keenan) and I _ that room service was pretty good when we got extra coffee, popcorn or something.'' Reed was held hostage with McCarthy and Keenan at varying times. Poel said Reed was decompressing and it was probably too early to say whether he had any specific problems. ``His laboratory tests all look quite good,'' Poel said. ``He shows a little bit of what you would expect of a man that has been held in captivity for a prolonged period of time. He has lost a great deal of weight. He's also tired. ... He needs to work at recovering his strength.'' Poel said it was too early to make a specific diagnosis of his mental state but that Reed's ``spirits are great. He speaks with vigor and is happy to be where he is. He is incisive. Ask a question and he speaks out. His memory is great.'' Poel said counselors planned to speak with Reed. Reed was being fed nutritional meals and dined on lobster by candlelight Friday night with his wife and two grown daughters by a previous marriage who have been staying with him. Saturday morning he asked for pancakes for breakfast. He has been receiving visitors and on Saturday saw Peggy Say, the sister of Terry Anderson, The Associated Press' chief middle east correspondent and longest held hostage with more than five years in captivity. Reed had spent some time with Anderson in captivity. Ms. Say said that because Reed was obviously exhausted, she put off any in-depth discussions about Anderson until next week. On Sunday, Reed planned to attend a brunch and news conference sponsored by the humanitarian organization No Greater Love. It was to include former hostages held in Lebanon and their families. Among those scheduled to meet with Reed were Keenan's two sisters, Brenda Gillham and Elaine Spence, who arrived from London on Friday night. Keenan, 39, an Irish teacher of English at the American University of Beirut, was kidnapped April 11, 1986. McCarthy, 33, a British television journalist, was kidnapped April 17, 1986. Reed, director of the private Lebanon International School in Beirut, was kidnapped Sept. 9, 1986. He had disclosed earlier that he also he had been held with Thomas Sutherland, an American University of Beirut dean. Reed arrived here Friday aboard an Air Force jetliner from Wiesbaden, West Germany. The two daughters from a previous marriage, Marilyn Langston, 33, and Jacqueline Reed, 28, went aboard the plane for a brief private reunion. Reed's Syrian-born wife, Fahima, known as Fifi, and their 9-year-old son, Tarek, flew with him from Germany. On Friday he thanked his ``fellow Americans'' for still being alive and pleaded for the release of ``my mates left behind'' _ the remaining six Americans and nine other Westerners held by Islamic militants in Lebanon. Robert Polhill, a fellow educator, was released in Beirut just eight days before Reed.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Baker, Shevardnadze and Genscher Comments
With Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts of statements made at Saturday's German unification talks in Bonn, from official texts. The Associated Press translated the remarks of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The remarks of West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher come from the official translation.

Secretary of State James A. Baker III: For we meet in recognition that a historical process is under way: the unification of Germans in peace and freedom. Today, we engage in an act of reconciliation _ of a people too long separated, of a continent too long divided. In helping Germany achieve freedom and unity, I believe all the states and peoples of Europe can be the winners. That should be our aim. That is a vision that looks to the future, not to the past. ... A primary task of this group, therefore will be to arrive at a formula by which we will terminate and transfer all remaining Four Power rights and responsibilities to a fully sovereign Germany _ a Germany united within the territory of the Federal Republic of Germany, the German Democratic Republic, and Berlin. We must focus our efforts on the substance of a final settlement, not on the symbols of the past. ... Unification will have important implications for each of us in our relations with Germany, as well as for Germany's place in the new, evolving European order. The United States recognizes that others among the four (powers) have legitimate interests that may need to be addressed as part of the two-plus-four process. We believe that this forum may be an appropriate place for discussions of such issues, but it is our view that this forum should take decisions only on those issues relevant to Four Power rights and responsibilities.

Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze: We never had earlier _ and happily we never acquired _ any allergy to the aspirations of the German people to unity. We are for the right of Germans to self-determination. We believe that a united Germany enters the family of European peoples as a democratic and peace-loving state. ... Returning to the question of military-political status, I would like to confirm our negative attitude to the membership of a united Germany in NATO ... Such a decision directly touches our security, would signify a brutal violation of the balance of forces in Europe and would create a dangerous military-strategic situation. For us, NATO remains that which it always was _ an antagonistic military bloc.

West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher: Almost 45 years ago to the day a war ended in Europe that claimed countless victims and caused immeasurable suffering. In again expressing our mutual intention, as in the first words of the Helsinki Final Act, `to contribute in Europe to peace, security, justice and cooperation,' we are honoring the victims of war and tyranny. ... Poland's participation in discussions on the border question will point the way for the recognition in international law by the united Germany of Poland's western border. Far-sighted statesmen and courageous peoples have given us the chance to shed the last remnants of the war and postwar period and to determine the architecture of a common European house, the structure of a peaceful European order. ... We have difficult problems to solve. However, if we are all willing not only to defend our interests but also to respect the interests of our partners, then we will find solutions. Our responsibility for the future of Europe demands resolution and a sense of proportion.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Germany Bjt
U.S. Defense Chief Urges Go-Slow Approach to European Missile Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Saturday the United States should delay withdrawal of its short-range nuclear forces in Europe until after the Soviet Union has pulled out its nuclear weapons. President Bush announced Thursday that the administration had abandoned plans to modernize the existing Lance missile, a short-range nuclear missile based in Europe and targeted on East Germany. The collapse of the Warsaw Pact had rendered the missile obsolete and the West Germans and members of the U.S. Congress had opposed plans to upgrade the system. Cheney, in an interview with Cable News Network's ``Newsmaker'' program, said the United States should wait before withdrawing the some 700 now-obsolete missiles and the approximately 1,500 nuclear-tipped artillery shells in Europe. ``Until the Soviets have removed their nuclear forces, short-range nuclear forces, in East Germany, it makes no sense for us to take ours out of West Germany,'' Cheney said in the interview. The Pentagon chief said only when the Soviets remove all their forces from Eastern Europe ``then I think we'll have a high degree of confidence, then we can reduce our own forces.'' Cheney is scheduled to meet this week in Canada with NATO defense ministers and is expected to discuss the issue of short-range nuclear forces. Bush said Thursday that the 16-member NATO alliance should meet in late June or July to consider a political and military strategy. In the interview, Cheney also described his vision of the future U.S. military in Europe that would include fewer Army divisions and greater reliance on reserve forces. In addition, ``you can probably dual-base some of your air squadrons, some of them back here in the United States with bases in Europe that they would move to in wartime,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Widespread Rural Flooding in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 19 grafs to update with Trinity crested, water down only 3 feet in Dallas, CORRECT last week's Texas storm deaths from seven to six, details on Okla. flooding, including isolated county, picking up 15th graf previous, ``High water.''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR1
DOC.TEXT: Flooding closed highways and forced scores of people from their homes Saturday in Oklahoma, Arkansas and Texas, and the high water from last week's heavy rain crumbled levees and threatened at least one dam. ``There's water, water everywhere,'' said Gary Talley, spokesman for the Arkansas Office of Emergency Services. ``To say we have extensive flooding is pretty accurate and it's only going to get worse.'' Texas emergency officials evacuated more than a dozen families in two rural counties south of Dallas overnight as levees along the Trinity River were washed out by record high water. The river at Trinidad, about 60 miles southeast of Dallas, was receding slowly after rising to almost 20 feet over the flood stage of 28 feet early Saturday, Henderson County emergency management coordinator Travis Roberts said. Trinidad police dispatcher Delois Langford said Trinidad and nearby Malakoff were not expected to be flooded, although 10 families were evacuated from an area near the river. The Trinity crested at Dallas on Thursday, forcing hundreds from their homes. Many were still out of their homes Saturday as the river began to recede slowly there. At midday Saturday, the river at Dallas had fallen only 3 feet and was still 14 feet above flood stage. Texas' death toll from last week's storms rose to six. A total of 12 Texas deaths have been blamed on the weather in the past weeks. More than 60 southeastern Oklahoma highways were under water Saturday and the number was expected to significantly increase as more water was released from overfilled reservoirs. In far eastern Oklahoma, the dam on Lake Frances on the Arkansas border threatened to break, which would send a torrent of water downstream into Flint Creek, Ark., and other small towns. A large chunk of the dam washed away Friday, and giant cracks appeared in the remaining concrete as the dam shifted 6 to 8 feet. About 100 downstream residents were evacuated, but were allowed to return as the water level behind the dam continued to fall. ``The worst conditions at Lake Frances have passed pending further flooding from future rain,'' said Harold Springer of the Oklahoma Water Resources Board. Along the Texas-Oklahoma border, Lake Texoma was almost 4 feet above its spillway Saturday, with about 30 mobile homes and 24 permanent structures under water around the huge lake. The Army Corps of Engineers was releasing as much as 126,000 cubic feet per second from Texoma, but Corps spokesman Edward Engelke said the reservoir still wouldn't crest until Monday, possibly at 5 feet above the spillway. The previous record was 3 feet. Lakeshore resident Jerry Russell spent Friday filling sand bags. ``I drew three chalk lines up my driveway,'' Russell said. ``The first was for worry, the second panic, and the third, for sale.'' Lake Texoma's rising water cut off all but one two-lane road connecting Marshall County, Okla., to the rest of the world Saturday. Some 200 Marshall County residents had been displaced but no injuries were reported. Between 25 and 30 families were marooned in one residential area, said civil defense director John Martin. ``There's no way in and no way out'' over land, Martin said. The residents, mostly elderly, retired people, don't want to leave. ``You know how it is with some of the elderly, they want to stay there to protect their homes. It's all they've got,'' Martin said. High water from northwestern Arkansas began creeping into low-lying areas of central Arkansas along the bulging Arkansas River on Saturday. Sections of several state highways and other roadways all along the river were under water, and industrial and commercial businesses near the river from Dardanelle 60 miles southeast to Little Rock will be threatened as the water rises slowly toward crests through Wednesday, authorities said. Water was 3 feet deep Saturday on Rogers Avenue, a main thoroughfare at Fort Smith, Ark., where the river was expected to crest at 13 feet above the 22-foot flood stage, said Talley of the emergency services office. Residents had evacuated from more than 50 flooded homes in surrounding Sebastian County, he said. Eighteen families were evacuated at the town of Toad Suck in Perry County, where sandbagging operations were halted, and seven families were evacuated in the Lollie Bottoms community near Mayflower, he said. National Guardsmen helped city work crews in sandbagging operations that began about midmorning Saturday in North Little Rock, where water had reached a residential area, said Todd Larson, the city's director of commerce and governmental affairs. Arkansas Gov. Bill Clinton declared 27 counties disaster areas Friday. President Bush declared 12 Texas counties disaster areas Friday. The flooding in the three states was caused by three days of torrential rain that followed an unusually rainy spring. Northern Texas has had 22.06 inches of rainfall in the first four months of 1990, the most since 1922. As much as 7 inches of rain fell within 24 hours in some areas. The Red Cross calculated Friday that more than 2,300 Texas families lost property in floods. More than 700 homes were destroyed and 1,600 others damaged, the Red Cross said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Banker: `If I Say Anything ... I'm Dead'
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's self-described personal banker worried two years ago that he'd be killed if he testified before the U.S. Senate about the Panamanian ruler's financial dealings, a tape recorded conversation shows. ``If I say anything about Noriega and it's reported by the press, I'm dead,'' Amjad Awan said in a secretly recorded tape played Friday in his federal drug money-laundering trial. ``He knows that I know everything.'' The banker, uneasy at being subpoenaed to testify before the Senate in September 1988, said he could trace the flow of the dictator's cash to accounts outside Panama. ``It's a question of money, and I know exactly where he has what,'' Awan unwittingly told an undercover agent. ``And no matter how much he likes me, how much of a friend I am ... when it comes to money, when his back is towards the wall, you know.'' The tape concluded the 15th week of government testimony that Awan, four fellow bankers at the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International and a Colombian laundered cash they knew to be drug proceeds. Awan had no reason to suspect the friend he was chatting with at a plush Miami restaurant was an agent. For more than a year, Awan had helped Robert Musella move large amounts of cash from the United States to secret overseas accounts. Musella, however, was the identity assumed by Drug Enforcement Administration agent Robert Mazur. He told Awan on tapes already played at the trial that the money was coming from some of Colombia's largest cocaine dealers. Awan said he didn't care, that it wasn't up to him to judge the morality of where the money came from. Awan and the other defendants maintain their innocence. The bankers say they were victims of the Luxembourg bank management's passion to expand and attract new capital. Two divisions of the bank _ one of the world's largest private financial institutions, pleaded guilty to money-laundering charges when trial began in January. In a plea bargain, the Luxembourg bank forfeited $15 million in frozen assets and interest. On the tape, Awan is heard questioning how the bank's high-powered Washington lawyer, former Secretary of State Clark Clifford, was handling the Senate subpoena. Awan expressed his fear that Clifford was about to sell him out to protect the Luxembourg bank and Clifford's bank, First American Bank, from scandal. Awan said the Luxembourg bank's board was so anxious to keep him from talking and avoid scandal that it even urged him to get out of the United States, to transfer from his Miami office possibly to Paris. The banker also predicted the bank would duck the subpoena by telling the subcommittee that no Noriega banking records existed in this country and that Noriega wouldn't surrender the bank's records in Panama. Clifford later gave a similar response to Sen. John Kerry, the subcommittee's chairman. Records seized when the bankers were arrested showed at least $600,000 of Noriega's money flowed from Panama to Europe through BCCI accounts at Clifford's Washington bank. Awan told the subcommittee in September 1988 that he once handled $23 million in Noriega's personal accounts and said he deposited money for Noriega in accounts at First American Bank, where Clifford was president. Clifford has denied any involvement by the Luxembourg bank in First American, other than some overlapping shareholders. But on the tape, Awan said the bank owned First American despite a series of shareholders designed to conceal the bank's ownership. ``The truth of the matter is,'' he said, ``the bank belongs to BCCI.''

DOC.HEAD: Wet Over Much Of Eastern Half Of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered over much of the eastern half of the nation Saturday, but rainfall was generally light. At midday, showers extended from south-central Kansas across south-central Nebraska, over north-central Illinois, from Ohio and eastern Kentucky across western Pennsylvania, and from northeastern New York state across northern and central New England. Showers and thunderstorms, some with the potential to become severe, reached from Maryland and Delaware across Virginia, North and South Carolina, much of Georgia, southeastern Alabama, the Florida Panhandle and northwestern Florida. Showers were scattered along the central and lower Texas Gulf Coast. Heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 0.70 of an inch at Massena, N.Y., and 0.50 of an inch at Dothan, Ala., the National Weather Service said. Serious flooding continued in parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas as a result of last week's heavy rain. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 38 at Augusta, Maine, to 101 at El Cajon, Calif. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 28 at Duluth, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Discovery Lands at Sheppard AFB on Trip Back to Florida
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather delayed the space shuttle Discovery here Saturday, partway through its return trip to Florida from California atop a jumbo jet. The shuttle, riding piggyback on NASA's specially equipped Boeing 747, arrived in the afternoon from Edwards Air Force Base in the California desert. The next leg of the flight back to Kennedy Space Center was delayed at least until Sunday because of bad weather farther east, said Sgt. Reed Henderson, spokesman for Sheppard Air Force Base. Discovery landed at Edwards on April 29 after a mission to deploy the Hubble Space Telescope.

DOC.HEAD: Rabin Says He Will Challenge Peres For Party Leadership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, ``The poll...' to CORRECT spelling of Yediot Ahronot newspaper. Pickup pvs 14th graf, `Pollster Mina...'
DOC.TEXT: Former Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said Saturday he will challenge Shimon Peres for leadership of the left-leaning Labor Party, and polls indicated that Rabin could lead the party to victory. A poll published Friday in the mass circulation Yediot Ahronot newspaper showed Rabin defeating caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of the right-wing Likud bloc by a 2-1 margin if direct elections for Israel's leader were held. Israeli voters chose political parties and not candidates, but a campaign to reform the electoral system and institute direct elections has been gaining substantial momentum. Rabin's challenge to party leader Shimon Peres was widely expected after Peres failed to form a coalition government last week, leaving Shamir in a position to head Israel's next government. If Shamir is unable to form a coalition, elections could be held. ``I believe that after a long period and several elections, the time has come to have a soul searching to decide who can lead the party in the next elections with a better chance to win them,'' Rabin said. Asked whether he was a candidate for leadership, Rabin replied: ``I believe that I, or maybe others'' could lead the party. ``I believe that there is a need for change,'' he added. Rabin said a Likud government ``can cause damage to Israel in the fields of the peace process, international relations, in their policies in the (occupied) territories, the settlements.'' Calls for a change in party leadership have been echoed by other Labor legislators and Rabin's popularity seems to be growing within the party and the nation. Rabin served as army chief of staff during the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel seized the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt. He also served as prime minister from 1974 to 1977. He was defense minister in the Likud-Labor joint government from 1984 to March of this year, when Labor collapsed the government to protest Likud's refusal to accept U.S. proposals to advance the peace process. Rabin's tough policy in handling the Palestinian uprising has won him widespread popularity. The poll in the Yediot Ahronot daily, was conducted May 1-2 by the Dahaf agency and showed that 60 percent of the 515 people questioned prefered Rabin for prime minister while only 32 percent chose Shamir. Pollster Mina Zemech said the poll examined the voting preferences of Jews, but excluded settlers and people living on communal farms. She said the margin of error was 4 percent to 5 percent. Also Saturday, Israeli soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian after Arab protesters in a West Bank refugee camp threw stones and a firebomb at troops, the army said. Mohammed Shaker al-Masri, 25, was struck in the heart with a bullet and died at Tulkarum hospital, Arab reports and hospital officials said. Al-Masri's death brought to 682 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 29-month-old rebellion against the occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Forty-three Israelis have also died in the violence. Palestinians have killed about 210 of their fellow Arabs, mainly on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Municipal elections were held in this small northwest Texas town Saturday, but more people were casting bait than ballots. That's because Saturday also was Fish Day. Once a year since the 1920s, everything has shut down as the locals head north to Lake Kemp to cast their lines. Fish Day officially is the first Monday in May, but most folks now stretch it into a three-day weekend. ``It's pretty well deserted, except around the courthouse where the election is going on,'' saidCity Election Secretary Mary Alice Smith. ``And Monday, it will be completely deserted.'' Ms. Smith said the conflict began two years ago when state officials decided local elections should be held on the first Saturday of May. Still, most of Seymour's approximately 3,500 residents manage to make the best of it, she said. Many cast absentee ballots before they head for the lake. And those who stay behind get to share in eating the catch. On the ballot: a sales tax to fund a hospital district.

At Saturday's commencement at the Rhode Island School of Design, 98-year-old Howard A. Trenn, Class of 1915, led the line of about 270 degree recipients. All had been awarded diplomas upon graduating, some as long as 82 years ago, but none had been granted a certified college degree. That's because until 1944, the school wasn't fully accredited. Now it offers the required liberal arts curriculum to make it a full-fledged four-year college. Like Trenn, who had studied mechanical design, most of the pre-accreditation graduates who lined up for honorary degrees Saturday used their schooling to earn their livings in art and design. The oldest living pre-accreditation graduate, painter Mary Crosby, 102 and Class of 1908, was unable to attend. But she was to be given her honorary degree later by school President Thomas F. Schutte. The 113-year-old school sent out 670 invitations _ complete with mortar boards and tassels. Many former students who could not attend the commencement wrote to ask that their new degrees be sent to them. ``You symbolize the heart and spirt of RISD,'' Peter Freeman, chairman of the school's board of trustees, told those honored, to the applause of about 500 friends and relatives. ``You are the living proof that all the energy expended to educate budding artists is worth it.''

DOC.HEAD: Tens Of Thousands Remember Czechoslovak Hero
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people gathered on a sunny hillside Saturday to remember the co-founder of Czechoslovakia, 71 years after he was killed in a plane crash. Under Communist rulers who were swept out of power in last winter's peaceful revolution, the republic's co-founder, Gen. Milan R. Stefanik, and its first president, Thomas Garrigue Masaryk, were virtually taboo figures accorded almost no public honors. On Saturday, President Vaclav Havel joined tens of thousands of people attended the nationally televised ceremony at Bradlo, the site where Stefanik crashed in 1919. The town is some 60 miles north of the regional Slovak capital of Bratislava. ``We gathered here ... to renew the tradition of annual national pilgrimage to Bradlo, a tradition which was created spontaneously by our people in the first Czechoslovak republic ... and which was interrupted by our last regime,'' Milan Cic, premier of the Slovak regional government, said after a wreath-laying ceremony. The ceremony was used as a time to emphasize the unity between the Czech and Slovak people who constitute the dominant ethnic groups within the nation. Those ties were strained in recent weeks by a debate over a new name for the country. Last month, Slovaks pushed Parliament to change the republic's name to ``The Czech and Slovak Federative Republic'' to emphasize the distinct role that Slovaks have played in the state. Stefanik ``understood that it was necessary to unite the destiny of the Slovak nation with the destiny of the Czechs. He understood this as well as Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, who knew that it was the only way to create a strong state here, a state which the Czech lands could never become without the Slovaks,'' Havel told the crowd. The era of ``psuedo-independence and federated totality'' has ended, Havel said, referring to the Communist past. ``Now, the era of brotherly cooperation of two autonomous nations is beginning.'' The languages of the two groups are very similar, but their history and traditions vary. The Czech region of Bohemia was one of the first places in Europe to undergo industrialization, while Slovakia is far more rural and still preserves peasant customs.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Killed in Stolen Radio Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A homeless woman who allegedly tried to sell a stolen car radio back to its owner was beaten to death with a baseball bat Saturday by the irate robbery victim, police said. The killer jumped into his car and sped off after the beating outside a restaurant, said police Sgt. Norris Hollomon. Hollomon said the initial account was based on reports from witnesses, and police were waiting for an autopsy before officially calling it a homicide. He said the incident began when Theresa Thomas, 35, walked into the restaurant trying to sell a car radio she was carrying. A man eating breakfast inside recognized the radio as coming from his car and began arguing with her, witnesses told police. The man went outside, checked his car and found the radio missing, Hollomon said. He went back in the restaurant after the woman, and the pair began arguing again. The argument spilled into the street outside the eatery, where witnesses told police they saw the man go into his trunk and pull out a baseball bat, Hollomon said. Witnesses said two other men helped the bat-wielding man beat the woman.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Parties Allowed to Register For First Time in 30 Years
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in three decades, opposition parties are being allowed to apply for legal standing to challenge the ruling party. At least five opposition parties had formally registered as of Friday, state television reported Saturday. Registration is the first step toward legalization. Presidential and legislative elections are to take place by the year's end, but a date has not yet been set. State television, which generally ignores anti-government protests or statements by critics, showed film of news conferences of two opposition groups on Saturday night. The opposition leaders themselves were not heard, but an announcer listed some of their complaints. The ruling Democratic Party has dominated this West African nation since independence from France in 1960. Opposition parties were legal under the nation's constitution, but none had been allowed to operate. The change in policy came this week, when President Felix Houphouet-Boigny on Thursday approved a recommendation from his party to allow the opposition groups to register. He acted after several weeks of violent protests, triggered by austerity measures. Demonstrators initially opposed the imposition of wage cuts and increased taxes but then began calling for the president's removal. The demonstrations included stoning and burning dozens of government vehicles, buses and schools. One student was killed.

DOC.HEAD: 16 Fundamentalists Arrested in Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday arrested 16 alleged Moslem militants in southern Egypt, continuing a crackdown in which 16 of the fundamentalists have been killed and hundreds detained, officials said. A police source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the 16 men detained in Beni Suif, 75 miles south of Cairo, were members of the Jihad organization.
