The same group claimed responsibility for the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in 1981. The suspects were arrested under emergency laws in effect since Sadat's death. The police source said no charges were filed. The arrests raised to 44 the number of militants arrested over the last two days. On Friday, 28 militants were arrested for allegedly planning attacks on police stations in Cairo and its suburb of Giza, Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said in an interview scheduled for publication Sunday in the state-owned Al-Ahram newspaper. He also confirmed that 16 Moslem militants were killed in April clashes with police and hundreds detained in the southern provinces of el-Minya, Assiut and Fayoum. Police said the Jihad organization was also responsible for a series of attacks on police stations in the city of Assiut, 235 miles south of Cairo, immediately following the assassination of Sadat. About 80 people, mostly policemen, were killed and 156 injured in the attacks and subsequent rioting. The government said the riots were designed to spark a nationwide uprising to overthrow Egypt's secular government and establish an Islamic fundamentalist regime. The latest crackdown on religious extremists has followed weeks of attacks in southern Egypt on members of Egypt's Coptic Christian minority. About one-tenth of the country's 55 million inhabitants are Copts.

DOC.HEAD: Radioactive Waste Leaking in National Marine Sanctuary
DOC.TEXT: The richest ocean wildlife sanctuary on the West Coast is threatened by a large radioactive waste dump piled high with corroded barrels leaking plutonium and cesium, according to a new federal report. Many of the corroding, 55-gallon barrels dumped between 1946 and 1970 in the Gulf of the Farallones National Marine Sanctuary wildlife sanctuary have burst from water pressure, according to the study. The federal study was reported in the San Francisco Examiner's Sunday edition. Yet more than 20 years after the government acknowledged that at least 47,500 barrels of U.S. atomic lab and industrial wastes lie in or adjacent to the sanctuary, the site remains virtually unstudied for its effects on marine life, said the report by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The report urges further study of possible radioactive contamination of commercial fisheries of Pacific herring, Dover sole, rockfish, sablefish and Dungeness crab and hefty rockfish sports catches. The report was prepared under an agreement between the Environmental Protection Agency and NOAA. EPA has authority for placing sites on the Superfund, the national priorities list of the worst toxic dumps. NOAA, a branch of the U.S. Department of Commerce, is the trustee for marine resources under Superfund. Two years ago, a contractor to the EPA rated the Farallon Islands Radioactive Waste Dump as ``high priority'' for investigation for Superfund. But no action has been taken by EPA, and now NOAA is pushing EPA to make an assessment of the potential danger of the dump on the marine life. ``We've started to dictate our own direction to projects that we think need our attention,'' said Jim Bybee, Northern California environmental coordinator for NOAA's National Marine Fisheries In Southern California, NOAA, which operates the nation's marine sanctuaries, filed notice of intent to sue chemical and petroleum companies for polluting bays and the ocean with DDT and heavy metals. Once in the environment, plutonium can last for hundreds of thousands of years. Its half-life is 24,360 years, and the rule of thumb is that it takes about 10 half-lives before it decays to background levels. In past studies, the sediments at the Farallones have shown higher than normal levels of long-lived and dangerous plutonium and cesium _ possibly more than 1,000 times expected background levels. Sole, rockfish and sablefish _ which are eaten by humans _ feed on worms and tiny shrimp that feed in these sediments and are most likely accumulating the radioactivity, scientists say. The Farallones marine ecosystem supports the largest population of seabirds south of Alaska and an abundance of fish, invertebrates and marine mammals.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Refugees Flee Cambodia Fighting
DOC.TEXT: More than 10,000 refugees have fled fighting between guerrillas and government forces in northwestern Cambodia, relief officials said Saturday. The Cambodian refugees arrived at guerrilla-controlled refugee camps on the Thai-Cambodian border in April, said aid officials in the Thai frontier town of Aranyaprathet. They spoke on condition of anonymity. Official Cambodian radio has said 37,000 refugees have returned from the Thai-Cambodian border to government-held parts of the northwestern province of Banteay Meachey. It did not say exactly when they returned. A transcript of the report seen in Bangkok Saturday said the government offered the refugees 6,000 acres of farmland if they returned. It was not clear from the report if the refugees had previously lived in refugee camps or in the northwest. But aid officials said there was no sign of people leaving the refugee camps to return to Cambodia. ``We have not seen any increase in people going back. In fact, just the opposite, people are fleeing the fighting to the border,'' said one official. He said most of the more than 10,000 people who fled Cambodia in April arrived at the sprawling site 2 camp near the border. The camp houses almost half of the 300,000 Cambodians living in refugee camps in Thailand. Since September, there has been heavy fighting between forces of the Vietnam-backed government and guerrillas in northwestern Cambodia. The start of the rainy season this month is expected to bring another round of guerrilla attacks in the 11-year-old civil war.

DOC.HEAD: Politicans, Guerrilla Leaders Meet
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran rebel leaders and representatives of nine political parties, including the rightist governing party, met Saturday in Mexico City. The meeting, held to discuss the progress of U.N.-sponsored peace talks, stemmed from accords signed last month in Geneva calling for negotiations between the government and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front. ``This meeting is an exchange of opinions about the peace negotiations,'' rebel leader Dagoberto Gutierrez said. The rebel delegation was headed by Shafik Handal and German Cienfuegos, both members of the rebels' military high command. The political party leaders included Guillermo Ungo, El Salvador's most prominent leftist leader, and Armando Calderon, president of the governing Republican National Alliance, or Arena. Ungo said the next government-rebel meeting ``could be held possibly May 15 in Venezuela.'' Ungo said the party leaders had met with rightist President Alfredo Cristiani earlier in the week to get the government's point of view on the progress of the peace negotiations. At least 71,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed in the decade-old insurgency between the rebels and a succession of U.S.-backed governments.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Puts Off Exxon Criminal Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to restore first reference to Kagan.
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for Exxon Corp. and its shipping company have convinced a federal judge that criminal charges stemming from the nation's largest oil spill are too complicated to be heard as soon June 18. U.S. District Judge H. Russel Holland has postponed the trial indefinitely. The June 18 date was chosen to comply with the federal speedy trial rule, which requires cases to be heard within a certain time following indictment. Exxon and Exxon Shipping Co. are charged with two felonies and three misdemeanors. Felony counts accuse the company of allowing an incompetent crew to operate the Exxon Valdez on March 23 and 24, 1989. The misdemeanor counts are for alleged violations of the federal Clean Water, Refuse and Migratory Bird Treaty acts. Motions filed by Exxon attorneys argue that most of the charges have not been used in oil-spill situations. Holland agreed. In a motion signed Wednesday, he said Exxon demonstrated ``that this prosecution involves novel questions of fact and law, and that there is an extraordinary volume of data to be digested by both the government and Exxon.'' Holland asked prosecutors and defense attorneys to propose a new trial date by June 11. The case stems from the March 24, 1989, wreck of the tanker Exxon Valdez, which struck a charted reef shortly after midnight and spewed nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. An Anchorage jury in March rejected charges that former Exxon skipper Joseph Hazelwood was drunk when the grounding occurred. According to testimony, chief mate James Kunkel said he warned Hazelwood that the seaman who took the helm on the disastrous voyage needed ``extra supervision'' for any task he took on. The seaman, Robert Kagan, was under the supervision of third mate Gregory Cousins, who testified that Kagan had under-steered the Exxon Valdez, failing to turn hard enough to avoid the grounding.

DOC.HEAD: Former EEOC Chair Announces Bid for District's Seat in Congress
DOC.TEXT: A former Carter administration official on Saturday announced her bid for the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate seat in Congress. Norton, 52, who has done extensive work in the area of civil rights, began her career as human rights commissioner of New York City. She later became chairwoman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission under President Carter from 1977 to 1981. The issue of statehood for the district had become a ``stark necessity'' said the Georgetown University law professor in the crowded playground of the elementary school she attended as a child. Norton joined D.C. At-Large Councilwoman Betty Ann Kane, former school board member Barbara Lett Simmons and Capitol Hill staffer Donald Temple in seeking the seat being vacated by Walter E. Fauntroy, D-D.C., following his announcement that he would run for mayor of the nation's capital.

DOC.HEAD: Given Free Rein, Unbridled Wins Kentucky Derby
DOC.TEXT: A colt named Unbridled ran to a 3{-length victory Sunday in the 116th Kentucky Derby, giving a 92-year-old lady named Frances A. Genter her first Derby victory in 50 years of racing. Unbridled, ridden by Craig Perret, took the lead in the home stretch and covered the 1\-mile course in 2:02 _ the 10th fastest _ to beat second-favored Summer Squall by 3{ lengths. Pleasant Tap was six lengths back and three lengths in front of Video Ranger. The favorite, Mister Frisky, was eighth. ``Today was payday,'' said a jubilant Perret, who finished second on Bet Twice in 1987 and third on Awe Inspiring in 1989. For Unbridled, the Derby was his second victory in five starts this year and his fourth triumph in 11 career outings. He paid $23.60, $7.80 and $5.80 while earning $581,000 from a purse of $756,000. Summer Squall returned $3.80 and $3.80 while Pleasant Tap, ridden by Kent Desormeaux, was $12 to show. The order of finish after Video Ranger were Silver Ending, Killer Diller, Land Rush, Mister Frisky, Thirty Six Red, Power Lunch, pace-setting Real Cash, Dr. Bobby A., Pendleton Ridge, Burnt Hills and Fighting Fantasy. Trainer Carl Nafzger called the race for Miss Genter, who had a wheelchair nearby. Her smile widened, and Nafzger put his arms around her and gave her a big kiss when Unbridled crossed the finish line. Said the owner: ``I couldn't see the race, so Carl made the call for me. He said, `He's sixth, he's fifth, he's going to win it.' ``We're No. 1,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Negotiators Recess Talks After Nine-Hour Session
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs with details of talks after 3rd grav prvs, `The talks...; picks up 4th graf pvs, `A four-hour...
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for striking Greyhound drivers and the bus line recessed negotiations Saturday after a nine-hour bargaining session failed to produce a new contract in the 2-month walkout. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service said both sides were reviewing proposals and that mediators hoped to schedule new talks within a few days. The talks were the first in the walkout since mid-March and came a day after the company reported a $56 million loss for the first three months this year. Much of Saturday's session was devoted to a review of the company's financial situation and how it would impact a potential contract, said a source close to negotiations. Money problems made the bargaining process ``extremely difficult,'' the source said. The lack of another scheduled meeting ``is not a good sign,'' the source said, noting negotiators had originally talked of possibly meeting Sunday and Monday as well. A four-hour round of morning negotiations, which mostly involved each side talking separately with federal mediators, produced ``very little'' progress, union president Edward M. Strait said after labor and management broke separately for lunch. ``We're feeling the process out right now,'' Strait said. ``We're hopeful we'll reach a settlement.'' Greyhound Vice President Anthony P. Lannie, the company's top negotiator, also said ``nothing's happened so far,'' but indicated that was because the two sides had spent most of the time in the morning session with mediators. The negotiators left by a basement exit after the afternoon session, avoiding reporters. Lannie and Strait are trying to settle disputes over wages, job security and seniority issues for the 6,300 striking drivers and 3,000 clerical and maintenance workers who walked out March 2. Union spokesman Nick Nichols said striking drivers were hopeful a new contract could be reached soon because there appeared to be less ``acrimony and tension'' between the two sides. Strait, head of the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, and Lannie met with Bernard E. DeLury, director of the mediation service, and two other federal mediators. Each side brought along a team of negotiators. Nichols said the strike ``has not been easy on either side,'' noting union members have been receiving $50 a week in strike benefits. The walkout halted intercity bus service in nearly half of the 10,000 communities Greyhound serves. Greyhound, the only nationwide bus line, has said it has since restored about 83 percent of its normal service. But on Friday, the company said it had suffered a $55.8 million loss in the January-March quarter, compared with a $14.4 million loss in the first quarter of 1989. It turned a profit of under $1 million last year. The company blamed $20 million of this year's first-quarter loss on security for the shootings, bomb threats and other violent incidents that have occurred since the strike began nine weeks ago. ``Clearly, the information verifies what we have thought for some time _ that the strike was being very effective and it was important to get back to the table,'' Nichols said. A source close to the process said the company's financial situation might mean both sides ``are going to have to be creative about the seniority and money areas.'' Citing the violence, the company withdrew from negotiations in mid-March. There have been more than 30 shootings at buses and terminals since the strike began. The union has strongly denied any involvement with the violence and supported prosecution for those involved. It said union members also were the victims of violence. A striking driver was crushed to death on the second day of the strike by a bus driven by a replacement driver. The company's last offer was for $63 million in wage hikes over three years, although the union contends the bus line is inflating the figure because the bus line wants to link pay increases to corporate performance, such as increased ridership. Drivers, who earn an average of $24,743 a year, are trying to recover some of the wage and benefit concessions they have given the company over the past decade. Besides wages, the two sides also need to resolve a dispute over the replacement drivers Greyhound has hired since the strike began. The company wants to let those 2,500 drivers keep their jobs and put a like amount of union drivers on a waiting list; the union wants its members to keep their jobs and retain seniority over replacements. There are also several disputes over work rules and grievance procedures. Greyhound's financial statement Friday said it was developing a financial restructuring plan. The bus line had maintained it had sufficient cash to withstand the strike and would make a $9.75 million debt interest payment due May 15. But the company said Friday that it would miss that payment. It also said it missed lease and other payments due April 30. The company also said it expects to lose money in April, May and possibly June before returning to profitability. Greyhound already laid off about 270 mechanics last month.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Rejects Latvian Declaration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series, edits to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday rejected Latvia's declaration of independence and threatened the Baltic republic with unspecified political, economic and administrative measures if it doesn't reverse its course, Tass reported. The Soviet president's decision came one day after Latvia's parliament adopted the independence declaration and was announced late Saturday night on Latvian television by Alfreds Rubiks, the republic's Communist Party chief. Rubiks' remarks were reported early Sunday by Tass, the official Soviet news agency. The Latvian legislators had called for a slow transition to independence and for negotiations with Moscow to avoid the sharp economic sanctions the Soviet Union imposed on neighboring Lithuania, which declared its independence March 11. Rubiks spoke by telephone with Gorbachev earlier Saturday and said the Soviet leader considered the attempt by the Latvians to portray their decision as different from Lithuania's was ``groundless,'' Tass reported. ``The president of the U.S.S.R. considers that the declaration that was passed May 4 by the Latvian parliament on the restoration of independence of the Latvian republic signifies a violation of constitutional norms and is leading toward the breakdown of governmental ties of the republics of the U.S.S.R.,'' Rubiks quoted Gorbachev as saying. Gorbachev emphasized negotiations are possible only under the guidelines of the Soviet Constitution and that negotiations can only begin after a reversal of the declaration of independence, Tass quoted Rubiks as saying. The news agency quoted Rubiks as saying that if the republic ignores the Soviet Constitution, the president reserves the right to take political, economic and administrative measures in response. He did not elaborate on what measures Gorbachev might take. In mid-April, the Soviet leader slapped an economic embargo on Lithuania for its pro-independence moves, cutting off all oil and sharply curtailing natural gas and other key supplies to the republic. Gorbachev's decision on Latvia was not broadcast on national Soviet TV Saturday night, and he did not make any reference to it in a public appearance in Moscow earlier in the day. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said he is still waiting for Moscow to begin talks with his representatives, even after he endorsed the idea of slowing the drive for independence. On May 15, Lithuania is expected to exhaust its reserve supplies of oil, natural gas and other raw materials, its deputy prime minister, Algirdas Brazauskas, said. On Monday, Lithuania will decide whether to retaliate by cutting off its supplies of meat and dairy products to Moscow and Leningrad, Brazauskas said. Gediminas Vagnorius, a Lithuanian lawmaker, said Saturday the Soviet embargo has forced 12,500 people out of work in the industrial, construction and transportation sectors, although many have been transferred to other needed jobs. The independence declaration by Latvia's Supreme Soviet parliament on Friday was greeted with fireworks and jubilant crowds danced in the streets of the capital, Riga. The vote for independence was 138-0, with one abstention and one lawmaker absent. But 57 deputies did not vote in protest, and Rubiks and another anti-independence deputies walked out of the hall to show their displeasure. In a message to Gorbachev, the deputies said the declaration ``opens the door to a transition period _ a period of close dialogue ... close cooperation and wide political, economic and human contacts.'' Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov had even said low level negotiations with Moscow would begin May 15. Rubiks predicted the declaration of independence would not be supported by his constituents, who would begin strikes, demonstrations and appeals for Gorbachev to impose presidential rule. On Saturday morning, a group of about 300 people gathered to denounce the declaration. Interfront, a group of ethnic Russians and other non-Latvians, organized the rally on Cathedral Square, where speakers mounted an army truck to demand the withdrawal of the declaration. Only 54 percent of Latvia's 2.7 million people are ethnic Latvians. Most of the remainder are ethnic Russians, many of whom oppose independence. Also Saturday, a group of Latvian economists announced plans to introduce their own currency in the republic. Economists of the new Latvia Fund said work was under way to restore the pre-Soviet Latvian currency, the lat. The fund, created last month, plans to issue $11 million in bonds and lottery tickets that can be sold abroad to finance the creation and printing of the new currency, they said. Similar plans to issue currencies have been announced in Estonia and Lithuania, but none has been issued yet.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Commission Calls For Stricter Controls In Adirondacks
DOC.TEXT: A state commission appointed to study the future of the 6 million-acre Adirondack Park called Saturday for strict new curbs on development in the largest such wilderness tract in the Lower 48 states. Many of the 245 proposals by the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century immediately drew fire from some of the park's 130,000 residents who hope increased development can bolster the region's weak economy. Though the mountainous area in northern New York is called a park, it actually is a patchwork of public land and private property. Use of the private land is controlled to some extent by a state law requiring parts of the region be kept ``forever wild.'' The commission recommended the state buy an additional 650,000 acres of the park _ more than 1,000 square miles. About half the park's land is in private hands. The panel proposed to reclassify 90 percent of that land for ``resource use,'' where construction would be prohibited for at least a year, said the commission. Another proposal to discourage development would require minimum 2,000-acre housing sites in some backwoods portions of the park. Under current park rules, the largest minimum lot size is 47 acres per dwelling. The commission was appointed by Gov. Mario Cuomo, and its recommendations must be enacted by the state Legislature to take effect. Its report should be viewed by park residents as a threat to their way of life, said Adirondack Planning Commission Chairman Hammond Robertson. ``They have just lost sight of the American way of life, the right to own property, the right to use property,'' said Robertson, who is also town supervisor of Queensbury, about 50 miles north of Albany. ``There is a real threat from people outside the park who don't really realize that this is our home. It's a community, it's not just a park. It's not like Central Park in New York City,'' said Robertson. The Cuomo commission insists that something must be done to preserve the unique character of the wilderness area. ``From within, development threatens its forested mountains, its shorelines and roadsides,'' said the report. ``From outside ... larger threats loom from a booming population looking for recreational property to buy, from changing economies in the timber and tourism industries, and from acid rain and deposition of airborne toxins.'' The Cuomo commission is headed by Peter Berle, president of the National Audubon Society and a former commissioner of New York state's Department of Environmental Conservation. Creation of the commission stirred up 20-year old resentment in the Adirondack Mountains, where the state already limits development through a complex land-use plan devised during the Gov. Nelson Rockefeller era. ``A moratorium would be a useless political maneuver designed only to appease the most extreme factions of the environmental community,'' said the Adirondack Fairness Coalition, a group of residents who favor development. Environmental groups, most notably the Adirondack Council, are urging stricter controls. Commission members and staff said that some of the panel's 245 recommendations were aimed at improving life for the Adirondack people. The report recommended creation of an Adirondack Park Community Development Corporation to build housing and provide services in areas set aside for development. The panel also called for a sliding tax on home sales starting at 1 percent for $150,000 homes and rising to 7.5 percent for those sold for more than $250,000. The revenue would go toward affordable housing programs in the park. ``It appears just to be a bone that they threw in to try and appease us,'' said Frederick Monroe, chairman of the Fairness Commission and a lawyer in Chestertown. ``We're not sure there's any meat on it.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Art Auction Brings `Sobering' Prices
DOC.TEXT: The market for Soviet contemporary art, once heated by glasnost and the new warmth in East-West relations, took a chilly plunge Saturday when nearly half the paintings at a major auction failed to draw bids. Two years ago, the Soviet Union's first international art auction attracted celebrity buyers such as rock star Elton John and pulled in a total of $3.6 million dollars, triple the pre-sale estimate by Sotheby's. Saturday's auction in New York, billed as the first major auction of Soviet contemporary art in the West, had roughly the same number of paintings by many of the same artists. But its total revenues barely topped $1.1 million. About 60 of the 119 works didn't sell at all. ``The people who bought, bought extremely well. They found some good bargains,'' said Swiss auctioneer Geza von Hapsburg, chairman of the Geneva-based auction house of Habsburg, Feldman. At Sotheby's Moscow auction in July, 1988, rapid-fire bidding drove the price for ``Fundamental Lexicon,'' a painting by 45-year-old Grisha Bruskin, to $416,000 _ a record for a piece of contemporary Soviet art. On Saturday, the gavel fell quickly on Bruskin's ``Old Testament'' at $36,000, in the lower range of the pre-sale estimate of $35,000 to $40,000 and far less than some experts had expected. Few of the 31 artists whose works were on sale attended the auction. One who did, 52-year-old Vladimir Yankilevsky, left glumly after none of his three pieces was sold. Von Hapsburg pronounced himself ``satisfied.'' He noted that 300 people packed the auction gallery in Manhattan's Puck Building, there was strong media coverage, and a few paintings sold for considerably more than predicted. But he conceded that the bidding, on the whole, was disappointing after the spectacular success of the pathbreaking Moscow auction. ``That was just hype _ the first one,'' he said. ``Today was _ you could say `sobering,' or you could say `realistic,' because many of these artists are not well known to the American public, even though they are the cream of what Soviet art produces today.'' All but a handful of the paintings that went on the block Saturday belonged to a single collection, amassed in buying trips to the Soviet Union during the past five years by a French art book publisher, Jose Alvarez. Von Hapsburg contended that the quality of the collection was, on average, higher than the paintings that the Soviet government allowed to go on sale in Moscow. While some experts might dispute that, there is general agreement that the artists represented in Saturday's auction _ including Ilya Kabakov, Ivan Chuikov, Igor Kopystianski, Francisco Infante and Natalia Nesterova _ are among the best in the Soviet Union, according to Margarita Tupitsyn, a curatorial consultant in Soviet contemporary art for the Guggenheim Museum in New York. The top price paid for a painting on Saturday was $140,000 for ``Path'' by Kabakov, 57, probably the best known contemporary Soviet artist in the West. A spokeswoman for the auction house said the buyer was a museum, but she declined to identify it without permission.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped 15-Day-Old Boy Found, Apparently Unhurt
DOC.TEXT: A baby boy whose kidnapping four days ago had prompted an islandwide search by police and the FBI was found alive and apparently unharmed Saturday, police said. The cries of 15-day-old Carlos Luis Canales were heard outside an office building by two census takers, who alerted their superiors. The infant had been abducted Tuesday by a woman who posed as a sales representative for a diaper manufacturer. He was discovered inside a shopping bag beside a garbage bin on the outskirts of Carolina, an eastern suburb east of San Juan, police said. A local radio station reported that a medical checkup indicated the baby was unharmed and in good physical condition. The kidnapper had told the baby's parents that their three children had won a contest sponsored by the diaper company. She took them to a local mall to photograph the children and, while the parents were busy, left with the infant. The census takers heard the baby crying outside a building that houses a U.S. Census office and other government offices. The parents, Migdalia Cortes and Luis Canales, rushed to the scene with police. Paul R. Philip, special agent in charge of the FBI office in San Juan, said the FBI had helped in the investigation although there appeared to be no federal jurisdiction in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Lennon Tribute in His Hometown Draws Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with concert over, details, color. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XLIV1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of John Lennon fans, some too young to remember the Beatles, swayed and sang along with songs including his anthem ``Imagine'' at a hometown tribute. ``It's a great day, isn't it?'' Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, asked the crowd. ``I think John would be happy, too.'' At the close of the concert, she and son Sean, 14, wept and hugged some of the musicians, who included B.B. King, Joe Cocker, Roberta Flack, the Moody Blues, Hall and Oates, Wet Wet Wet and Randy Travis. However, the turnout was only 15,000, according to police estimates. Organizers had hoped for about 45,000. Tickets were $41 for the charity benefit concert, which featured a program of Beatles and Lennon songs. The concert was televised in Britain and was to be rebroadcast worldwide in October in a 50th birthday tribute to Lennon a decade after his death. Cyndi Lauper, in a white minidress, sang ``Hey Bulldog,'' and Dave Edmunds, backed by the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, did the Beatles classic, ``A Day in the Life.'' Soul singer Al Green was the opening act. His version of ``All You Need is Love,'' turned into a singalong with the crowd, and Kylie Minogue did ``Help.'' American actor Christopher Reeve was among the hosts of the concert. Ex-Beatles George Harrison, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr did not attend, but McCartney and Starr made taped contributions. On tape, Starr performed ``I Call Your Name'' and said, ``John had the biggest heart of any man I have ever met to this day. He was a giving, loving, caring human being. He was crazy as well some days _ but the guy would give you his heart.'' Lennon's co-songwriter, Paul McCartney, said on his tape: ``Hello Liverpool, scene of many great memories, John, me and the rest of the lads.'' The Beatles were raised in Liverpool and got their start in the Merseyside bars. All the musicians assembled on stage for ``Give Peace a Chance,'' as the enthusiastic audience sang along, waved and clapped. The concert closed with a recording of Lennon singing ``Imagine,'' while giant screens showed a video featuring John and Yoko. Proceeds are to go to the Spirit Foundation, the charity founded by the Lennons in 1978, two years before Lennon was shot to death in front of his apartment in New York City. Lennon was slain on Dec. 8, 1980, when he was 40. The confessed killer, Mark Chapman, is serving a life prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Cypriots Go To Polls Sunday
DOC.TEXT: Turkish Cypriots vote Sunday in parliamentary elections that could bring defeat for the governing party and new momentum to stalled peace talks aimed at uniting the island's Turkish and Greek sectors. Analysts said voters in the breakaway Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus could unseat President Rauf Denktash's National Unity Party Sunday for the first time in 15 years. The region, created following Turkey's 1974 invasion of Cyprus, is only recognized by Turkey. Two weeks ago Denktash won his fourth term as president by capturing 67 percent of the vote, but his party appears much less popular. Analysts said if the National Struggle Party, an opposition coalition, wins power, it would leave Denktash virtually powerless because most decisions are made by the legislature and the president has little executive power. The opposition has accused Denktash of intransigence in reunification talks on Cyprus. While opposition leaders said they would welcome peace talks, they have also indicated they would not retreat from the traditional Turkish demand for a loose federation with both zones. Turkey will also remain a factor in future negotiations. Ankara maintains an estimated 30,000 troops in the north and has given substantial funding to the republic. The opposition coalition comprises the conservative New Birth Party, mainly supported by settlers from Turkey, the leftist Socialist Liberation and the Republican Turkish Party. In the last elections in 1985 the parties received a combined vote of 61 percent, but their divided votes gave them a minority of seats in the 50-member Parliament. The opposition has accused the governing party of widespread corruption and the misuse of economic resources.

DOC.HEAD: USS Pueblo Crew Receives Honor Denied Them Two Years Ago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to DELETE final `the'; SUBS 10th graf, `Even after...,' to fix grammar.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GO1
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two years after their capture by North Korea and two years after being snubbed by their own government, the crew of the USS Pueblo received prisoner of war medals Saturday.
DOC.HEAD: Sixty-four of the 82 crewmen seized with the intelligence ship
DOC.TEXT: gathered by San Diego Bay to be recognized as prisoners of war for enduring 11 months in captivity in North Korea in 1968. The sailors, a few of whom are still on active duty with the Navy, received the awards in a ceremony conducted by Assistant Secretary of the Navy Barbara Pope. She read a statement from President Bush commending the crew for its ``unfailing resolve.'' It was a day of celebration for the former shipmates, but for former Pueblo Cmdr. Lloyd ``Pete'' Bucher, who had worked to see the men honored for their courage under captivity, it also was a day of redemption for the ship. ```This is what needed to be done when we got home, '' Bucher said after the 40-minute ceremony. ``They needed to tell these guys that they had served well. ``What they got was a very military function called a board of inquiry and then, `Bye-bye.' They did receive some awards later on but it was done more or less in private. I wanted these guys recognized in public.'' When the POW medal was authorized by Congress in 1988, the crew of the Pueblo was excluded from eligibility. The Pentagon had ruled that the crew was merely detained, rather than according the sailors POW status. ``It's a day of great for me personally,'' Bucher said. ``I have never been happier than I am today.'' The Pueblo was captured Jan. 23, 1968, in international waters after being fired on by North Korean vessels. The crew was tortured, endured public humiliation and resisted efforts by the North Koreans to be used for propaganda purposes before being released in December 1968. Even after a formal Navy court of inquiry, many questions remain about the Koreans' reason for seizing the ship and about the failure of U.S. forces to respond to calls for help before Bucher surrendered the ship and crew. Bucher and other Pueblo officers were recommended for courts martial at the time of the inquiry. But the Navy never tried them. During a ceremony attended by about 500 people, including the families of some of the crew members, the sailors heard praise that had eluded them for more than two decades. ``These men once were snubbed by our government when the medals were first awarded, '' said Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, who Bucher credited for eventually getting the medals approved in Congress. ``That was an oversight. Today, in a small way, we are trying to right that wrong.'' F.C. ``Skip'' Schumacher Jr. acknowledged the honor on behalf of the crew. ``The POW medal is to honor those people who served and served honorably, and I'm here to tell you today that this crew did serve honorably,'' Schumacher said, drawing applause. Bucher has in the past accused the Navy of putting the ship in dangerous position without adequate support. Bucher declined to speak at the ceremony, and said later it was because he'd been too emotional. In a sense, the medals close the books on the Pueblo affair, Bucher said: ``Now we move on to just reunions and watching one another's kids and grandkids grow up.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Apologizes for Massacre of Indians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after ninth graf, `The Assembly ...' and two grafs after penultimate graf, `The army ...' to UPDATE with comment from state Rep. David Clarenbach and historian. Pick up last graf, `The site ...'
DOC.TEXT: Sac and Fox Indians received an apology Saturday from Wisconsin for the 1832 Bad Axe Massacre during which hundreds of their tribal predecessors were killed while trying to flee white pursuers. ``I thank you, sir,'' Elmer Manatowa of Stroud, Okla., chief of the Sac-Fox nation told a state legislator who presented a proclamation of apology from the Wisconsin Assembly during a ceremony. ``The Sac and Fox nation in Oklahoma is thriving. One hundred years ago, one might have thought the Sac and Fox might not be in existence today,'' Manatowa said. Gunfire on the banks of the Mississippi River 158 years ago ended a trek of hundreds of miles by men, women and children led by chief Black Hawk after white settlers evicted the tribes from their ancestral lands near Rock Island, Ill. Known to history as the Black Hawk War, the relentless pursuit of the fleeing Indians and the riverside massacre was described by one historian as ``one of the bloodiest tragedies in the sad history of American-Indian relations.'' The Indians were attacked by Army soldiers, state militia and settlers. The ceremony at the battle site about 20 miles downstream from La Crosse was attended by about 200 people. Wisconsin Chippewa, currently debating the state over treaty rights to off-reservation natural resources, have participated in memorial ceremonies at the site in previous years. Attorney Truman Carter of Stroud, the Sac-Fox treasurer, said 20th century disputes among Indians and non-Indians must be resolved in the courts, not in the field. The Assembly proclamation was presented by state Rep. David Clarenbach. The resolution was adopted last year at the urging of Milwaukee-based Honor Our Neighbors Origins and Rights. ``What we do is not without example elsewhere,'' Clarenbach said. ``The state of Minnesota apologized to the Sioux for mass executions carried out without due process'' after an Indian uprising in the 1860s. ``Congress has acknowledged the impropriety of internment of Japanese-Americans and the new regimes of Eastern Europe draw great moral strength from the admission of past wrongs,'' he said. Tribal leaders from the Sac and Fox nation in Iowa, Oklahoma and Kansas were invited to the ceremony. Since 1955, a roadside placard has told visitors about the battle during which Black Hawk's people, trying to escape across the Mississippi, were hounded into riverside marshes where they were shot or drowned. ``To have the state of Wisconsin publicly apologize is something we look at,'' Manatowa said last week. ``I am going to ask the state of Wisconsin to do the same thing for the Chippewa, to do something to ease the relationship up there.'' More than 1,000 Sac and Fox had gathered at the river after eluding militia at the Battle of Wisconsin Heights near Madison, a maneuver some historians say classified Black Hawk as a military genius. The army, aided by an armed steamboat on the river, launched a campaign to stop them. Black Hawk tried to surrender at Bad Axe but troops disregarded the plea, witnesses said. Estimates of Indian deaths range from 850 to 1,400. ``What a terrible day it was in 1832. What a great day this is,'' Hilary Waukau Sr., a Menominee tribal legislator, said during the ceremony. The massacre ``was one of the bloodiest tragedies in the sad history of American-Indian relations,'' historian Ray Allen Billington wrote in a book called ``Westward Expansion: A History of the American Frontier.'' The site in southwestern Wisconsin contains many reminders besides Victory, a nearby hamlet named by whites after the battle. There's also Black Hawk Campground, Black Hawk Marina, Battle Island, Battle Bluff, a town called Retreat, and another called Soldier's Grove.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica Signs Accord With Creditor Banks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf with one graf to RESTORE words `was signed by.'
DOC.TEXT: Costa Rica and a group of U.S. banks signed an accord Saturday restructuring the Central American country's $1.8 billion commercial debt. The accord, which is expected to save Costa Rica $150 million a year, was signed by James Jardine of the Bank of America, and Eduardo Lizano of the Costa Rican Central Bank. Jardine acted as the representative of the creditor banks. President Oscar Arias hailed the agreement as an historic event that removes one of the main obstacles to his country's economic growth. Eduardo Lizano, president of the Central Bank, said earlier that under the agreement, Costa Rica will repurchase 64 percent of its commercial debt at 16 cents on the dollar. Costa Rica now will have until May 21 to pay $253 million to bring itself up to date in payments and repurchase the old debt. Costa Rica was one of the earliest countries to reach agreement in principle on new financing packages under a U.S. plan unveiled in March 1989 by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. It focuses on enticing commercial banks to write off some of their loans to Third World nations or reduce the interest charged in return for guarantees that the remaining debt will be paid.

DOC.HEAD: Police Make Huge Cocaine Haul in Series of Lab Raids
DOC.TEXT: Army troops backed by fighter bombers and helicopter gunships raided crude jungle laboratories and seized 16,400 pounds of cocaine, an army general said Saturday. It was the largest haul of cocaine in Colombia since March 10, 1984, when agents seized 22,000 pounds in what was believed to be the biggest seizure of the drug to date. Two men were killed and 14 were arrested in the raids, Gen. Humberto Castaneda said in a broadcast interview with the RCN radio chain. The raids began Thursday, and by Saturday morning the army had landed troops at 20 clandestine runways where five airplanes were seized, the general said in the RCN interview. One of the planes seized was from Bolivia, Castaneda said. Cocaine paste is brought from Bolivia and Peru to Colombia, where it is converted into pure cocaine through chemical processing. The raids were in the state of Meta, in an area about 200 miles southeast of the capital of Bogota. Castaneda did not disclose how many laboratories were found. It is common for traffickers to build a cluster of labs in the same area to make it more difficult to spot the operation from the air. The government of President Virgilio Barco launched an offensive against drug traffickers after they were blamed for killing a presidential candidate, Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, on Aug. 18. Since then, the government security forces have found dozens of laboratories, seized tons of cocaine and confiscated millions of dollars worth of property. The army and police have seized mansions, ranches, yachts, airplanes and luxury cars believed to belong to traffickers. So far all but one of the chieftains of the Medellin cartel have eluded the police raids. Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, the reputed No. 2 figure in the cartel, was shot during a battle with police Dec. 15 on Colombia's north coast.

DOC.HEAD: British Jurist Named to Head Inquiry Into Illegal Arms Shipment
DOC.TEXT: A British jurist will lead an investigation into a shipment of Israeli-made arms ordered by a Cabinet official that ended up in the hands of Colombian drug dealers, the government said. Louis Blomcooper was chosen by the Cabinet at a special meeting on Friday because of his experience in conducting commissions of inquiry and will arrive in the Caribbean republic to start this week, a government statement said Friday. The arms scandal broke in February when Colombian authorities discovered a cache of Israeli-made arms in a ranch owned by reputed drug lord Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, who was killed in a gun battle with police in December. The Colombian authorities said they found 232 weapons, including rifles, shoulder-fired rockets and infrared nightscopes. A preliminary investigation by a special committee set up here determined that the arms shipment passed through Antigua, a tiny island 250 miles southeast of Puerto Rico, on April 24, 1989, and arrived in Colombia five days later. The scandal has plunged the Antiguan government into one of its worst crises since Prime Minister Vere Bird Sr., 81, came to power in 1956. Minister of Public Works Vere Bird Jr., national security adviser to his father, was named by the Israeli government as the Antiguan official who ordered the arms shipment in November 1988 for the Antiguan Defense Forces. It is unclear how the weapons were then shipped to Colombia. Bird Jr., 54, has denied any wrongdoing and stepped down from his post until the matter is resolved. The twin-island state of Antigua and Barbuda has a population of 80,000 and gained independence from Britain in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Report: Romania and Warsaw Pact Nations Sold Soviet Weapons to United States
DOC.TEXT: The United States secretly bought advanced Soviet military technology from Romania for 10 years before deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was executed, according to a published report. The Washington Post, quoting ``intelligence sources here and abroad,'' said the program coordinated by the Central Intelligence Agency resulted in more than $40 million being paid to Romania through foreign middlemen, with about 20 percent of that ending up in Swiss bank accounts controlled by the Ceausescu family. The paper said the Ceausescu connection was part of a larger weapons-buying operation that reached into the East Bloc military and allowed the U.S. military to obtain important components of air defense systems that the Soviet Union has in place to protect itself and Warsaw Pact countries. The paper said the latest version of the Shilka, one of the most effective antiaircraft systems in the Soviet inventory, was among the items purchased from Romania, which also sold mobile rocket launchers and radar systems. ``The potential value of these things is almost incalculable,'' the Post quoted an unidentified U.S. intelligence officer as saying. ``The only way you can truly unlock the secrets of your adversaries' weapons is to physically have them.'' For example, access to Soviet radar systems aided in development of the ``stealth'' technology that is designed to allow U.S. military planes to avoid radar detection, the paper said. It quoted U.S. government officials as saying that Nicolae Causescu was not personally involved in the dozen or so transactions, but that the operation could have succeeded only with his tacit approval. The Romanian operation came to a halt with Causescu's overthrow last December, the paper said. Moreover, it said the pro-democracy upheaval in Eastern Europe has disrupted the broader operation, but not stopped it. Over the past decade, the United States has paid more than $250 million to obtain the latest versions of Soviet-made weapons systems through contacts in Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, East Germany and Bulgaria, the Post quoted its sources as saying. The willingness of influential military or Communist Party officials to sell secrets to the United States was viewed by some U.S. intelligence officials as a reflection of growing discontent among some Warsaw Pact officials. ``It was corrupt to the core,'' the paper quoted a former U.S. official as saying. ``There was no ideological discrimination. If you wanted to use this as an indication of the fragility of the system, this was a classic.'' As to the Romanian connection, the Post quoted a retired high-ranking U.S. intelligence official as saying ``it was just greed -- pure and simple personal greed. It was an indication of the corruption of the Ceausescus, and from the U.S. standpoint, we didn't really care who we dealt with if they could produce. Generally, you don't run into sainted characters in this business.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Orders Enhanced Cargo Door Monitoring on Older Boeings
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered airlines to install an enhanced cockpit warning system to ensure cargo doors are properly shut on certain older Boeing 747s, in response to a deadly accident last year. The order is the latest in a series of FAA directives prompted by the Feb. 24, 1989, accident in which nine people were swept to their deaths after a United Airlines 747 cargo door ripped open in flight near Hawaii. The FAA estimates it will cost U.S. airlines about $774,000 to make the changes on the 140 airplanes affected by the order. Under the directive, which takes effect May 29, cockpit warning devices must be repositioned so they can be seen by both the pilot and the copilot. The devices must also be made to monitor more parts of the doors' locking mechanisms. Warning lights are to be hooked directly to the part of the lock believed to have been damaged in the United accident. Currently, the lights are hooked to pressure relief windows on the cargo doors. The United accident is believed to have been caused by locks that had been damaged unnoticeably by improper handling. The FAA has already required U.S. airlines to reinforce the locks. ``We felt the way it was set up was adequate,'' Boeing Co. spokeswoman Elizabeth Reese said Friday. ``But we have worked with the FAA to make this change. We want to make sure this never happens again.'' The agency has no jurisdiction over 640 older 747s used by foreign air carriers, but they often follow the FAA's lead.

DOC.HEAD: Redskins Owner Marries Friend of Former Wife
DOC.TEXT: Washington Redskins owner Jack Kent Cooke on Saturday married a woman said to be the best friend of his former wife, Suzanne Martin Cooke, in his fourth trip down the aisle. Cooke, 77, confirmed that he and Marlen Ramallo Chalmers were wed at his Virginia estate over the weekend. The announcement was made at the running of the Virginia Gold Cup Steeplechase in The Plains, Va,. where Cooke's horse, Lithograph, was scratched from the race. Cooke wore a beige and yellow houndstooth check jacket while his bride was attired in an off-the-shoulder, white cotton tea-length dress, with a straw hat pulled low over her face. Asked whether they planned a honeymoon, Chalmers said, ``Oh yes,'' before Cooke hurriedly steered her away. Chalmers, who is in her mid 30s, and Suzanne Cooke, the billionaire's third wife, were old family friends who used to vacation together, according to the couple's companions at the racetrack. Cooke's last marriage ended in a highly publicized divorce when he discovered that Suzanne Cooke had became pregnant and failed to get an abortion as she had allegedly promised. Cooke did not acknowlege paternity of their daughter, Jacqueline, who was born Jan. 25, 1988, until after a court-ordered blood test.

DOC.HEAD: British Soccer Fans Close Out Season With Violent Clashes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with more arrests, charges in Bournemouth; picks up 5th pvs, `In the ...'
DOC.TEXT: British soccer fans clashed with police and one another in several cities on the closing day of soccer season, leaving dozens injured and more than 80 people arrested, authorities said Saturday. British soccer has long been plagued by fan violence and crowd control problems. Last year, a crowd crush at Hillsborough Stadium in Sheffield left 95 dead. The worst violence was in the south coast resort town of Bournemouth, where hometown fans clashed Friday night and Saturday with police and visiting fans from Leeds. At least 50 people were arrested and charged with assault, criminal damage or public order offenses, police said early Sunday. At least 20 people, including six police officers, were hurt, police said. In the hours before Saturday's game, 2,000 fans _ many without tickets or with forged tickets _ began showering police with rocks, bricks and bottles and threatening Bournemouth players. Police brought in reinforcements from as far away as London, 95 miles away. The trouble began the night before the match, when about 100 soccer fans set fire to Bournemouth's famous pier and smashed windows at a posh shopping arcade. About 300 others attacked workers and customers at a seaside pub and tore apart furniture, authorities said. ``I have been in Bournemouth for 33 years and I have never seen scenes like that before, and that includes the mods and rockers in the '60s,'' said assistant chief police constable Alan Rose. At Chesterfield, just south of Sheffield, 12 people were taken to the hospital and others were treated at the stadium after clashes between rival fans and police. None of the injuries was said to be serious, but there were 30 arrests. Trouble was also reported in Shrewsbury, in central England, where visiting fans from Preston battled with hometown supporters. A match in Birmingham had to be halted twice by the referee when fans ran onto the field, and several people were arrested, but police said no exact figure was available.

DOC.HEAD: Drive Launched in Oman to Save Rare Mountain Goat From Extinction
DOC.TEXT: Conservation officials on Saturday announced a renewed drive to save from extinction one of the world's rarest mammals, the Arabian Tahr mountain goat. The campaign will combine a new captive breeding program and continued efforts to protect the animals in the wild, said Ralph Daly, conservation adviser to Oman's ruler, Sultan Qaboos. The remaining Arabian Tahr are found in the sultanate's northern Hajar mountain range and in mountains in the neighboring United Arab Emirates. There are believed to be between 1,000 and 2,000 of the goats left. The government established the Wadi Sarin Nature Reserve to protect the goats after hunting them was banned in 1975. Mountain tribesmen known as mushrafyn, or guardians, monitor the movements of the goats in their remote reserve on 6,500-foot Jebel Aswad, or Black Mountain. Daly said a breeding program for scientific study of around 14 Tahr is already under way at a captive breeding center. It will be supplemented by a second breeding program ``to ensure we have animals of different lines,'' he said. ``We believe it is vital to broaden the genetic base of the only Tahr population left in the world,'' said Daly. The goats are related to the chamois and musk ox, and their preferred habitat is steep, north-facing mountains. The Hajar range runs in a crescent from the Strait of Hormuz in the north to the edge of the Wahiba Sands in the southeast. The majority of the research work carried out for the government has been led by Muscat-based British wildlife biologist Dr. Paul Munton. He described the Arabian Tahr as ``not a well-adapted desert dweller but a relic of a more temperature fauna.'' The species, he said, is ``hanging on to life in the coolest and most sheltered parts of the most difficult mountains of Arabia.'' The goats eat fruit, seeds and grasses. They are hunted in the wild by leopards, hyenas and wolves, and their young are prey to eagles, ravens and red foxes.

DOC.HEAD: Two Soldiers Charged in Panama Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES lead and SUBS 7th graf pvs, `The men...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with description of killing by relatives and attorney for one defendant. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Under military...
DOC.TEXT: Two soldiers have been charged with murdering a woman outside a bar during the U.S. invasion of Panama and a third soldier has pleaded guilty to lesser charges in the case, the Army revealed. The case, made public Thursday, is the second prosecution of U.S. soldiers for their conduct during the invasion. A paratrooper based at Fort Bragg, N.C., was charged with murder for shooting a Panamanian who surrendered to U.S. forces during the December invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Noriega. The charges against the Fort Ord soldiers involve the shooting death of a 50-year-old Panamanian woman at a bar. They were charged in late January, and were tentatively scheduled for military trial in late June, said Maj. L.D. Walker, a Fort Ord spokesman. The men to be tried are Sgt. Paul R. Finsel Jr., 25, of Arkoma, Okla., and Pfc. Mark F. McMonagle, 20, of Philadelphia, Pa. The men were members of the 7th Light Infantry Division stationed at Fort Ord. In addition to murder, charges against Finsel and McMonagle include conspiring to obstruct justice and willfully disobeying orders against consuming alcohol or having sexual contact with Panamanian women. A third soldier, Pfc. Marc Gussen, 19, of Teaneck, N.J., pleaded guilty in April to firearms, alcohol and obstruction of justice charges in the case, Walker said. He was sentenced to two years' confinement, forfeiture of all pay and allowances, reduction to private and a dishonorable discharge. John L. Williams, attorney for McMonagle, disputed the murder charge. ``Whatever it is, it is not murder,'' Williams told The New York Times. ``There is no evidence of premeditation at all. Nor is there good evidence that he is the person who fired the shot.'' The men were charged in the death of Leila Diaz De Panay on Jan. 25 in the Rio Abajo section of Panama City, according to Walker, who refused to reveal details. According to Williams and McMonagle's relatives, the trouble began when Finsel lost his pistol at a bar that also served as a brothel. To cover the loss, he suggested the men stage a firefight outside, the Times reported Sunday. As they fired into the air, other soldiers came out of a nearby barracks to investigate. They were then ordered to pull back, with McMonagle covering the rear, Williams said. When Ms. Panay was killed in an alley, McMonagle was nearby, he said. Under military law the maximum penalty for murder is death, but the sentence can be invoked only in a case of premeditated murder, said Walker. Penalties short of death are left to the discretion of the officer conducting the court martial, he said. In the earlier case, 1st Sgt. Roberto Enrique Bryan, 42, a member of the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, faces a charge of premeditated murder. He is accused of shooting a Panamanian man who surrendered after a grenade attack that injured two U.S. soldiers at Madden Dam outside Panama City on Dec. 23.

DOC.HEAD: Elton Rule, Former President of ABC, Dead at 73
DOC.TEXT: Elton H. Rule, the former ABC chief who was credited with the network's rise to broadcasting dominance in the 1970s, died of cancer Saturday at his home. He was 73. Rule, named president of ABC in 1968 and chief operating officer in 1972, introduced such innovations as the made-for-television movie and ABC Monday Night Football. He also signed producer Aaron Spelling to an exclusive contract to produce programs for ABC. Spelling produced such hit series as the ``The Mod Squad,'' ``Starsky and Hutch,'' ``The Love Boat'' and ``Charlie's Angels.'' ``Elton was universally admired by all who knew him,'' said Thomas S. Murphy, chairman and chief executive officer of Capital Cities-ABC Inc. ``He led ABC from a third-place network to equality with CBS and NBC. We are all saddened by his passing.'' During his ABC reign, the network added 68 affiliated stations, while ABC Radio Network grew by 1,435 affiliated stations. Corporate revenues grew from below $600 million in 1968 to more than $2.7 billion in 1983. Earnings grew from $13.5 million to $160 million during the same time period. He left active management in 1984 and continued to serve on the board. Rule is survived by his wife of 47 years, Betty Louise Bender; three children, a grandson and a granddaughter. There will be no funeral and the body will be cremated, according to Rule's wishes, ABC officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Art Dealers Convicted in Sale of Bogus Dali, Celebrity Reproductions
DOC.TEXT: Two art dealers were convicted in a multimillion swindle involving reproductions of works by Salvador Dali and actors Anthony Quinn, Red Skelton and Tony Curtis. A federal jury on Friday convicted William Mett, who owns Center Art Galleries-Hawaii in the Waikiki tourist district, and Marvin Wiseman, director of the gallery, of mail and wire fraud. Mett was convicted of 73 counts and Wiseman of 63 counts. The gallery was convicted of 72 counts. Federal prosecutors said the gallery made huge profits between 1977 and 1989 by buying cheap reproductions of Dali paintings and works by the celebrities and telling buyers the artists were personally involved in the reproduction process. ``My any measure, this was a massive fraud directed at our visitor industry,'' said U.S. Attorney Dan Bent. Assistant U.S. Attorney Les Osborne estimated that customers of the gallery who bought Dali reproductions were defrauded of $113 million from 1977 to 1989. Mett, 47, and Wiseman, 46, said in a joint written statement they will appeal. The gallery bought reproductions of Dali paintings for less than $135 each and sold them for $1,000 to $21,500 apiece, prosecutors said. Each count on which the two were convicted carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Similar fines could be imposed on the company. Sentencing in U.S. District Court was scheduled for Aug. 20.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Envoy Irks Kenya's President With Calls for Political Change
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. ambassador to Kenya has run afoul of President Daniel arap Moi as the Kenyan leader continues to resist calls for a multiparty political system. The ambassador, Smith Hempstone, has publicly suggested that abolishing one-party rule would bring greater democracy and also result in a better investment climate. Moi, who has served unchallenged for 10 years, characterizes those advocating political change in this East African nation as ``tribalists and traitors.'' On Friday, Moi repeated his view that Kenya was not politically mature enough for a multiparty system. While not mentioning Hempstone by name, he hinted at the possiblity of steps against foreign diplomats considered to be interfering in Kenya's affairs. In a fundraising speech, the president noted embassy personnel are allowed to travel freely throughout Kenya and said pointedly he ``would not like to'' restrict those movements. Moi did not specifically mention Hempstone, but his party issued a statement naming the U.S. envoy and declaring: ``We assert, as we have always done, that national interest must never be dictated by external forces.'' It added: ``Kenya is a sovereign state, a fact that is not negotiable and which cannot be compromised at any cost.'' Moi's ruling Kenya African National Union has dominated politics since independence from Great Britain in 1963. Hempstone, a former editor and columnist for the conservative Washington Times, has been highly visible and outspoken since his arrival in Kenya late last year. The latest political debate was ignited three weeks ago when an Anglican bishop, Henry Okullu, called for an end to the one-party system and a limit of two four-year terms for presidents. Since then, other critics have taken up the call, with their demands for change extensively reported by Nairobi's three English-language newspapers. Such public debate is relatively rare in Kenya, where the government has been known to detain its critics. It comes at a time when a number of other African nations, most of them former French colonies in West Africa, have begun to move toward multiparty systems. Moi's party was enshrined as Kenya's only legal party under a 1982 constitutional amendment. On Thursday, two former Cabinet members called for repeal of that amendment, along with the dissolution of Parliament and free elections. One of the two, Kenneth Matiba, a former minister for transport and communications, had been picked up by security police in March and held for questioning. No charges were ever filed.

DOC.HEAD: Sweepstakes Winner Scores Again in Mayor's Race
DOC.TEXT: A man who won $10 million in a magazine contest last year notched another victory Saturday: He was elected mayor of this city of 50,000 residents. Bob Castleberry, 60, said he had thought about running for the non-paying job for years, but couldn't afford to until he won the Publishers Clearinghouse Sweepstakes a year ago. He quit his job as a salesman for a business forms company in January to follow in the political footsteps of his father, who served on the Denton City Council. ``I grew up watching my father giving everything to the community,'' Castleberry said. ``Now I just want to do what I can.'' Castleberry beat two-term incumbent Ray Stephens, winning 50 percent of the vote to Stephens' 45 percent. Appearing in advertisements about the sweepstakes helped in the campaign by boosting his visibility in the community 35 miles northwest of Dallas, the new mayor said. Castleberry gets his $10 million in annal installments: He got $500,000 last year and gets $250,000 a year for the next 27 years, when a lump sum of $2 million is due. Castleberry used part of the money to set up scholarships at Texas A&M University, the University of North Texas and Texas Woman's University and to buy a $32,000 car. It wasn't immediately known how much he spent on the campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Shots Fired Between Fishing Boats in Gulf of Mexico
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with some fishermen detained. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Authorities had reported...
DOC.TEXT: Rival fishing crews fired automatic weapons and rammed each other's boats Saturday in the Gulf of Mexico amid tension between longtime area fishermen and Vietnamese newcomers. No injuries were reported, said Petty Officer Matt McGovern in New Orleans. The shooting stopped when Coast Guard helicopters and boats arrived, McGovern said. ``Some Vietnamese and Americans were shrimping together out there. They got a little too crowded, tempers flared and somebody started shooting,'' said Donald Lirette of Dulac, president of the Terrebonne Fishermen's Organization. Five Vietnamese shrimpers were taken into custody and some number of automatic weapons were confiscated, said Petty Officer John Litzenberger said. Witnesses told the Coast Guard one shrimp boat got its anchor caught in another's trawling nets. ``That's when the firefight started,'' Litzenberger said. Witnesses accused the Vietnamese shrimpers fired on a boat crewed by some longtime Louisiana fishermen, who then shot back, Litzenberger said. The Coast Guard picked up three Vietnamese shrimpers after they jumped into a passing boat and were taken to a nearby oil platform, Litzenberger said. Two other crewmen were later taken into custody, he said. Of 10 boats in the area, only two or three were involved in the shooting, Litzenberger said. Authorities had reported one boat sinking because of the ramming, but Litzenberger said it was out of danger. There has been animosity in Louisiana because of the arrival of Vietnamese shrimp fishing crews, but there has been little violence, Lirette said. ``It's a dog-eat-dog situation when things are like they are now. Everybody's starving,'' Lirette said. ``The American shrimpers can communicate with each other, but they can't communicate with the Vietnamese.'' Three Coast Guard boats, a U.S. Customs Service vessel and a helicopter were sent to the scene, about 5 miles offshore. Litzenberger said authorities would keep watch on the shrimp boats overnight and board the vessels at daylight Sunday. Until then, the fishermen would have to remain aboard their vessels, he said. ``We just have to determine what happened in the first place,'' Litzenberger said.

DOC.HEAD: Romanians Pursue Anti-Communist Protest
DOC.TEXT: More than 8,000 anti-Communist demonstrators thronged downtown University Square for the 13th straight day Friday, demanding the resignation of interim President Ion Iliescu. The round-the-clock protest began April 22 and continued without letup. Protesters say Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, favored to win May 20 elections, have not completely shed Communist beliefs and lean toward authoritarian government. Although the rally has blocked traffic downtown, it gave little sign of being a sharp political confrontation. Demonstrators holding flags and candles were seen debating and huddled around bonfires. Protesters chanted, ``Down with Communism!'' and other slogans expressing opposition to National Salvation Front leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Sudan's Military Leader Pardons Condemned Trade Union Leader
DOC.TEXT: Sudanese strongman Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir on Friday pardoned a trade union leader condemned to death for leading a general strike. He also canceled a prison sentence given another union member and decided to release both men immediately, Egypt's state-owned Middle East News Agency said in a report from Sudan's capital Khartoum. The agency gave no further details but the move was apparently taken in response to appeals at home and abroad. Five days ago, el-Bashir promised a delegation of prominent Sudanese doctors that he would soon respond favorably to their pleas and release the two. The United States and Egypt were among other countries that appealed for the clemency. The pardon followed the execution of 28 army officers and the jailing of 14 others for involvment in an alleged attempt to overthrow the el-Bashir regime April 23. The officers were executed by firing squads after a secret summary court-martial. A militry court sentenced Dr. Mamoun Mohamed Hussein, leader of the disbanded Sudanese Doctors Union, to death by hanging in November for leading a general strike a month earlier to protest the detention of colleagues in military jails and the dismissal of doctors from government posts. Dr. Sayed Mohamed Abdallah was sentenced to 15 years in jail by the same court for taking part in the strike. The court said it based its decision on an emergency law el-Bashir imposed after he seized power June 30 in a military coup. Strikes are banned under the law. The emergency law, among other things, dissolved trade unions, political parties and parliament.

President Bush says that even as he slashes new missile systems and negotiates with the Soviets to reduce others, nuclear weapons are still needed in Europe. ``Only the combination of conventional forces and nuclear forces have insured peace in Europe,'' he said Friday in the first of a series of commencement speeches he will make on the changing geopolitical face of the world. Bush said that in addition to scrapping upgraded Lance missiles in Europe, he wants to begin talks with the Soviets to reduce other short-range missiles shortly after signing a treaty on reducing conventional forces next fall. Nonetheless, he said, ``The United States is not going to allow Europe to become `safe for conventional war.'''

Latvia's lawmakers defied Moscow by declaring independence, but they called for a more gradual break than in neighboring Lithuania and emphasized their desire to negotiate with the Kremlin. ``Everything is ahead,'' Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov said after the vote Friday. ``This is only the very, very beginning.'' Gorbunov said at an evening news conference that the Latvian government had received a proposal from Estonian President Arnold Ruutel to start immediate coordinated actions on the two republics' drives for independence. The 138-0 parliamentary vote, 50 years after Moscow seized the three Baltic states on the Soviet's western border, put Latvia on a similar secessionist path with Lithuania and Estonia.

Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene says a strong declaration of support by Western nations could be decisive in bringing the Baltic republics independence from the Soviet Union. Mrs. Prunskiene's two-day, non-stop crusade for Lithuanian independence at the White House, State Department and on Capitol Hill resulted in an inconclusive session with President Bush. But she said Friday that she continues to hope that Bush and other world leaders can yet be persuaded that embracing independence for Lithuania and its neighbors Latvia and Estonia will not undermine Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his program of political and economic reform. She said the reluctance of Western nations to recognize an independent Lithuania now is ``the main factor'' in the Soviets' refusal to accept her republic's secession as an accomplished fact.

Freed hostage Frank Reed was undergoing medical evaluation today after returning to America and to the arms of his two grown daughters for the first time in eight years. ``Fellow Americans, because of all of you I'm alive,'' he said in thanking friends, family and fellow hostages. On Reed's first night back, the family dined on lobster, the first thing he said he wanted when he got back home from captivity in Lebanon. He tried to catch up on things with his daughters whom he hadn't seen since 1982 and he was laughing again, just the way they remembered him. Reed's daughters, his wife and the crowd that greeted him here Friday wept as he thanked them and eloquently pleaded for the release of ``my mates left behind,'' the remaining six Americans and nine other Westerners held by Islamic militants in Lebanon. ``God, make it soon,'' he prayed.

Greyhound's third-quarter loss of nearly $56 million may make the bus line more anxious to settle the 2-month-old strike by its drivers, the union hopes. Bargaining talks, stalled since mid-March when the company walked out over strike violence, were to resume today at the National Mediation and Conciliation Service. ``We certainly hope, with this financial situation, they come back to the table ready to negotiate,'' said Nick Nichols, a spokesman for the 6,300 bus drivers and 3,000 other workers who have been on strike since March 2. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said the company would have no new proposal on wages to present today. The company has said it is offering $63 million over three years, although the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions contends the bus line is inflating the figure.

The seized assets of Manuel Noriega include some of $11 million he got from U.S. intelligence agencies, his lawyers argued, while asking that the government be forced to release the money so they can be paid. A federal judge Friday ordered the government to justify its seizure of the deposed Panamanian leader's $20 million in assets, which defense attorneys claim were earned legitimately. Noriega's lawyers argued during an hourlong hearing that they cannot proceed without money from bank accounts frozen by the government. They subpoenaed records from the CIA, Drug Enforcement Administration and other agencies as a way to prove Noriega's income was not from drug trafficking. Frank Rubino, Noriega's lead attorney, told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler that U.S. intelligence agencies had paid Noriega $11 million during his years in the Panamanian National Guard.
