DOC.HEAD: Oily Tea Leaves: Interpreting OPEC's Behavior Is Always a Guessing Game
DOC.TEXT: When OPEC ministers proclaimed a 1.5 million barrel-a-day production cut to help stabilize oil prices, the international petroleum market gave them a demonstration of their credibility. Prices fell. The reaction to the accord reached this past week was in many ways predictable. Key members of the 13-nation cartel frequently have cheated undercut each other after past agreements, and some oil intelligence analysts said there wasn't much reason to think it would be different this time. ``These OPEC agreements all tend to have a half-life of a couple of months,'' said Edward Krapels, head of Energy Security Analysis Inc., a Washington-based forecasting and consulting company that advises clients on oil price trends. ``We expect them to erode quickly.'' Nonetheless, Krapels and others said, it is dangerous to dismiss the rhetoric and behavior of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the single-most powerful influence on the fuel that drives the world economy. Although OPEC's word cannot necessarily be trusted, the cartel often has achieved exactly what most of its members want: stable or higher prices in a market that easily could become submerged in more oil than it can absorb. ``The fact remains that anytime the price of oil is in the teens, that is not a natural market price,'' said Stephen Smith, an oil analyst for the Bear Stearns Cos. investment firm in New York. ``Someone is not producing.'' Without any price discipline, oil inevitably would tumble toward the price it costs the leading OPEC producers to extract from the ground, which ranges from $1 to $8 a barrel. ``The fundamental problem of the oil business is that there's just too much fo the stuff around,'' said Krapels. While suddenly cheap oil may sound desirable, it could set off a chain reaction of volatility and panic worldwide. Developing countries that rely on oil revenues could default on billions of dollars in loans, for example. The oil-producing areas of the United States, which are just climbing out of a prolonged recession, could plunge back into another one. Ministers called the emergency OPEC meeting in Geneva in response to a 25 percent drop in crude prices since the beginning of this year, from more than $20 a barrel down to the $15-16 level this spring. Although prices recently have edged back up, the remote but underlying fear remained a production free-for-all that would send oil back toward the $10 nadir reached five years ago. Much of the most recent drop was attributed to violations of self-imposed output limits by three OPEC members that historically have played a crucial role in cartel policy, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. Under this the Geneva agreement, each member will contribute toward reducing the cartel's output by about 1.5 million barrels a day, bringing it down to roughly 22 million barrels vs. 23.5 million barrels in April. Theoretically, that would eliminate much of the glut that has depressed prices and coincide with the seasonally higher demand for oil during the summer. Instead of rallying, however, the oil market weakened. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, an important barometer of demand, the June delivery price of West Texas Intermediate crude dropped 69 cents a barrel on the day the accord was reached, to $17.99. The price closed out the week Friday at $17.98. Some strategists said that despite skepticism about the durability of the OPEC commitment, they believed most members _ including the chronic quota violators _ were worried enough about price instability to stay honest for awhile. ``I take what OPEC says with a grain of salt, because they lie,'' said William Randol, an international oil specialist at the First Boston Co. investment bank in New York. Nonetheless, he said, OPEC fear of a price plunge, combined with inevitably higher demand, would strengthen prices eventually. ``A clumsy agreement is better than no agreement at all,'' said Krapels. ``OPEC, even clumsily, is pretty effective.'' In other business and economic news this past week: _Fears of an economic slowdown arose with the Labor Department report that the U.S. unemployment rate climbed to 5.4 percent, the highest level in more than year. But the stock and bond markets found consolation in the jobless figures on the theory that a weaker economy will ease pressure for higher interest rates. _More bad news than cars seemed to roll off the assembly lines. The major domestic automakers reported sharp drops in first-quarter earnings, primarily because of steep production cuts and weak sales in the North American market. _Two of the biggest themes of the 1980s, takeovers and securities fraud, received major legal jolts. The Supreme Court ruled that corporate mergers can be dismantled through antitrust suits brought by private citizens, further dampening the takeover business. Separately, a federal appeals court nullified a Securities and Exchange Commission rule widely used in insider trading prosecutions.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Outlook Tied Up in Bonds
DOC.TEXT: By the time the government finishes selling $30.5 billion in bonds and notes over the next few days, Wall Streeters hope the outlook will have brightened for the stock market. The record-sized quarterly auction of Treasury securities slated for Tuesday through Thursday has been hashed over for weeks among stock and bond analysts. For a time, some observers believed it would compel the Federal Reserve to tighten its monetary policy merely to make sure that a decent contingent of bidders from around the world showed up. In the past few days, however, the mood in the markets seemed to perk up, with long-term interest rates already at their highest levels since last year around this time. While hopes increased a bit that rates might be near a turning point, investors were confronted with a new cause for pause _ that the zigzagging economy might once more be veering in the direction of a recession. ``The economy is starting to weaken again,'' assert the economists David A. Levy and S. Jay Levy in the latest edition of their newsletter Industry Forecast. ``Right now, many investors are talking about worsening inflation and a pickup in the economy. Three months from now, recession fears will dominate their thinking and the inflation danger will have been all but forgotten.'' Talk of a pickup in business activity and increasing inflationary pressures was abruptly quieted Friday, when the Labor Department reported that the civilian unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point in April to 5.4 percent. The figures also showed an increase of 64,000 in nonfarm payroll employment, far less than economists had been expecting. That presumably didn't bode well for corporate earnings in the second quarter and beyond, at a time when some forecasters had been looking for profits to start pulling out of their recent slump. Nevertheless, some analysts say other, positive forces are at work in the market for Treasury securities that shouldn't be overlooked. For one thing, they say, an increased emphasis on savings over spending in this country has started to ease the United States's much-lamented dependency on foreign capital to finance its deficit spending. Stock traders seemed willing at least to listen to such arguments in the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 65.31 to 2,710.36. The New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 4.63 to 185.37; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market added 10.63 to 428.61, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 3.09 at 345.73. Volume on the Big Board averaged 139.90 million shares a day, against 135.59 million the week before. In recent years, observed John Connolly at Dean Witter Reynolds, ``every major government refunding has become a cliff-hanger. Will foreign investors show up, or will the auctions be a flop? Such uncertainty breeds higher interest rates.'' But more recently, Connolly contends, the trends that helped create this situation have shifted. ``The savings rate has risen steadily, which, combined with higher incomes, has substantially increased the pool of savings. At the same time the government deficit has abated somewhat. ``The numbers are changing, and this will eventually affect markets,'' he concludes. ``The United States has, in the last two years, made major strides toward financial self-sufficiency.''

DOC.HEAD: Managers Buying Deutz-Allis From German Company Say They're Optimistic
DOC.TEXT: A group of Deutz-Allis Corp. managers who are buying the farm equipment maker from its West German parent said Friday they hope to profit from pent-up demand for agricultural equipment. ``We're extremely optimistic,'' said Robert Ratliff, president and chief executive officer of Deutz-Allis and leader of the five-member management buyout team. ``All of us recognize that the ag economy has recovered and is strongly positioned for the future.'' The group formed a holding company, Allis-Gleaner Co., with financing from New York-based Hamilton Robinson and Company, Inc., to purchase Deutz-Allis from its German parent, Kloekner-Humboldt-Deutz AG (KHD), Ratliff said. He refused to disclose the sale price. The new owners plan no organizational or product changes, they said, and will honor all existing contracts, warranties and dealer agreements in the U.S. and Canada. ``The only change is that we're bringing the company back to U.S. ownership,'' Ratliff said. KHD formed Deutz-Allis in 1985 after buying the farm equipment manufacturing line of Allis-Chalmers Corp. The company lost $80 million in 1987 in the midst of the farm recession but narrowed that to $8.8 million last year after cutting costs and laying off half its 1,800 employees. Under its new owners, the company will continue distributing Deutz-Allis tractors and hay, tilling and lawn and garden equipment in the U.S. through an agreement with KHD. Deutz-Allis also will continue operating its sales and service network of about 800 U.S. dealers and continue making Gleaner crop harvesting combines at a plant in Independence, Mo. Deutz-Allis, with sales of $307 million last year, holds a small fraction of the U.S. farm equipment market dominated by Deere & Company and J.I. Case, said Tobias Levkovich, an industry analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. ``They're a shell of what they used to be,'' Levkovich said. But he predicted the company could still benefit from a farm economy upswing he estimated would last three to five years. ``The business right now is very strong,'' Levkovich said, with both sales of large tractors and combines climbing in recent months. KHD had announced the sale Thursday in West Germany. It also confirmed it was selling its aerospace technology subsidiary to Bayerische Motoren Werke AG (BMW).
